questions.text: A 45 year old lady presents with a 5cm mass in the breast and 3cm node in the ipsilateral supraclavicular fossa. TNM staging is :
questions.solution:
The TNM staging in this patient is T2N3M0.

  • T2 involves mass 2-5cm in size.
  • N3 indicates ipsilateral infraclavicular/internal mammary and axillary/supraclavicular lymph nodes.
  • M0 indicates absence of distant metastasis.

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of Carcinoma Breast

Tumor (T)

Description
Tx

No evidence of primary tumor
Tis (DCIS) Ductal carcinoma in situ
Tis (Paget) Paget disease not associated with invasive carcinoma or DCIS

1mic ≤ 0.1 cm

1a >0.1 to 0.5 cm

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

Tumor of any size and -

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – Inflammatory breast carcinoma (typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*
Nodes (N) Description
N1 mic Refers to micrometastasis to Lymph node

N2A Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes
N2B Ipsilateral internal mammary without axillary lymph node involvement
N3A Ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes
N3B Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes
N3C Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes
Distant metastasis (M) Description
M0 Metastasis absent
M1 Metastasis present

 

Stages T, N  M
Stage 0 TisN0 M0
Stage IA T1N0 M0
Stage IB T0,1N1mic M0
Stage IIA T0,1N1 (or) T2N0 M0
Stage IIB T2N1 (or) T3N0 M0
Stage IIIA T0,1,2,3N2 (or) T3N1 M0
Stage IIIB T4 N0,1,2 M0
Stage IIIC

Any T, N3

# Chest wall includes Serratus anterior, Intercostal muscles, Ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of the chest wall.

* Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage 4d) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of the breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered a benign condition and not included under Tis.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging
  • y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)
  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents concerns related to a sudden increase in mole size present over his arm. You notice an asymmetrical nevus of variable shape. Which among the following is the best prognostic marker for this condition?
questions.solution:
The condition given in this scenario with an asymmetric nevus with variable shape and history of sudden increase in size is most probably a malignant melanoma. The best prognostic marker for this condition is the depth of invasion also known as Breslow thickness.

Breslow thickness is the measurement of the depth of the melanoma from the surface of your skin down through to the deepest point of the tumor. 

It’s measured in millimeters (mm) with a small ruler, called a micrometer. The pathologist uses this ruler with a microscope when looking at your tissue sample in the laboratory. Doctors use the Breslow depth in melanoma for the TNM staging system.

Related Pearl: Breslow’s Classification of Malignant Melanoma

Breslow's classification of malignant melanoma:

Stage Depth
Stage I ≤ 0.75mm
Stage II 0.76 mm - 1.50mm
Stage III 1.51 mm - 4 mm
Stage IV >4 mm

 

TNM staging based on the thickness of invasion according to AJCC:

  • T1 - ≤1.0 mm
  • T2 - 1.01-2.0 mm
  • T3 - 2.01-4.0 mm
  • T4 - >4.0 mm

questions.text:
Match the following parasites with their respective hosts:
1. Diphyllobothrium latum a. Sheep
2. Paragonimus westermani b. Crayfish
3. Brugia malayi c. Cyclops
4. Fasciola hepatica d. Mansonia
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option is 4-a, 2-b, 1-c, 3-d.

Diphyllobothrium latum infection is acquired by eating raw or undercooked fish containing third-stage plerocercoid larva. It usually causes diphyllobothriasis (Transient abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, nausea, weakness, weight loss) and vitamin B12 deficiency by absorbing large quantities of vitamin B12 and interfering with the ileal absorption

  • Definitive hosts: Man, dog, and cat. Man is the optimal host.
  • First intermediate host: Cyclops or Diaptomus.
  • Second intermediate host: Freshwater fish (salmon, trout, etc.).

Treatment for Diphyllobothrum latum infection is Praziquantel.

The image below shows the life cycle of Diphyllobothrium latum 

 

Paragonimus westermani (lung fluke) infection is acquired by consuming freshwater crab/crayfish containing metacercariae. It causes pulmonary symptoms similar to pulmonary tuberculosis (coughing and hemoptysis).

  • Definitive host: Man, cats, tigers, leopards, foxes, dogs, pigs, beavers, and domestic animals
  • First intermediate host: Freshwater snail
  • Second intermediate host: Freshwater crab or crayfish.

The adult worms live in the respiratory tract of the definitive host in cystic spaces surrounded by a fibrous capsule formed by the host tissues. Unembryonated eggs escape into the bronchi and are coughed up and voided in sputum or swallowed and passed in feces.

Praziquantel (25 mg/ kg TDS for 1-2 days) is the drug of choice.

The given image shows the life cycle of Paragonimus westermani

 

Fasciola hepatica is a liver fluke that resides in the liver and the lumen of the biliary passages and causes fascioliasis. It mainly affects sheep and other domestic animals. Infection in sheep and man is acquired by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation.

  • Definitive host: Sheep, goat, cattle, and man.
  • Intermediate host: Snails of the genus Lymnaea and Succinea. Encystment occurs on aquatic plants, which act as second intermediate host.

Oral triclabendazole (10 mg/kg once) is the treatment of choice

Life cycle of Fasciola hepatica

 

Brugia malayi causes filariasis in man. The intermediate host of Brugia are vectors of genera Mansonia. In India, main vectors are Mansonia annulifera and M. uniformis.

Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice. It is given orally in a dose of 6 mg/ kg body weight daily for a period of 12 days.

Life cycle of Brugia malayi

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with poor dental hygiene complaints of painful swallowing, difficulty in opening his mouth, and a neck swelling which has been increasing over the past 3 days. On examination, there is a woody hard swelling of the floor of the mouth. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above patient with odynophagia, trismus, swelling in the floor of the mouth with a woody-hard feel, and the tongue is pushed up and back is likely to have Ludwig's angina.

Ludwig's angina is the infection of the submandibular space present on the floor of the mouth. The mylohyoid muscle divides this space into the sublingual space (above the mylohyoid) and the submaxillary and submental compartment (below the mylohyoid). Dental infections are the most common cause.

The infections are usually polymicrobial. Alpha-hemolytic streptococci, staphylococci, and Bacteroides groups are commonly associated.

Patients present with difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) and trismus. Examination of the oral cavity will reveal that the floor of the mouth is swollen and the tongue is pushed up and back. The submental and submandibular spaces become swollen, tender, and have a woody-hard feel.

It is treated by systemic antibiotics, incision and drainage of the abscess, and tracheostomy if the airway is threatened. 

Complications of this condition include the spread of infection to the parapharyngeal space, retropharyngeal space, and the mediastinum, airway obstruction, septicemia, and aspiration pneumonia.

 

Other options:

Option B: Parapharyngeal abscess can occur from acute and chronic infections of the tonsils, dental infections, and infections of the parotid, retropharyngeal and submaxillary spaces. Patients with anterior compartment involvement present with prolapse of the tonsil and tonsillar pillar, trismus, and external swelling behind the angle of the jaw, and patients with posterior compartment involvement present with bulges of the pharynx behind the posterior pillar, paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X, XI and XII and sympathetic chain, and swelling of the parotid region. Symptoms common to both compartments are fever, odynophagia, sore throat, torticollis, and signs of toxemia.

Option C: An acute retropharyngeal abscess usually occurs in children below 3 years of age due to infections of adenoids or tonsils causing suppuration in the retropharyngeal lymph nodes which leads to the formation of an abscess. The clinical features of a retropharyngeal abscess include dysphagia, dyspnea, stridor, croupy cough, torticollis (extended stiff neck), and swelling on one side of the midline. (Posterior pharyngeal wall)

The image given below shows the X-ray of the retropharyngeal abscess.

 

Option D: Vincent's angina presents with low-grade fever, sore throat, and a membrane over the tonsil. The membrane is easily removed to reveal irregular ulcers over the tonsil. A throat swab will show both the organisms typical of the disease, namely fusiform bacilli and spirochaetes, specifically Borrelia vincentii.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the drain shown in the image below?

choices.text: It is a closed type of drain
Drain removal is done 72 hrs after thyroidectomy
Routinely used after ventral hernia repair

questions.solution:
The drain given in the image is a Romovac drain and it is usually removed within 24 hours post thyroidectomy. Their main purpose is to cover postoperative bleeding. 

Romovac drain is a type of closed drain kept in the subcutaneous tissue (Option A). Active drainage of contents is seen due to the negative suction (Option B). It is routinely used in ventral hernia repairs, thyroidectomy, lymph node dissections, modified radical mastectomy, subcutaneous swelling excision, amputations, etc (Option C).

Drains are placed at surgical sites to freely collect the air or fluids that may accumulate. This enhances wound healing by preventing the formation of unnecessary cavities. Drains are prophylactic in elective surgeries and therapeutic in emergency surgeries.

Drains can be:

  • Open- they are based on the principle of gravity and passive drainage.
  • Closed
    1. Suctioned: Active drainage through negative pressure created by suction.
    2. Non-suctioned: Passive drainage through capillary action and gravity. Examples include urinary catheters and nasogastric drainage systems.

The time of removal of drains for various conditions is as given below:

  • Drains used in surgeries like thyroidectomy are usually removed within 24 hours. Their main purpose is to cover postoperative bleeding.
  • Drains used to cover the gastrointestinal anastomoses are placed for 3-5 days
  • Common bile duct T-tube drains are usually placed for 2-3 weeks
  • Drains for infections are removed when the infection subsides or when the content of the drain is minimal.

questions.text: Which of the following is a fibrin specific plasminogen activator and avoids the systemic lytic state?
questions.solution:
Alteplase is a relatively fibrin specific plasminogen activator. By preferentially activating fibrin bound plasminogen, it usually avoids the systemic lytic state.

Alteplase is used in thrombolysis in myocardial infarction, major pulmonary embolism, or acute ischemic stroke. Side effects include a risk of significant bleeding, including cerebral haemorrhage.

Other options:

Streptokinase, urokinase and anistreplase are non-specific fibrinolytic agents. There is no distinction made between circulating and fibrin-bound plasminogen by nonspecific plasminogen activators.

Option A: Streptokinase lowers mortality in individuals receiving systemic treatment for acute MI. Side effects include transient hypotension, allergic reactions or rarely anaphylactic reactions.

Option B: Urokinase is frequently used for the catheter-directed lysis of thrombi in the peripheral arteries or deep veins.

Option C: Anistreplase is not clinically used due to its high cost and less effectiveness when compared to alteplase.

questions.text: Which diagnostic test would be the most appropriate choice for detection of HIV in the window period?
questions.solution:
HIV RNA detection (RT-PCR): This test directly detects HIV RNA, the viral genetic material, as early as 10-12 days after exposure. It is the most sensitive and specific test available, making it the optimal choice for diagnosing HIV within the window period.

The period between infection and detection of antibodies against HIV is known as the window period. The window period may last anywhere between 2–8 weeks to a few months. During this period, the individual may be highly infectious. HIV infection can be detected during this period by p24 antigen assay and RNA PCR.

Other options: 

Option A: ELISA for HIV antibodies: While the most common HIV test, antibodies typically take 2-8 weeks to become detectable, falling entirely within the window period in this case.

Option B: Western blot test: This confirmatory test detects specific viral proteins, but it's often used to confirm positive ELISA results rather than for primary diagnosis. 

Option C: Rapid HIV tests: These finger-prick tests are convenient but lack sensitivity and accuracy during the window period, making them unreliable for early diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to PHC with complaints of cough, sore throat, fever and sandpaper rash over her trunk and extremities. Treatment of her condition will prevent which of the following complications?

PHC - Primary Healthcare Centre
questions.solution:
This patient with symptoms suggestieve of an upper respiratory tract infection ie cough, sore throat and fever along with sandpaper rash are suggestive of scarlet fever which is caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci. Acute rheumatic fever is one of the main indications for antibiotic treatment of streptococcal pharyngitis.

Post-infection sequelae of scarlet fever include rheumatic fever, glomerulonephritis, reactive arthritis, PANDAS(pediatric autoimmune neuropsychiatric disorders associated with streptococcal infection).

Scarlet fever  is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, which produces pyrogenic exotoxins. The clinical features of scarlet fever are fever, rhinitis, strawberry tongue, and an erythematous sandpaper rash, which later desquamates. The tongue is coated and papillae are swollen and remain prominent after desquamation, giving rise to the strawberry appearance.

The following image shows strawberry tongue, also called raspberry tongue as seen in Scarlet fever.

questions.text: You are conducting a meta-analysis of studies on the effects of statin drugs and the risk of developing ventricular arrhythmias in patients with cardiomyopathy. The analysis is presented as the following plot. Which among the given statements is incorrect regarding the interpretation of these plots?

choices.text: The diamond shows the overall pooled results
Each rectangle depicts a single study
The vertical dashed line is the “line of no effect"
The size of the rectangle denotes the sample size

questions.solution:
The given plot for the meta-analysis is a forest plot. The vertical solid line is the “line of no effect", signifying no difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1)

The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analyzed measure of effect.

Forest plots allow the results to be seen at a glance with the identification of the outliers.

Interpretation of the graph given in the image: 

  • Each rectangle represents a single study. 
    - ex: Smith et al, Jones et al 
  • The size of the rectangle represents the sample size
    - ex: Smith et al 1999 had a small sample size whereas Chu et al 2009 had a large sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side represents the confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
    - ex: Ng et al 2004 has a small confidence interval and is more reliable than Jones et al 1993 as it has longer confidence intervals
  • The vertical solid line- the “line of no effect", no difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1) 
    -the location of the result depicts whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not. Any study line which crosses the line of null effect does not illustrate a statistically significant result.
  • A diamond represents the overall pooled result of the meta-analysis where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged. 
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
 

Related Pearl: Forest Plot

  • A forest plot is used to present the results of a meta-analysis.
  • It is also called blobbogram.

Interpretation of forest plots: 

  • The rectangles represent the single studies
  • The size of the rectangle is proportional to the sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side - confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
  • The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 
  • The location of the result - whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not
  • A diamond shows the overall pooled result where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
  • The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analysed measure of effect.

Let's understand with an example - 

  • For study A- it has a wide horizontal line that crosses the line of null effect with a black box that is to the right of the vertical line. This most likely demonstrates a small scale study with few participants where the point estimate result favours the control used in the study. But because the study contains the null value in its 95% confidence interval, it is likely to have a p-value >0.05 and not be statistically significant.
  • For study B- it has quite a narrow line that does not cross the line of null effect with a black box that is to the left of the vertical line and is bigger than study A. This most likely demonstrates a larger study with more participants compared to study A, where the result favours the intervention used. Because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the null value, this study is likely to have a p-value <0.05 and hence the differences observed in the study can be regarded as statistically significant.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient department with complaints that the scrotum is sometimes empty. On examination,  stimulation of the skin of the scrotum or thigh causes the testis to ascend and temporarily disappear into the inguinal canal. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate method of management of this condition would be to advise no treatment.

This patient with complaints of temporary disappearance of testis from the scrotum and his examination findings are suggestive of retractile testis. A patient with retractile testis usually requires no treatment.

A retractile testis is a normally developed and descended testis that retracts back into the inguinal canal due to hyper-reflexive cremasteric muscle contraction.

Therefore any stimulation of the skin of the scrotum or thigh causes the testis to ascend and temporarily disappear into the inguinal canal. When the cremaster relaxes, the testis reappears in the scrotum.

The scrotum of a boy with such a retractile testis is normal, that is, normal rugosity is seen.

Chair test helps to differentiate retractile testis from ectopic testis because both of them involve the testis lying in an abnormal position. In this test, the young patient is asked to sit on a chair hugging his knees to his chest. This manoeuvre helps the retractile testis to get pushed down back to the bottom of the scrotum and retractile testis can be differentiated from the ectopic testis.

Other options:

Option B: Orchidectomy, removal of the testis is considered in cases of undescended testis if the incompletely descended testis is atrophic, particularly in the postpubertal boy if the other testis is normal.

Option C: Surgical exploration is the treatment of choice for testicular torsion. 

Option D: Orchidopexy is the treatment of choice for ectopic testis.

questions.text: You observe a nurse administering an intramuscular injection to a patient in the clinic. Which of the following was likely being administered to the patient?
questions.solution:
Tetanus toxoid is likely to be administered intramuscularly.

The intramuscular route (IM) of drug administration is mostly given in the deltoid, gluteal region, and anterolateral aspect of the thigh where the muscle is bulkier. This route bypasses the first-pass metabolism and reaches systemic circulation quickly. 

This method is suitable for moderate volumes, oily vehicles, and some irritating substances. Absorption of drugs in an aqueous solution after IM injection depends on the rate of blood flow to the injection site and can be relatively rapid. Thus, the injections given in the gluteal region are relatively more slowly absorbed in females than in males. Depot injections may produce slow and prolonged action. 

The Z-track technique is used for intramuscular injections in which the needle is inserted at 90 degrees with a quick darting movement. This prevents skin staining through the tract to the surface of the skin. Pain intensity is also reduced.

 

Intramuscular injections are contraindicated if there is an active infection at the site of administration, coagulation defects, and thrombocytopenia.

Other routes of administration are oral (undergoes first-pass metabolism), intravenous (100% bioavailability and bypasses first-pass metabolism), subcutaneous, inhalational (e.g Metered dose inhaler, rotahaler), topical (including eye and skin preparations), and rectal.

Other options:

Options A and B: Test doses of drugs and BCG vaccines are administered intradermally.

Option D: Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is administered subcutaneously. Heparin can be given through intravenous and subcutaneous routes.

questions.text: You are working in the intensive care unit. Your resident asks you to perform arterial blood sampling in a patient. Which of the following steps you should not do?

choices.text: Pull back the syringe plunger to collect blood
Ask the patient to relax his fist
Transport the sample in container containing crushed ice

questions.solution:
During arterial blood sampling, we should not pull back the syringe plunger.

Arterial blood sampling

Materials required

  • Preheparinised syringe
  • Needles (20, 23 and 25 gauge)
  • A safety syringe with a needle cover
  • A bandage to cover the puncture site after collection
  • A container with crushed ice for transportation of the sample

Procedure

Approach the patient, introduce yourself and ask the patient to state their full name. Make the patient lie on his/her back comfortably. If the patient is clenching their fist, holding their breath or crying, this can alter the test results.

Locate the radial artery and performing an Allen test to check for collateral circulation. If the collateral circulation is poor, choose other hand for blood sampling.

Perform hand hygiene, clean the sampling site with 70% ethyl alcohol and allow it to dry. Assemble the needle and heparinised syringe. Pull the syringe plunger to the required fill level. 

Hold the syringe like a dart and palpate the radial pulse with the index finger. Once the pulse is localised, insert the needle into the artery at 45 degrees, approximately 1 cm distal to the index finger. Once the needle reaches the radial artery, blood flashes in the syringe. Allow the syringe to fill to the appropriate level. Do not pull back the syringe plunger.

Withdraw the needle and syringe. Place a clean, dry piece of gauze or cotton wool over the site and have the patient or an assistant apply firm pressure for sufficient time to stop the bleeding.

Remove the air bubble if present within the syringe. Place the sample in a container containing crushed ice if the analysis is not done in the point of care.

 

Below gif shows Allen's test used to assess collateral circulation in the hand before performing arterial sampling.

questions.text:
Which of the following structures are removed in Scanlon’s modified radical mastectomy?

  1. Skin over breast tissue
  2. Axillary lymph nodes
  3. Pectoralis minor
  4. Pectoralis major
  5. Nipple-areola complex
questions.solution:
Scanlon’s modified radical mastectomy involves mastectomy with removal of the nipple areola complex and axillary lymph node dissection with division but not excision of pectoralis minor.

Structures removed in modified radical mastectomy:

  • Whole breast tissue
  • The skin over the breast tissue
  • Nipple-areola complex
  • Pectoral fascia
  • Levels I, II, ± III axillary lymph nodes

The pectoralis minor muscle is removed in Patey’s mastectomy while it is retracted in Auchincloss’s modification.

Other statements:

Statement 3: Pectoralis minor is divided but not removed in Scanlon’s procedure.

Statement 4: Pectoralis major is not removed in modified radical mastectomy.

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presents with 50% second-degree burns. She weighs 100 kgs. Which of the following is true regarding fluid resuscitation in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case, patient weighs 100kgs with burns involving 50% of the total body surface area (TBSA). The resuscitation formula used in thermal burns in adults is 2 mL/kg × % TBSA. Therefore, the total fluid to be administered is = (2 ml x 100 kg) x 50% = 10000 mL = 10 Litres. The patient should be resuscitated with 50% of the total fluid required (i.e. 5 liters) in the first 8 hours.

Fluid resuscitation in burns:

Intravenous fluid resuscitation is done in adults with second degree and third degree burns > 15% TBSA (Total body surface area) and in children with burns > 10% TBSA.

According to ATLS 10th edition, 2018, the resuscitation formula used in thermal burns in adults is 2 mL/kg × % TBSA. 50% of the total fluid is given in the first 8 hours after the burns injury and the remaining 50% is given in the subsequent 16 hours. This can be calculated as:

First 8 hours: 1 mL/kg × % TBSA (lactated Ringer solution)
Next 16 hours: 1 mL/kg × % TBSA (lactated Ringer solution)

For a patient presenting 8 hours after sustaining thermal burns, the total volume using resuscitation formula should be given in the next 16 hours i.e; 2 mL/kg × % TBSA in the next 16 hours while maintaining a target urine output of 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults.

In adults, urine output should be maintained between 30 and 50 cc/hr to minimize potential over-resuscitation.

In case of paediatric burns, the resuscitation formula used in thermal burns is 3 mL/kg × % TBSA.

 

Note:

The goal of resuscitation is to maintain the fine balance of adequate perfusion as indicated by urine output. It is important to understand that formulas provide a starting target rate; subsequently, the amount of fluids provided should be adjusted based on a urine output target of 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults and 1 mL/kg/hr for children weighing less than 30 kg.

The total percentage of the burnt area is calculated clinically using the rule of nines.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: A researcher recently found out that the heart muscle has the highest arteriovenous oxygen difference of 120 ml/L. Considering that the lungs absorb 200 ml of O2 per minute from the atmosphere. What is the expected cardiac output?
questions.solution:
The expected cardiac output is 1.67 L/min.

Based on the Fick principle, cardiac output can be calculated by the following equation:

Cardiac output (L/min) = (O2 absorbed per minute by the lungs (mL/min)) / (Arterio-venous O2 difference (mL/L of blood)) 

In the given scenario:

  • The oxygen consumption of the heart muscle or the arteriovenous difference of the pulmonary artery and the pulmonary vein is 120 ml/L.
  • O2 absorbed by the lungs: 200ml/min

Hence cardiac output = 200 ml/min / 120 ml/L= 1.67 L/min 

Cardiac output is the amount of blood pumped by the heart into the aorta every minute. The average cardiac output is 5L/min and can be measured by various indirect methods.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man working in a wool factory presents with a 1-week history of fever, cough, and severe hemoptysis. Chest X-ray reveals mediastinal widening. The specimen collected shows positive Ascoli test. Which of the following monoclonal antibodies is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This scenario is highly suggestive of inhalational anthrax and Raxibacumab is a human monoclonal antibody specifically designed to neutralize the protective antigen of anthrax. It a life-threatening bacterial infection caused by Bacillus anthracis spores, confirmed by the positive Ascoli thermoprecipitation test. 

Treatment for anthrax includes antibiotic therapy with ciprofloxacin, penicillin G, doxycycline, erythromycin, or vancomycin. Post-exposure prophylaxis after potential exposure includes ciprofloxacin or doxycycline for 60 days and three doses of vaccine called 'AVA BioThrax'. It is a bioterrorism category A agent and is a potential tool in biological warfare.

Other options:

Option A: Natalizumab: This monoclonal antibody is used for the treatment of multiple sclerosis and Crohn's disease. It has no role in the management of anthrax.

Option B: Tocilizumab: This monoclonal antibody is used for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis. It has no specific activity against Bacillus anthracis.

Option C: Reslizumab: This monoclonal antibody is used for the treatment of severe eosinophilic asthma. It is not effective against anthrax.

questions.text: What are sirtuins?
questions.solution:
Sirtuins are a family of NAD-dependent protein deacetylases.

Sirtuins comprise of proteins that inhibit metabolic activity, reduce apoptosis, stimulate protein folding, and inhibit the harmful effects of oxygen-free radicals. They help adapt to various environmental stresses, including food deprivation and DNA damage and hence sirtuins are thought to increase longevity. Sirtuins also increase insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism and may target for the treatment of diabetes. Caloric restriction also increases sirtuin production

Other options

Option A: Demethylases(14 alpha-sterol demethylase) are enzymes present in fungi that convert lanosterol to ergosterol. The azole group of antifungals inhibit this enzyme.

Option C: Site-specific DNA methylases are associated with restriction endonucleases. Restriction endonucleases are present only in cells that also have a companion enzyme that site-specifically methylates the host DNA, rendering it an unsuitable substrate for digestion by that particular restriction enzyme. The methylation of histones is associated with the regulation of gene expression.

Option D: Acetylases are involved in acetylation which generally leads to transcriptional activation of DNA. The process of thyroid hormone synthesis is subject to modification through the acetylation of the thyroid hormone receptor.

questions.text:
A 3-day-old infant is brought with a rash. On examination chorioretinitis and microcephaly are noted, with no cardiovascular abnormality. Which of the following is not included in your differential diagnosis?

CMV-Cytomegalovirus
questions.solution:
Among the options, neonatal lupus would not come under your differentials as patients with neonatal lupus usually have petechial rashes and no chorioretinitis and no microcephaly. 

Neonatal lupus erythematosus is thought to be caused by the transplacental passage of maternal antibodies. It is characterised by skin lesions known as lupus dermatitis in newborns, as well as various haematological and systemic abnormalities. In some cases, congenital heart block (no CVS anomaly in this patient) may also occur. Thrombocytopenia and hepatic involvement are also seen.

It is also associated with the presence of maternal antibodies like anti-Ro, anti-RNP and anti-La. 

The most common cutaneous finding in neonatal lupus erythematosus is an erythematous, slightly scaly eruption on the face and periorbital skin (raccoon sign/owl eye/eye mask). The eruption can be exacerbated by UV exposure. The rash improves over the first few months of life and usually resolves without scarring by 12 months of age.

Avoidance of sunlight should be advised and low‐potency topical steroids may be of benefit.

Other options:

Option A: Congenital toxoplasmosis is acquired by the transplacental route. Infants are usually born with inactive disease. It is characterised by sensorineural hearing loss, microcephaly and chorioretinitis.

Option B: Congenital CMV presents with hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. Head neuroimaging shows intracranial periventricular calcifications. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss. Diagnosis is made by isolating the virus from the urine or blood by polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

Option C: Congenital Zika syndrome is caused by Zika virus (RNA virus). It is a flavivirus transmitted primarily by infected mosquitoes of the Aedes genus, mainly the Aedes aegypti. Pregnant women are infected, particularly during the first trimester and via transplacental transmission they infect fetal neuronal tissue, leading to microcephaly, chorioretinitis, facial disproportion, seizures, neurologic abnormalities and maculopapular rash. It can also lead to abortions, preterm births and stillbirths.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was brought with complaints of eye pain. On examination, you see multiple corneal erosions. Excessive epidermal thickening of the palms and soles was also observed. Detailed laboratory evaluation revealed a deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine transaminase. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine transaminase is suggestive of type II tyrosinemia.

Tyrosinemia type II (Richner-Hanhart syndrome) is caused by a defective TAT gene. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Clinically, children present with painful herpetiform dendritic corneal ulcers, photophobia, palmoplantar keratosis, and intellectual disability.

The image given below shows herpetiform dendritic corneal ulcers seen in type II tyrosinemia.

 

The laboratory finding includes marked hypertyrosinemia and elevated tyrosine and tyramine in urine. The treatment for this condition is a diet low in protein.

The image given below shows the metabolism of tyrosine.

 

Other options:

Option A: Type I tyrosinemia is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. Children present with mild mental retardation, liver failure, and hypoglycemia. Urine typically has a boiled cabbage odor.

Option C: Alkaptonuria occurs due to a deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase. It is an autosomal recessive condition. Patients present with arthritis (usually occurs in the third decade) and bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue (ochronosis). Urine in these patients turns dark in color on standing for long.

Option D: Albinism occurs due to a deficiency of the enzyme tyrosinase. Clinical features include white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-grey in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common location of Ghon's focus?
questions.solution:
Primary bronchus does not describe the location of Ghon's focus as the tubercle bacilli implants in distal air spaces, not proximal.

Ghon's focus is the gray-white inflammation with consolidation. It is seen in primary tuberculosis. The common location of Ghon's focus is the lower part of the upper lobe or the upper part of the lower lobe, usually close to the pleura. Ghon's focus along with the nodal involvement is called the Ghon's complex.

The following image shows the presence of Ghon's complex on chest X-ray :

 

Primary tuberculosis occurs on first exposure. The following findings may be seen:

Ghon's focus - focus of infection located subpleurally
Ghon's complex - Ghon's focus with lymph node involvement
Ranke complex - a calcified Ghon's complex

Secondary tuberculosis occurs due to the reactivation of TB. It affects the apex. The following findings may be seen:

Puhl's complex - supraclavicular lesion
Assmann's complex - infraclavicular lesion

Disseminated or miliary tuberculosis is characterised by 1-2 mm disseminated lesions all over the lung. The following findings may be associated:

Simon's focus - early hematogenous seeding in the apex of lungs
Rich focus - tuberculous caseous foci in brain, meninges and spinal cord

questions.text: A patient with acute intestinal obstruction and bowel distension is posted for immediate laparotomy. Which of the following anesthetic agent is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Nitrous oxide is contraindicated in a patient with intestinal obstruction and bowel distension. This is due to its tendency of rapid diffusion into air-containing cavities than nitrogen in the blood, thus increasing the pressure.

Nitrous oxide is the least potent inhalational anesthetic agent. It has a very high diffusion capacity than nitrogen (air) itself, which causes the cavity to expand. Thus it is avoided in cases like pneumothorax, air embolism, acute intestinal obstruction with bowel distention, intracranial air, pulmonary air cysts, intraocular air bubbles, and tympanic membrane grafting.

It can even diffuse into tracheal tube cuffs, thus increasing its pressure and hampering mucosal blood circulation. It is also avoided in patients at high risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV).

Other side effects include bone marrow depression, megaloblastic anemia, teratogenicity and peripheral neuropathy.

Other options:

Option B - Desflurane is avoided in patients with severe hypovolemia, malignant hyperthermia, and intracranial hypertension.

Option C - Halothane is avoided in patients with unexplained liver dysfunction, intracranial space-occupying lesions and reduced left ventricular function.

Option D - Isoflurane has no unique contraindications but has to be avoided in patients with the risk of developing malignant hyperthermia as it can be a triggering agent.  

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

MAC (Potency)

Blood-gas coefficient (Solubility)
Halothane 0.75  2.4
Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. The lower the MAC, the higher is the potency.

questions.text: In which of the following layers of skin are desmosomes abundant?
questions.solution:
Desmosomes are abundant in the stratum spinosum layer of the epidermis. Stratum spinosum in the above image is represented by ‘3’.

The stratum spinosum/spinous layer/prickle cell layer is situated immediately above the basal cell layer. The epibasal keratinocytes enlarge to form this layer.

The desmosomes appear like spines on microscopy, and hence, this layer is also called the prickle layer. Desmosomes are the major adhesion complex in the epidermis. They anchor keratin intermediate filaments to the cell membrane and form bridges between adjacent keratinocytes. 

One of the main components of desmosomes is a transmembrane cadherin called desmoglein (Dsg). There are 4 types of epidermis‐specific desmogleins— Dsg1 to Dsg4. Disruption of Dsg1 occurs in staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome and bullous impetigo. Dsg-2 damage is associated with arrythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy and Dsg-3 damage is associated with pemphigus vulagris. Antibodies to desmosomal proteins may develop in conditions like paraneoplastic pemphigus.

From superficial to deep, the layers of the epidermis are marked in the below image-

  1. Stratum corneum
  2. Stratum granulosum
  3. Stratum spinosum
  4. Stratum basale

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man was started on PEP-C for refractory multiple myeloma. Ten minutes after initiating therapy, he developed blurring of vision, breathing difficulty, sweating, headache, nausea, and vomiting. History reveals heavy alcohol consumption by the patient since his wife's death recently. Which drug in his regimen would have led to these symptoms?

PEP-C : Prednisone, etoposide, procarbazine and cyclophosphamide
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of a disulfiram-like reaction. Procarbazine is associated with a disulfiram-like reaction following alcohol ingestion. 

Disulfiram-like reaction with alcohol ingestion is seen with the following drugs:

  • Metronidazole
  • 1st generation sulfonylureas like chlorpropamide
  • Cephalosporins like cefoperazone, cefamandole
  • Griseofulvin
  • Procarbazine

questions.text: In a laboratory, a bacterium is seeded into a suitable liquid medium and incubated. Bacterial counts are made at intervals after inoculation and plotted in relation to time. A growth curve is obtained as shown below. Which of the following statements regarding the bacterial growth curve is not true?

choices.text: Adaptation to new environment occurs in phase A
Exotoxins are produced in phase C
Maximum size is in phase D
Cells stain uniformly in phase B

questions.solution:
The maximum size of the cell is towards the end of phase A, not D.

Phases of bacterial growth: 

  1. Lag phase (Marked as A)
    • Occurs immediately after the seeding of a culture media.
    • There is no increase in cell number but cell size increases and maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase.
    • This initial period is the time required for adaptation to a new environment, during which the necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication to proceed
  2. Log phase or exponential phase (Marked as B)
    • In this phase, cells start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially or by geometric progression with time.
    • Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. 
  3. Stationary phase (Marked as C)
    • Cell division stops due to depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products.
    • It is a state of equilibrium, where the number of new cells forms equals the number of cells that die.
    • Sporulation occurs during this phase. 
    • Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins and antibiotics.
    • Cells are gram variable and show irregular staining due to the presence of intracellular storage granules.
  4. Phase of decline (Marked as D)
    • In this phase, the population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation, and action of autolytic enzymes.
    • Involution forms are common.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old multiparous woman with polyhydramnios delivered a baby. Immediately after delivery, the patient went into shock and there was uterine inversion with the placenta in situ. What is the correct sequence of events in the management of this patient?

1. Secure 2 large-bore IV cannula
2. Start uterotonic drugs
3. Start tocolytics and reposition the uterus with the placenta in situ
4. Haultain incision if constriction ring is present
questions.solution:
The correct order of management in uterine inversion in this scenario is 1→3→2→4

The following steps are done in uterine inversion.

  • Discontinue uterotonics
  • Administration of IV crystalloids through large-bore IV cannulas to prevent/treat neurogenic and hemorrhagic shock. This is followed by blood transfusion to replace losses.
  • Repositioning is tried after confirming that the inverted uterus is not firmly retracted or contracted. If the placenta is attached to the uterus, it is done with the placenta in situ. The part of the uterus that inverts first is repositioned last.
  • Administer tocolytics such as terbutaline, magnesium sulfate, and nitroglycerin can be used to relax the uterus for repositioning if the initial attempt has failed. An inhalational anesthetic agent can be used if relaxation is not sufficient with tocolytics. Once the uterus is relaxed, repositioning is re-attempted.
  • Oxytocin infusion is started and tocolytics are stopped after repositioning. Await spontaneous expulsion of the placenta.
  • The position of the uterus is maintained while applying bimanual compression. A Bakri balloon can also be used.
  • If repositioning fails, laparotomy is indicated.
  • Surgical intervention is needed if repositioning fails or can't be done. This includes Huntington's method and Haultain's surgery.

Manual repositioning of the uterus is tried first in a case of uterine inversion. Haultain's surgery is performed if uterine repositioning is not successful with manual repositioning of the uterus.

Uterine inversion is most commonly caused due to mismanagement of the 3rd stage of labour where the uterus is turned inside out partially or completely. Shock appears immediately after delivery and is both neurogenic and hemorrhagic. After repositioning, the position of the uterus is maintained by applying bimanual compression or using a Bakri balloon as shown in the image below.

Uterine inversion is a rare cause of postpartum collapse which is acute in onset and occurs immediately after delivery. Below is an image depicting uterine inversion in a patient with the tip of the uterine fundus highlighted.

The most common cause is mismanaged 3rd stage of labor (Delivering a yet to be separated placenta or premature cord traction). Clinically, the patient goes into shock immediately after delivery and the degree of shock is out of proportion to the amount of bleeding. Shock is both neurogenic and hemorrhagic. On examination, the fundus of the uterus cannot be felt.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient is to undergo mastoid surgery. Which of the following instruments will not be required during this surgery?
questions.solution:
Lichwitz trocar and cannula (image 4) is not used in mastoid surgery. It is used for a proof puncture/antral lavage, where maxillary sinus is irrigated via puncturing of its medial wall.

Other options:

Option A: Lempert’s endaural speculum is used to spread open the meatus when giving a local injection or making an endaural incision. 

 

Option B: Lempert’s endaural retractor is used for endaural approach to ear surgery. It has two lateral blades that retract the flaps and a third central blade with holes. The central blade retracts the temporalis muscle and can be fixed to the body of the retractor by its holes.

 

Option C: Lempert’s curette (scoop) is used for the removal of bony septa and granulations in mastoid surgery.

questions.text: A patient with portal hypertension is planned to undergo a distal splenorenal shunt surgery. Which of the following is true regarding this procedure?

choices.text: It has lower chances of hepatic encephalopathy
It is also known as the Linton shunt

questions.solution:
The distal splenorenal shunt (also known as Warren’s shunt) is a selective shunt used in the treatment of portal hypertension. Since it is a selective shunt the risk of hepatic encephalopathy is lower in this shunt.

The distal splenorenal or Warren shunt involves dividing gastroesophageal collaterals, enabling venous drainage from the stomach and lower esophagus through short gastrosplenic veins into the spleen. Splenectomy is not performed in this procedure. This shunt is advantageous for its lower incidence of hepatic encephalopathy and decompensation, and it does not impede subsequent liver transplantation.

Surgical shunts for portal hypertension are recommended for patients with MELD (model for end stage liver disease) scores below 15, those ineligible for liver transplantation, or those with limited access to transjugular intravenous porto systemic shunt (TIPS) therapy and follow-up. 

Shunts for portal hypertension:

  • Non-selective shunt- bowel and splenic blood is shunted. Better control of ascites seen, but risk of hepatic encephalopathy is higher.
    - Linton shunt (proximal lienorenal shunt with splenectomy)
    - Eck fistula (portocaval shunt)
    - Mitra shunt (splenorenal shunt)
    - Mesocaval shunt
  • Selective shunt- only splenic blood is shunted. Risk of hepatic encephalopathy is lower, but poorer control of ascites is seen.
    - Warren shunt (distal splenorenal shunt)
    - Inokuchi shunt (left gastric vein to inferior vena cava)

Other options:

Options A and D: The proximal lienorenal shunt involves splenectomy as a part of the procedure. It is called the Linton’s shunt.

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text:
Match the RNA polymerases with the products synthesized by them.
RNA polymerases RNA synthesized
1. RNAP1 a. tRNA
2. RNAP2 b. rRNA
3. RNAP3 c. mRNA
questions.solution:
The correct match of RNA polymerases with their products is 1-b, 2-c, 3-a.

RNA polymerases

Major Products

RNA polymerase I

rRNA

RNA polymerase II

mRNA, miRNA, snRNA, lncRNA

RNA polymerase III

tRNA, 5srRNA


rRNAs (ribosomal RNA) are involved in protein synthesis. They facilitate the interaction of mRNA, tRNA, and amino acids with each other for the translation process. 

mRNA (messenger RNA) is a protein-coding RNA that is directly involved in protein synthesis.

miRNA (micro RNA) is derived from large primary transcripts through specific nucleolytic processing. It modulates gene expression by altering mRNA function. They bind to matching pieces of mRNA, turn it into a double strand and arrest the translation. 

tRNA (transfer RNA) helps to transport amino acids from the cell cytoplasm to the ribosome where protein synthesis occurs. Since they are soluble in nature, they are also known as soluble RNA (sRNA).

Related Pearl: RNA polymerase in Humans and Their Major Products

Types

rRNA

mRNA, miRNA, snRNA, lncRNA

tRNA, 5srRNA

mRNA

Transfer RNAs (tRNA)

Small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs)

Micro and silencing RNAs (miRNAs and siRNAs)

questions.text:
A 3-year-old female child is brought to the pediatrician with a diagnosis of Rett’s syndrome. Which of the following clinical features are observed in this condition?

1. Stereotypic hand movements
2. Abnormal breathing and hyperventilation
3. Reduced head circumference at birth
4. Association with seizures
5. No loss of spoken language
questions.solution:
The clinical features observed in Retts syndrome include stereotypic hand movements, abnormal respiration with periods of hyperventilation, and association with seizures (statements 1, 2, 4). The affected children experience loss of spoken language (statement 5) and the head circumference is normal at birth (statement 3).

Retts syndrome is an X linked dominant disorder which occurs predominantly in females. At about 1 year of age, the child shows deterioration in communications skills, motor behavior, and social functioning. Symptoms include ataxia, facial grimacing, teeth-grinding, and loss of speech. 

Abnormal respiration with periods of hyperventilation are characteristic while the child is awake. Stereotypical hand movements, including hand-wringing, biting or licking the fingers, and poor muscle coordination are also common.

Microcephaly develops as age progresses. Head circumference is normal at birth, but between the age of 6 months to 1 year, growth begins to decelerate. Seizures are an associated feature in a large number of cases.

Supportive treatment is given. Physiotherapy is beneficial for muscular dysfunction. Anticonvulsants may be required to control seizures.

Trofinetide is a synthetic analogue of the amino‐terminal tripeptide of insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1). Trofinetide has been shown to inhibit the production of inflammatory cytokines, inhibit overactivation of microglia and astrocytes, and increase the amount of available IGF-1 that can bind to IGF-1 receptors.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of severe pain in her buttocks because of the inflammation of the muscle marked in the image below. Which of the following nerves is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the image is the piriformis. When piriformis muscle gets inflamed, there is compression of the sciatic nerve which leads to piriformis syndrome characterised by pain along distribution of the sciatic nerve. 

Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle. This can occur due to inflammation of the piriformis muscle. The patient will present with pain along the distribution of the sciatic nerve which is also known as sciatica. It is triggered by sitting for a long time or running, climbing stairs, or applying firm pressure directly over the piriformis muscle which puts pressure over the underlying the sciatic nerve and causes pain along the distibution of the nerve thereof.

Early signs include pain, tingling, or numbness in the buttocks. Later it may lead to severe pain extending down the length of the sciatic nerve.

questions.text: While measuring the blood pressure of an 80-year-old man, it was found that the pulse pressure was wide. Assuming he has no other co-morbidities, and that it is due to age-related changes, what is the physiology behind this widened pulse pressure?
questions.solution:
Pulse pressure increases with age due to decreased arterial wall compliance. 

Diastolic blood pressure falls after 60 years of age due to increased arterial stiffness and decreased compliance, often associated with arteriosclerosis. As the left ventricle contracts against stiffer, less compliant arteries, systolic blood pressure also increases. 

As a result of these two changes, pulse pressure increases (↑PP = ↑SBP - ↓DBP) 

The factors that affect the pulse pressure:

  • the stroke volume output of the heart 
  • the compliance or total distensibility of the arterial walls
  • the character of ejection from the heart during systole (less important)

Pulse pressure = Stroke volume/ arterial compliance

Widened pulse pressure (> 40 mm Hg) occurs with several diseases such as:

  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Aortic sclerosis
  • Severe iron deficiency anemia 
  • Arteriosclerosis 
  • Hyperthyroidism 

In the majority of these cases, systolic pressures increase while diastolic pressures remain near normal.

Related Pearl: Blood Pressure and its determinants

Type of Blood Pressure

Determinant

Systolic BP (SBP)

Stroke volume (directly proportional)

Compliance of aorta (inversely proportional)

Diastolic BP (DBP)

Elastic recoil of aorta/major vessels (directly proportional)

Pulse pressure (PP)

Ratio of stroke volume to compliance of the arterial tree

Mean blood pressure (MAP)

Cardiac output

Total peripheral resistance

questions.text: Which of the following statements about insulin glargine is false?

choices.text: It cannot be mixed with short acting insulins
It should be administered at the same time each day
It can be safely administered via the IV route as well

questions.solution:
Insulin glargine should be administered only via the subcutaneous route. 

It is a long-acting insulin with ~24 hours duration of action. Hence, it requires a once-daily dosing(option D) and can be administered at any time of the day. However, the catch is that it should be administered at the same designated time each day(option B) to serve as a part of an effective basal bolus regime. 

Insulin glargine forms a cloudy white precipitate when mixed with short-acting insulins(option A). Due to the acidic pH (4.0) of insulin glargine, it cannot be mixed with short-acting insulin preparations that are formulated at a neutral pH as it aggregates at a neutral pH into a cloudy white precipitate. This reduces the effectiveness of the insulin dose.

Related Pearl: Insulin Classification According to Duration of Action

Rapid acting (3-4 hours)

  • Glargine
  • Degludec (24-42 hours)

questions.text:
Assertion: PTH acts on osteoblasts to activate bone resorption.

Reason: PTH induces the production of RANKL ligand by osteoblasts.

PTH- Parathormone

RANKL ligand- Receptor activator of nuclear factor-ќβ ligand

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are correct
Both assertion and reason are wrong

questions.solution:
Both assertion and reason are correct.

Parathormone (PTH) promotes bone resorption, indirectly through its effect on osteoblasts by regulating the production of RANK- ligand. 

Osteoclasts carry out bone resorption under the influence of stromal cells (including osteoblasts) and both local and systemic activators. 

Proliferation of osteoclastic progenitor cells requires the presence of a RANKL ligand (receptor activator of nuclear factor-ќβ) produced by the stromal osteoblasts after stimulation by PTH, glucocorticoids or pro-inflammatory cytokines. RANKL binds with a RANK receptor on the osteoclast precursor in the presence of a macrophage colony-stimulating factor (M-CSF) before full maturation and osteoclastic resorption can begin.

Note: Denosumab is a monoclonal RANKL antibody, which leads to marked suppression of bone resorption and has been found to be a useful therapeutic agent for conditions like osteoporosis

questions.text:
Match the following types of psoriasis with the areas they commonly involve.
i. Discoid psoriasis a. Flexural surfaces
ii. Inverse psoriasis b. Extensor surfaces
iii. Guttate psoriasis c. Para-nasal areas
iv. Seborrheic psoriasis d. Trunk
questions.solution:
The correctly matched set is i-b, ii-a, iii-d, iv-c. 

i. Discoid psoriasis b. Extensor surfaces
ii. Inverse psoriasis a. Flexural surfaces
iii. Guttate psoriasis d. Trunk 
iv. Seborrheic psoriasis c. Para nasal areas

Psoriasis is characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silver scales. It generally affects the extensor surfaces. The peak occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years.

Plaque psoriasis or discoid psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis. It presents with pruritis and a papulosquamous rash. Lesions can be described as red, scaly, and a well-defined demarcation from the normal skin. The scales often appear white and silvery. The lesions may be encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring. They are seen in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

An image of plaque psoriasis is shown below:

 

Inverse psoriasis or flexural psoriasis or intertriginous psoriasis refers to psoriasis of the flexural areas such as the inguinal creases, axillae, inframammary, and other body folds. Unlike characteristic lesions of psoriasis, these plaques are thin, with minimal or no scaling. The surface is glazed with fissuring.

Inverse psoriasis may manifest as new lesions occurring on the body or the Koebner phenomenon on top of existing intertriginous dermatoses, or it may be present along with classical plaque psoriasis. It typically involves the diaper area in infants, referred to as napkin psoriasis. It may also affect older, obese patients.

Guttate psoriasis usually has a sudden onset of small lesions on the trunk and proximal limbs, in children. It usually occurs weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis. It is shown in the image below.

Seborrhoeic psoriasis or sebopsoriasis presents as thin, demarcated erythema with scales. It is typically seen in areas that are involved in seborrhoeic dermatitis - paranasal areas, external ears, medial eyebrows, hairline, presternal, and interscapular chest wall.

 

Other types of psoriasis include:

  • Pustular psoriasis - the appearance of macroscopic pustules within lesions.
  • Erythrodermic psoriasis - an uncommon type where almost the entire body is affected, and the patient is systemically ill. 
  • Unstable psoriasis or active psoriasis or eruptive inflammatory psoriasis - characterised by actively enlarging erythematous plaques, with the development of new smaller plaques

Psoriasis may affect specific sites. These include:

  • Scalp psoriasis
  • Follicular psoriasis
  • Seborrhoeic psoriasis or sebopsoriasis
  • Flexural psoriasis or inverse psoriasis
  • Genital psoriasis
  • Non‐pustular palmoplantar psoriasis
  • Nail psoriasis
  • Ocular psoriasis
  • Mucosal psoriasis

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

Related Pearl: Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

I. In Mild Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • Coal tar
  • Dithranol
  • Potent topical steroid
  • Vitamin D analogue

Second line

  • Local NB-UVB or PUVA
  • Excimer laser

II. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • NB-UVB or PUVA

Second line

  • Acitretin
  • Apremilast
  • Ciclosporin
  • Fumaric acid esters (where available)
  • Methotrexate

Third line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Secukinumab
  • Ustekinumab

III. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis with Psoriatic Arthritis

First line

  • Apremilast
  • Methotrexate

Second line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Ustekinumab

Third line

  • Combination therapy

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient approached a radiologist for a screening breast examination during breast cancer awareness month. Which of the following best represents the difference in the  X-ray tube used in this procedure from that of a conventional X-ray machine?

choices.text: Beryllium exit window and molybdenum filter
Glass exit window and aluminium filter
Beryllium exit window and aluminium filter
Glass exit window and molybdenum filter

questions.solution:
The screening procedure for breast cancer is mammography. The x-ray tube used in mammography differs from that of a conventional x-ray machine in that it has a beryllium exit window and molybdenum filter.

Differences between mammography and conventional radiography:

  • Mammography involves the use of low-energy and high-amperage waves.
  • The target anode is made of a tungsten disc in conventional x-ray tubes and molybdenum in mammography x-ray tubes.
  • Most mammography tubes use beryllium exit windows between the evacuated tube and the atmosphere.
  • The conventional X-ray tube has an aluminum filter, but in mammography, a molybdenum filter is used.

Some indications for mammography:

  • Evaluation of breast signs and symptoms like masses, skin changes, deformities, nipple retraction, discharge, and eczema
  • Breast cancer screening
  • Follow-up for patients treated for breast cancer
  • Localization of lesions not visible on ultrasound

The two standard mammographic projections are the mediolateral oblique view and the craniocaudal view.

Note: Breast cancer awareness month is an annual international health campaign organized by major breast cancer charities every year in the month of October.

Related Pearl: Difference between Normal Radiography and Mammography

  Radiography Mammography
Type of X rays Bremsstrahlung reaction Characteristic radiation
Target Tungsten Molybdenum
Exit Window Glass Beryllium
Filter Aluminum Molybdenum

questions.text: A patient presents with ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis and enophthalmos. On examination, the ciliospinal reflex is found to be absent. The treatment of choice for correction of ptosis in the above patient would be:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Horner’s syndrome. Fasanella servat is the treatment of choice for mild ptosis caused by Horner’s syndrome.

Fasanella servat operation is done for cases of mild ptosis (1.5-2 mm) with retained levator palpabrae superioris muscle function as seen in Horner’s syndrome.

Ptosis in Horner's syndrome is due to the loss of sympathetic supply to the muller's muscle of the lid and not due to levator muscle palsy. Fasanella servat operation is not done in patients with severe ptosis and poor levator function.

Option A: Levator resection is performed for moderate and severe grades of ptosis but with retained levator function. This operation is contraindicated in patients with poor levator function.

Option B: Frontalis sling also known as brow suspension is done in patients with severe ptosis with poor or absent levator muscle function. Here, the lid is anchored to the frontalis muscle via a sling. 

Surgical treatment of various types of ptosis:

Surgery 

Requisite 

Levator

action 

 Amount of ptosis that can be treated  Indications 

Fasanella 

Servat

Levator 

Resection(option A)-

Anterior

approach

Levator 

resection – Conjunctival approach 

 Moderate  Any  Moderate resection in ptosis 

Levator r

esection with aponeurotic reinsertion 

 Moderate  Any  Acquired ptosis 

Frontalis suspension(option B)-

Fascia lata 

 Poor  > 2 mm 

Congenital ptosis-

Marcus Gunn ptosis 

Option D: Faden surgery is done for correction of squint. The procedure involves suturing of muscle to sclera 12-18mm posterior to its original insertion.

questions.text: What is the utility of the test as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image is the Hess chart and is used to assess ocular motility diagnose and monitor patients with incomitant strabismus by assessing a binocular single vision field. In its interpretation, a smaller chart indicates the eye with the paretic muscle and a larger chart indicates the eye with an overacting muscle.

Other options : 

Option A : Test to detect abnormal retinal correspondance (ARC) are

  • Worth's four-dot test
  • Prism bar
  • Red filter
  • After image test
  • Bagolini striated glass tests
  • Synaptophore tests

Option B : Visual acuity is most commonly measured using snellen chart (which is the measure of form sense)

Option D : Measurement of heterophoria (latent squint) is done either by objective test which are prism and cover test or subjective test which are maddox rod test, maddox wing test and double prism test.

questions.text: The imaging modality shown below is a combination of which of the following :

choices.text: B-mode imaging and pulsed Doppler acquisition
A-mode imaging and power Doppler acquisition

questions.solution:
The image in the question depicts a duplex ultrasonography of the kidney. Duplex scans involve a combination of B-mode imaging and pulsed Doppler data acquisition.

A duplex scanner generates a real-time image while operating in the imaging mode. The positioning of the Doppler gate over the target vessel is determined by its dimensions (length and breadth) being suitable for assessing blood velocity, as well as its orientation (angle relative to the interrogating US beam) being indicative of the Doppler angle. The scanner electronics, when in Doppler mode, ascertain the optimal timing for data extraction exclusively from within the gate specified by the user.

Diverse configurations of duplex scanning instrumentation are available. Electronic array transducers frequently alternate between a collection of transducers employed to generate a B-mode image and one or more transducers responsible for acquiring Doppler information.

Due to the knowledge of the transducer frequency and the velocity of sound, the duplex system enables the estimation of blood velocity directly from the Doppler shift frequency. In contrast, the estimation of the Doppler angle is feasible using the B-mode image and input into the scanner computer for computation. Flow estimation (in units of cm3/s) is achieved by multiplying the velocity by the cross-sectional area of the vessel (cm2) once the velocity is known.
