questions.text:
In a city of 50,000 people, there are 5000 sexually active citizens. During a five year period, 25 individuals are newly diagnosed with HIV. What is the incidence rate?

HIV: Human immunodeficiency Virus
questions.solution:
The incidence rate will be 1 per 1000 people-year. 

Incidence rate = New cases in the given time frame/ (Population at risk * time frame)

Here, the new cases in the given time frame are 25; the population at risk is 5000; the time frame is 5 years.

So, 25 / (5000 * 5) = 25 / 25000 = 1 case / 1000 people-year 

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text:
All of the following conditions are contraindications for the respective contraceptives, except:

IUCD : Intrauterine contraceptive device
OCP : Oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
The preferred contraceptive pill in a lactating woman is the progesterone-only pill and it is ideally started at 3 months in a fully breastfeeding woman.

Regular breastfeeding is effective in preventing pregnancy with a failure rate of 0.5%-1.5%.  This occurs due to prolactin preventing LH surge and ovulation. It depends on the frequency of the feed rather than the duration of the feed. Hence when the woman is fully breastfeeding, a contraceptive method should be used from the 3rd postpartum month and with partial or no breastfeeding, it should be used from the 3rd postpartum week. Progesterone - only pill does not suppress lactation and hence it is the preferred contraceptive in lactating women.

Other options:

Option A: Copper IUCD is contraindicated in invasive diseases of the uterus such as trophoblastic disease as it would increase the risk for uterine perforation.

Option B: Severe migraine raises the risk of stroke in patients on OCP and therefore OCP are contraindicated.

Option C: Ormeloxifen is a non-steroidal contraceptive that prolongs the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle. It is contraindicated in polycystic disease of the ovary.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the correct order from proximal to distal:

1. Alveolar duct

2. Lobar bronchi

3. Terminal bronchiole

4. Alveolar sac

5. Segmental bronchi

6. Respiratory bronchiole
questions.solution:
The following is a sequence of the intrapulmonary anatomy from proximal to distal: Trachea → Main Bronchi → Lobar Bronchi → Segmental Bronchi → Terminal Bronchiole → Respiratory Bronchiole → Alveolar Duct → Alveolar Sac → Alveoli

According to Weibel’s model, the respiratory tract is divided into 23 generations, consisting of conducting (upper 16 generations) and respiratory zones (lower 7 generations). It begins at the trachea (designated as zero) and ends with alveoli (last generation).

The epithelial layer transitions from a pseudostratified columnar layer in the upper airways (trachea, bronchi) with submucosal secretory glands to a cuboidal epithelium (bronchioles), and finally, to a flat squamous epithelium in the alveoli, facilitating efficient gas exchange in the respiratory zone. 

As we progress downward, the following changes occur in the structure of the airways: 

  • The number of mucus-secreting cells/secretory glands decreases.
  • The amount of cartilage in the airway wall decreases.  
  • The quantity of smooth muscles increases from trachea to terminal bronchioles but decreases from respiratory bronchioles to alveoli.
  • The amount of dead space decreases.
  • The number of cilia decreases such that they are absent in alveoli.
  • The surface area and volume progressively increase, facilitating easy gas exchange.
  • The number of flat squamous cells (Type 1 pneumocytes) increases.

The diagram given below further reiterates the above concept

questions.text:
Renal biopsy of a patient presenting with proteinuria is shown below. Which of the following is most likely associated with the condition?

HIV - Human Immunodeficiency Virus

choices.text: HIV infection in a heroin addict

questions.solution:
The given histopathological slide shows glomerular deposits which appear as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid as well as capillary lumens which are obliterated points towards the diagnosis of amyloidosis in which extracellular fibrillar protein is seen.

Given below is another histopathological image further depicting the above mentioned findings in a renal biopsy of a patient with amyloidosis. 

Amyloidosis refers to extracellular deposits of fibrillar proteins. The kidney is the most common organ involved in amyloidosis. Abnormal fibrils are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind a wide variety of proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, including heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, and plasma proteins, notably serum amyloid P component (SAP). Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

It could be classified as systemic, localized, and hereditary amyloidosis. Microscopically, all types of amyloid deposits are made up of continuous, nonbranching fibrils. A characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation is visualized on X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy.

The stain used for amyloid deposits is congo red staining, which imparts pink to red color to the amyloid under ordinary light and apple-green birefringence under polarised microscopy.

The image shows a congo-red stained biopsy specimen with the following:

(A) focal positive staining (orange-red) of amorphous extracellular material

(B) apple-green birefringence under polarized light 

The next best step is to determine the type of precursor protein by immunohistochemistry, immunoelectron microscopy, or extraction and biochemical analysis using mass spectrometry.

Other options:

Option A: History of streptococcal pharyngitis would be seen in patients with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). It typically develops around 1 to 2 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis, or 3 to 6 weeks after streptococcal pyoderma. Renal biopsy of PSGN on light microscopy would show enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with diffuse mesangial and endothelial proliferation and leukocyte infiltration.

Below is the image showing light microscopy findings of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.


Option B: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is commonly associated with heroin use and HIV infection.  It is characterized by degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells and effacement of foot processes. Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis are seen due to the entrapment of plasma proteins and increased extracellular matrix deposition. The histopathology slide will appear as follows: 


Option C: Mutation in the collagen gene is seen in Alport syndrome. It is a hereditary nephritis caused by mutations in the genes coding for type IV collagen. Glomeruli may have irregular thickening of the glomerular basement membrane. Electron microscopy shows a characteristic basket-weaving appearance of lamina densa as shown below.

questions.text: A child who is diagnosed to have Grade II vesico-ureteric reflux with no bladder and bowel dysfunction is ready to be discharged. What is the most appropriate management for this child ?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for grade II VUR is voiding behavior modification.

The therapeutic aim in the management of vesico-ureteric reflux is to prevent UTI from the reflux, thereby preventing its progressing into pyelonephritis and renal damage. It is based on the fact that VUR often resolves over time and if UTIs can be prevented, morbidities associated with it can also be prevented without any surgery.

Voiding behavior modification includes:

  • timed voiding during the day,
  • ensuring regular fecal elimination,
  • increased fluid intake,
  • assessing satisfactory bladder emptying periodically, and
  • prompt assessment and treatment of urinary tract infections (UTIs), particularly febrile UTIs.

Antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated for Grades III & IV and surgery is usually reserved for those with recurrent & refractory UTIs.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to amplify the gastrocolic reflex in a newborn baby, leading to frequent defecation after meals?

choices.text: Cholecystokinin response to fat in breast milk
Gastrin release after distention from the stomach
Lactose induced fermentation and gas production
Triggering of rectal stretch receptors by milk caesin

questions.solution:
The gastrocolic reflex is amplified by the action of gastrin which is released on distension of the stomach after feeds.

GIT reflexes which are mediated by prevertebral sympathetic ganglia include:

  • Gastrocolic reflex —>Distension of the stomach and digestive byproducts in the small intestine activate afferents to the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia. This results in stimulation of the colon and an urge to defecate. 
  • Enterogastric reflex → signals from the colon and small intestine inhibit stomach motility and secretion
  • Colonoileal reflex → signals from the colon to inhibit the emptying of ileal contents into the colon

GIT reflexes which are mediated by the brain stem and spinal cord include:

  • Pain reflexes that cause inhibition of the whole gastrointestinal tract
  • Long-distance vagal reflexes regulating gastric motor and secretory activity
  • Defecation reflex → Distension of the rectum and colon results in powerful contractions of the rectum, colon, and abdominal wall which are required for defecation.

Other options:

Option A and C: While cholecystokinin (CCK) and lactose play roles in digestion, they are not directly involved in initiating the reflex. CCK is more involved in gallbladder and pancreatic enzyme secretion, not directly related to colonic motility. Lactose fermentation may increase colonic motility in some people, but it's not the main driver of the immediate post-feeding reflex in infants.

Option D: While stretch receptors play a role in defecation, they are primarily located in the sigmoid colon and rectum, not directly activated by stomach distension and is part of the colonoileal reflex.

questions.text: A patient presents with a low-grade fever and a suppurative granulomatous skin lesion, with recent travel history to North America. Chest X-ray reveals right lung consolidation with hilar lymphadenopathy. Culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar shows the following finding. What is the correct description of the slide given below?

choices.text: Yeast cells with broad-based budding in culture at 25°C
Yeast cells with broad-based budding in culture at 37°C
Yeast cells with narrow-based budding in culture at 25°C
Yeast cells with narrow-based budding in culture at 37°C

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of blastomycosis caused by Blastomycosis dermatitidis. It appears as yeast cells with broad-based budding in culture at 37°C.

The slide in the image above shows thick-walled round yeast cells with single broad-based budding depicting the figure of 8 appearance, which is suggestive of B. dermatitidis. It causes North American blastomycosis.

Blastomycosis is an infection most commonly seen in North America. It is contracted through the inhalation of contaminated soil. Primary infection usually presents as pneumonia.  Chest X-ray reveals consolidation. Disseminated disease may lead to multiple abscesses. Cutaneous lesions present as papules and nodules which progress into large ulcerative lesions.

Blastomyces is a dimorphic fungi. Dimorphic fungi exist in the yeast form in body tissues and cultures maintained at 37°C, and in the filamentous form in cultures at room temperature (25°C).

Some common examples of dimorphic fungi:

  • Blastomyces dermatitidis
  • Coccidioides immitis
  • Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
  • Penicilliosis marneffei
  • Sporothrix schenckii
  • Histoplasma capsulatum

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following structures has an embryological origin that is different from the rest?
questions.solution:
Of the listed options, the collecting tubule is derived from the ureteric bud while the other structures are derived from the metanephric blastema.

The renal system develops from three sources:

  • Metanephric blastema gives rise to the excretory system of the kidney. It forms the Bowman's capsule, the proximal convoluted tubule, the loop of Henle, and the distal convoluted tubule.
  • The ureteric bud, an outgrowth of the mesonephric duct, gives rise to the kidney's collecting system. It forms the collecting ducts, minor and major calyces, renal pelvis, and ureter.
  • Angiogenic mesenchyme, which migrates into the metanephric blastema, gives rise to the glomeruli and the vasa recta.

Given below is a diagram summarizing the development of the urogenital system

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Mesonephric (Wolffian) duct and Paramesonephric (Mullerian) duct

Structures arising from mesonephric/Wolffian duct

Ureteric bud and its derivatives Ureteric bud and its derivatives
Trigone of bladder Trigone of bladder
The proximal part of the prostatic urethra The posterior wall of the urethra
Spermatic pathway Gartner's duct
Appendix of epididymis  

Structures arising from the paramesonephric/Mullerian duct

Males Females
Appendix of testis Fallopian tube
Prostatic utricle Uterus

questions.text: A first-year medical student during his practical exam was given with 1st rib and asked to name the structures related to it. The neck of the 1st rib is related to all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The internal thoracic artery is not related to the neck of the first rib.

The structures related to neck of the first rib (medial to lateral):

  • Sympathetic trunk
  • Vein ( posterior intercostal)
  • Artery (superior intercostal)
  • Nerve (T1 nerve)

These structures are also related to the apex of lung anteriorly.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman came with complaints of a frontal headache, nasal congestion and pain near the gums. A diagnosis of allergic fungal sinusitis was made. Which of the following are included in the major criteria for diagnosis of this condition ?



1. Nasal polyposis

2. Positive fungal culture

3. Positive fungal stain

4. Serum eosinophilia

5. Double density sign on CT scan
questions.solution:
The major criteria that are used for the positive diagnosis of allergic fungal sinusitis are nasal polyposis, positive fungal stain and characteristic CT findings like double density sign.

Bent and Kuhn’s diagnostic criteria are used as diagnostic criteria for Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (AFRS). It includes :

Major Criteria Minor criteria
1. Type I hypersensitivity 
2. Nasal polyposis
3. Characteristic CT findings
4. Eosinophilic mucin without invasion
5. Positive fungal stain		 1. Asthma
2. Unilateral disease
3. Bone erosion
4. Fungal cultures
5. Charcot-Leyden crystals
6. Serum eosinophilia

All the major criterias must be met by the patient while the minor criteria serve to support the diagnosis and describe individual patients.

Characteristic CT findings in AFRS include heterogeneous signal intensities within the paranasal sinuses filled with allergic mucin (double density sign or rail track sign), expansion of the paranasal sinuses/nasal cavity, unilateral or asymmetric disease load, and bony erosion.

Treatment of allergic fungal sinusitis includes avoidance of allergen exposure, antihistamines, corticosteroid nasal sprays, aggressive surgical intervention for mucin removal which improves sinus drainage, post-surgery oral corticosteroids, and immunotherapy against fungal and non-fungal allergens.

questions.text: The condition seen in image starts to occur at intake levels of ________ of the offending agent.
questions.solution:
The image shows mottling of teeth seen in Fluorosis. It starts to occur at intake levels of 1.5 mg/L of fluoride. 

Fluorosis seen with corresponding levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: 1.5 mg/L
  • Skeletal fluorosis: 3-6 mg/L
  • Crippling fluorosis: >10 mg/L

questions.text: What is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image above represents the Bragg-peak effect of a proton.

The Bragg peak effect is pronounced for protons. Proton therapy, therefore, allows to target tumors inside the body, precisely localize the radiation dosage and spare the patient’s healthy cells, offering a much less invasive alternative to treat cancer.

Protons and the Bragg peak effect:

The Bragg curve plots the energy loss of ionizing radiation during its travel through matter.

The proton is a heavy and charged particle that gradually loses its speed as it interacts with human tissue. The proton is very fast when it enters the patient’s body and deposits only a small dose on its way. The absorbed dose increases very gradually with greater depth and lower speed, suddenly rising to a peak when the proton is ultimately stopped. This is known as the Bragg peak. 

Other options:

Option A: The BOLD (blood oxygen level dependent) effect forms the basis for functional MRI (fMRI).

Option B: The Bohr effect is the loss of affinity for O2 with decreasing pH. It occurs in the microcirculation as oxygen is consumed and CO2 (carbonic acid) is released by tissues.

Option D: The Haldane effect is the phenomenon whereby increasing arterial PO2 reduces the ability of the blood to store CO2 (as Hb-bound, carbamino Hb; or as HCO3-), thereby increasing the CO2 partial pressure.

questions.text: An elderly patient with atrial fibrillation presents with hematochezia and abdominal pain. Ischemia of Griffith's point is suspected. Which of the following areas is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
The splenic flexure of the colon is also known as Griffith's point and is a watershed area between the superior and inferior mesenteric arteries. 

Ischemic colitis occurs due to interruption or decrease in colonic blood flow. It may occur with many different conditions, including embolism from cardiac disease (eg. in patients with atrial fibrillation like in this case), low-flow states such as congestive heart failure, sepsis, and vasopressor use. Major vascular surgery (both open and endovascular repair), especially involving the abdominal aorta, is also a risk factor for developing ischemic colitis, due to possible compromise of the inferior mesenteric artery.

Although any area of the colon may be affected, the watershed areas of the splenic flexure (Griffith’s point) and the rectosigmoid junction (Sudeck’s point) are the most prone to ischemia because of the often incomplete anastomoses of the marginal artery which connect the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) in these locations. 

Given below is a diagram showing the arterial blood supply to the large intestine along with the potential sites of ischemia.

Other option(s):

Option C: The rectosigmoid region is called Sudeck's point. This region receives its blood supply from the superior hemorrhoidal artery and distal sigmoid branches, both terminal branches of the IMA and prone to atherosclerotic changes.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with cheilosis, magenta coloured tongue and corneal vascularization. Which test can be used for diagnosis of this vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Cheilosis, magenta coloured tongue and corneal vascularisation is seen in vitamin B2 or riboflavin deficiency. The diagnosis is established by measuring RBC glutathione reductase activity.

Riboflavin or Vitamin B2 is an important antioxidant in the body. It provides reactive moieties of the coenzymes Flavin Mono Nucleotide (FMN) and Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide (FAD). The main dietary sources of riboflavin are milk and dairy products. Because of yellow colour of riboflavin it is also used as food additives.

Riboflavin deficiency shows features such as:

  • Cheilosis
  • Magenta coloured tongue
  • Seborrheic dermatitis
  • Corneal vascularisation
  • Anemia

Other options :

Option A: Niacin deficiency is diagnosed by measuring urinary levels of 2-methyl nicotinamide and 2-pyridone.

Option C: Urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid differentiates between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency.

Option D: Thiamine (B1) deficiency can be diagnosed by measuring transketolase levels.

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Relatively unknown

questions.text: During the vaginal delivery of a woman with gestational diabetes, the anterior shoulder of the baby could not be delivered. All of the following maneuvers can aid the delivery, except:

choices.text: Push the head back and perform a cesarean
Flexion of hip against the abdomen

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of shoulder dystocia in a patient with gestational diabetes. Fundal pressure is never applied in case of shoulder dystocia as it causes further impaction of the shoulder.

Shoulder dystocia, defined as a head-to-body delivery time >60 seconds, occurs when either the anterior or the posterior (rare) fetal shoulder impacts on the maternal symphysis or the sacral promontory respectively. Risk factors for the development of shoulder dystocia include maternal diabetes mellitus, obesity, post-dated pregnancy, excessive weight gain during pregnancy, etc. 

Management of labour in case of shoulder dystocia includes the following.

Gentle downward traction of the fetal head with suprapubic pressure (not fundal).
Mc. Roberts manoeuvre involves the flexing of the legs against the abdomen with concurrent suprapubic pressure (Option B)Below is a diagram depicting the Mc. Roberts manoeuvre.

Woods corkscrew manoeuvre involves the pro­gressive rotation of the posterior shoulder by 180 degrees in a corkscrew fashion to release the impacted anterior shoulder (Option C). Below is a diagram depicting the Woods corkscrew manoeuvre.

Zavanelli manoeuvre: It involves the replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis followed by cesarean delivery (Option A).
Other manoeuvres include Rubin's maneuver (rocking fetal shoulders side to side) Gaskin maneuver (All fours maneuver), Symphysiotomy (cutting the symphyseal carti­lage and ligamentous supports) and cleidotomy (Fracture of the clavicle using an instrument). Below is a diagram depicting the cleiodotomy procedure.

questions.text:
A woman suffers from generalized tonic-clonic seizure a few hours after vaginal delivery. She was induced at 37 weeks gestation via an oxytocin infusion for pre-ecclapmsia with severe features and was given MgSO4 injections. Her vital parameters are presently normal and laboratory results are as follows. What is the most likely cause of this patient's seizure?

Hemoglobin - 7 g/dL 
Platelets- 160,000/mm3 
Sodium- 112 mEq/L 
Potassium- 3.6 mEq/L 
Chloride- 100 mq/L
Magnesium- 5.2 mg/dL (normal therapeutic range: 1.8 - 2.6 mg/dL)
questions.solution:
Prolonged IV administration of oxytocin at high doses in conjunction with large volumes of hypotonic fluid may cause water intoxication associated with severe hyponatremia (sodium 112 mEq/L) which can present as seizures. 

This patient had a generalized tonic clonic seizure after an induction of labor for preeclampsia with severe features. The most common cause of postpartum seizure is eclampsia; however, given this patient's normal blood pressure and therapeutic range of magnesium levels, other causes require evaluation (Options A and B). With a sodium level of 112 mEq/L, this patient's seizure is mostly likely due to severe hyponatremia, a side effect of oxytocin overdose.

Oxytocin has a structure similarity with vasopressin. Oxytocin can bind to V2 receptors on the serosal surface of renal tubular cells resulting in reduced free water clearance. 

Other options:

Option A : Magnesium toxicity can present as muscle weakness which progresses to loss of deep tendon reflexes and, eventually, flaccid paralysis that can cause respiratory compromise. Further complications include those in the cardiovascular system, beginning with hypotension and bradycardia.

Option B : Acute blood loss anemia (hemoglobin 7) from postpartum hemorrhage can cause pituitary infarction (ie, Sheehan syndrome). Sheehan syndrome typically has a delayed presentation of nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue and decreased lactation, not an isolated seizure. 

Option D: Intracerebral hemorrhage from hypertensive crisis (eg, uncontrolled preeclampsia) may present with seizures. However, patients typically have focal neurologic deficits and severely elevated blood pressure (ie, systolic > 210 mmHg or diastolic > 110 mm Hg), which are not seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented with low backache and morning stiffness for the past 6 months with a history of symptomatic improvement with exercise. On examination, he had decreased chest expansion. What will be the earliest X-ray sign in the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis and the earliest X-ray sign is the erosion of the sacroiliac joint.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joint. It is more common in young males and has a strong association with HLAB27.

Clinically, patients present with recurring backache which worsens in the early morning or with inactivity and improves with exercise. Later they develop fatigue, pain, joint swellings, and heel pain.

Extra-articular manifestations include uveitis, aortic incompetence, carditis, and apical lobe fibrosis.

Examination findings include loss of lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, diminished spinal movements, and decreased chest expansion.

X-ray findings:

  • erosion of sacroiliac joints - earliest sign
  • periarticular sclerosis (option B) in later stages 
  • squaring of vertebrae due to flattening of normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body is the earliest vertebral change
  • bamboo spine appearance (option C) due to bridging of adjacent vertebrae
  • wedging of the vertebra (option D) leading to hyperkyphosis

Treatment consists of maintaining posture and preserving mobility. Pain and stiffness can be controlled with anti-inflammatory drugs. In severe cases, TNF inhibitors are used. Surgery can be considered to correct the deformity.

The image below shows the bamboo spine's appearance:

Related Pearl: Joint Involvement in Various Arthritis

 Joint Disorders Joints Commonly Involved

Joints Commonly Spared

 Osteoarthritis

Cervical and lumbosacral spine, PIP, DIP, 1st CMC, hip, knee, 1st MTP, 

 Elbow, Wrist, Ankle, MCP 
Rheumatoid Arthritis Shoulder, Wrist, MCP, PIP, Knee, MTP  DIP 
Ankylosing Spondylitis Sacroiliac joint, intervertebral joints  
Psoriatic Arthritis PIP, DIP Ray distribution* 

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

questions.text: Identify the sensory nerve supply for the given histological specimen of tongue.
questions.solution:
The given histological specimen shows a dome-shaped structure lined by stratified squamous epithelium suggestive of the circumvallate papilla of the tongue which is located at the junction of the anterior 2/3 and posterior 1/3 of the tongue. Sensory and gustatory innervation to the circumvallate papilla is by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Circumvallate papillae are 8-12 in number which is large cylindrical structures. They form a V-shaped row just in front of the sulcus terminalis. Usually, the entire papillae are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. Taste buds are present in the lateral wall of these papillae which surrounds the papillae circumferentially.

Other papillae of the tongue: 

Fungiform papillae are large, rounded, and red in color and are mainly present on the lingual margins and also on the dorsal surface of the tongue. They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. They are supplied by the facial nerve.

Filiform papillae are minute cylindrical or conical projections that are mainly present on the dorsal part of the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. The filiform papillae do not contain taste buds. They are covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. They are supplied by the facial nerve.

Foliate papillae are red, leaf-like mucosal ridges that are present bilaterally in two zones at the sides of the tongue near the sulcus terminalis. They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

A diagrammatic representation of the various papillae of the tongue is given below:

Below is the image showing the various parts of the tongue.

Special sensory

Posterior 1/3rd

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Internal laryngeal nerve (CN X)

questions.text: An older patient with bilateral hearing loss and occasional vertigo is being investigated. Biopsy from the region is given below. The most likely diagnosis is _____.
questions.solution:
The given histology image shows dense pink Antoni A areas predominantly (bottom left) and loose, pale Antoni B areas (top right), as well as hyalinized blood vessels seen in schwannoma.

Schwannomas are benign tumors that exhibit Schwann cell differentiation and often arise directly from peripheral nerves. They are associated with inactivating mutations in the NF2 (Neurofibromatosis 2) gene on chromosome 22.

They appear as well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that are attached loosely to the associated nerve without invading. They cause symptoms by local compression of the involved nerve or adjacent structures.

Their cell of origin is the Schwann cell, thus they show immunoreactivity for the S-100 marker.

Treatment is done using surgical removal.

Other options:

Option A: Leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle tumors, that often arise in the uterus and are the most common neoplasm in women. Histologically, they are composed of fascicles of densely eosinophilic spindle cells that tend to intersect each other at right angles. 

Option B: Rhabdomyomas are the most frequent primary tumors of the heart in children. Microscopically, they are composed of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes with abundant glycogen. But due to routine histological processing, the glycogen content is reduced and looks like thin strands that stretch from the nuclei to the surface membrane, which appears like ‘spider cells’.

Option D: Neurofibromas are also benign nerve sheath tumors and the histological picture shows the presence of bland Schwann cells admixed with stromal cells such as mast cells, perineural cells, and fibroblasts. The stroma of the tumors contains loose collagen arranged in wavy bundles.

questions.text: A second-year medical student, during the ward rounds, asks one of the patients to keep his fingers as shown in the image, to elicit a clinical finding. Which of the following conditions is least likely to cause an abnormal sign pertaining to this clinical finding?
questions.solution:
The medical student, by asking the patient to keep the dorsal surfaces of his fingers opposed, is trying to elicit clubbing. Irritable bowel syndrome is not associated with clubbing.

In a normal person, when the dorsal surfaces of the distal parts of two fingers are opposed, a diamond-shaped gap is created, called Schamroth's window. 

Obliteration in clubbed fingers of the diamond-shaped window normally produced is called the Schamroth's sign.


Clubbing is the growth of the tips of the fingers which occurs due to connective tissue proliferation. It can be idiopathic, hereditary, or acquired.

The underlying mechanism for clubbing is still unclear but different hypotheses include anoxic, toxic, neurogenic, metabolic, and humoral. 

The different grades of clubbing are as follows: 

Grade 1 Increased fluctuation of the nail bed with loss of onychodermal angle
Grade 2 

Increase in antero-posterior and transverse diameter of the nails. Nails becomes smooth and glossy with loss of longitudinal ridges.
Grade 3

Increased pulp tissue
Grade 4

Wrist and ankle swelling due to hypertrophic osteoarthropathy

Causes of clubbing include: 

  1. Cardiac causes
    1. Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    2. Subacute bacterial endocarditis
    3. Cardiac tumors
    4. Eisenmenger's syndrome
  2. Lung and pleural causes
    1. Bronchiectasis
    2. Lung abscess
    3. Bronchogenic carcinoma
    4. Empyema thoracis
    5. Fibrosing alveolitis
    6. Pleural mesothelioma
    7. Pulmonary arteriovenous fistula
    8. Cystic fibrosis
    9. Fibrocaseous tuberculosis
  3. Ulcerative colitis
  4. Biliary cirrhosis
  5. Intestinal causes
    1. Malabsorption
    2. Crohn's disease
    3. Polyposis coli
    4. Coeliac disease
  6. Normal
  7. Genetic

Related Pearl: Nail findings and associated systemic conditions

questions.text: The postmortem examination of an elderly man with chest pain showed a myocardial infarction in the area marked below. Occlusion of which of the following arteries is the cause of myocardial infarction in this patient?
questions.solution:
The area marked in the above image is the anterolateral wall of the left ventricle. This area is suppleid by the anterior interventricular artery which is likely to be occluded in this patient.

The left coronary artery arises from the left aortic sinus (left posterior sinus ) of the ascending aorta. It passes between the pulmonary trunk and the left auricle and then runs in the atrioventricular groove. 

It divides into two branches in the coronary sulcus. They are:

  • The anterior interventricular branch or left anterior descending artery (LAD) - Is the continuation of the left coronary artery. Gives anterior septal branches, anterior ventricular branches, and diagonal artery.
  • Circumflex branch (Options A)- Curves left in the atrioventricular groove and continues around the left cardiac border to reach the posterior part of the groove. It terminates in the crux in most hearts but may continue as a posterior interventricular artery in some individuals.

The left coronary artery supplies most of the left ventricle, a narrow strip of the right ventricle, the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum, and most of the left atrium.

The right coronary artery arises from the anterior aortic sinus. It first passes between the right atrium and the pulmonary trunk. On reaching the atrioventricular groove, it descends down vertically and curves around the right border of the heart to reach the inferior (posterior) part of the groove. The artery ends a little left of the cardiac crux by joining the circumflex branch of the left coronary artery. 

Branches of the right coronary artery are :

  • Right conal artery
  • Branches to the anterior part of the atrium and ventricles.
  • Right marginal artery (acute marginal artery) (Options C & D)
  • Posterior interventricular artery

The right coronary artery supplies most of the right ventricles, a small part of the diaphragmatic aspect of the left ventricle, the posteroinferior third of the interventricular septum, the right atrium and part of the left atrium, sinoatrial node, and atrioventricular node.

Dominance is determined by the vessel which supplies the posterior interventricular artery. If the posterior interventricular artery is derived from the left coronary artery it is called left dominance, if it is derived from the right coronary artery it is called right dominance.

questions.text: To elicit which of the following signs in a pregnant female would you be required to do a visual inspection and not manual palpation?
questions.solution:
A dusky hue of the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall visible at about 8th week of pregnancy is called Chadwick’s sign or Jacquemier’s sign. It is diagnosed on visual inspection and not manual palpation.

The discoloration is due to local vascular congestion.

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following options represents the Australia antigen in the given image of viral structure?
questions.solution:
The Australia antigen, which is another name for hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), is marked as '1' in the given image. This antigen was first isolated from the serum of an Australian person, hence the name Australia antigen.

Under electron microscopy, the serum from hepatitis B patients shows three types of particles:

  • Spherical particle: 22 nm; most abundant; containing only HBsAg
  • Filamentous or tubular particle: 22 nm; containing only HBsAg
  • Double-walled spherical structure: 42 nm diameter; the complete hepatitis B virus; called the Dane particle, since it was first described by Dane

The illustration given below shows the sphericle structure of the hepatitis B virus.

Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is an objective marker of active HBV infection and is detectable in large quantities in the serum. It is present in active infection and also may be present in the chronic carrier state (when it persists for longer than 6 months). 

Hepatitis B core antigen (HBcAg) is a capsid/core protein found on nucleocapsid. 

Hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) is the envelop antigen. It is a protein on the nucleocapsid. It is a marker of active viral replication. The persistence of HBeAg is an indicator of chronic hepatitis B with active viral replication. Anti-HBeAg antibodies are produced against these antigens.

The nucleocapsid contains the DNA, which appears partially double-stranded and partially single-stranded. It is associated with a viral DNA polymerase that has both DNA-dependent DNA polymerase and RNA-dependent reverse transcriptase functions.

The image given below shows the hepatitis B virus genome.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

questions.text: During the routine checkup of a primigravida in her fifth month of pregnancy, you notice that fundal height is 4 weeks less than the corresponding period of gestation. An anomaly scan showed increased cortical echogenicity in both the kidneys, dilated ureters, and a bladder neck to fundal height of 70mm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of oligohydramnios evidenced by a difference of 4 weeks between the fundal height and the period of gestation along with increased cortical echogeneicity in both kidneys, and a bladder neck height of 70mm (normal <35mm) is suggestive of bladder outlet obstruction most likely due to posterior urethral valves (PUV).  

PUV is the result of abnormal, persistent urethral folds that cause bladder outlet obstruction in males resulting in urinary obstruction. This leads to a dilated posterior urethra and bladder distension (eg, fluid-filled abdominal mass). With increasing backup of urine, hydronephrosis may develop (eg, enlarged kidneys with thin renal cortices). Decreased fetal urine output leads to subsequent oligohydramnios. Prolonged and early-onset oligohydramnios, is associated with pulmonary hypoplasia (ie, neonatal respiratory syndrome) because amniotic fluid is required for fetal lung development. 

Oligohydramnios refers to a decreased volume of amniotic fluid. The clinical definition of oligohydramnios can be given as follows:

  • Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) <5 cm
  • Deepest vertical pocket (DVP) <2 cm

Fetal conditions that can cause oligohydramnios include:

  • Amnion nodosum
  • Bilateral renal agenesis
  • Multicystic dysplastic kidney disease
  • Bladder outlet obstruction disorders like posterior urethral valves
  • Sirenomelia-previously termed mermaid syndrome. It is characterized by a single lower extremity in the mid-line and bilateral renal agenesis.
  • Persistent cloaca
  • Intrauterine infections 

Other options:

Options A & D: Bilateral renal agenesis and bilateral dysplastic kidneys are also associated with oligohydramnios and hypoplastic lungs; however, ultrasound would reveal absent or small (rather than enlarged) kidneys and small (rather than distended) bladder.

Option B: Polycystic kidney disease may result in enlarged kidneys and oligohydramnios due to abnormally functioning fetal kidneys. However, affected fetuses would have a small to normal-sized bladder due to decreased urine production (rather than obstruction).

Related Pearl: Causes of oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida developed fever and pruritic vesicular rashes one day after a full-term normal vaginal delivery. A diagnosis of varicella infection was made. How should the neonate be managed?

choices.text: Acyclovir therapy should be started immediately

questions.solution:
Passive immunization with Varicella-Zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) is administered to neonates whose mothers develop a varicella-zoster rash from five days before delivery up to two days after delivery.

If the fetus or neonate is exposed to active varicella infection just before or during delivery, they may develop a disseminated visceral and central nervous system disease, which can be fatal. Neonte is not at risk of severe neonatal chicken pox, if mother contracts infection before and after this period (i.e 5 days before and 2 days after delivery), in that case passive immunisation is not required.

VZIG may not prevent infection, but reduces the severity of neonatal infection. Monitoring of the neonate should be prolonged to 28 days, as VZIG may prolong the incubation period.

If signs of neonatal infection develop despite VZIG, the neonate should be treated with acyclovir. 

Primary varicella infection presents with flu-like symptoms, followed by a pruritic vesicular rash. The fetus may develop congenital varicella syndrome if infection occurs in the first half of pregnancy, the highest risk is between 13 and 20 weeks. Features of congenital varicella syndrome include:

  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cerebral cortical atrophy
  • Growth restriction
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Cicatricial skin lesions

Pregnant women who are exposed to varicella and are susceptible should be given VZIG. Infected women usually require only supportive care, but those who require intravenous (IV) fluids and or develop pneumonia should be hospitalized. Intravenous acyclovir therapy is given to women requiring hospitalization.

questions.text:
A 12-day-old infant born at 33 weeks of gestation presents with abdominal distension and hematochezia. An abdominal X-ray reveals the presence of air within the bowel wall. Which of the following statements are true regarding this infant’s diagnosis?

PPI - Proton pump inhibitor

1. Early and aggressive feeding reduces the incidence of this condition
2. Intestinal strictures can occur after surgical treatment
3. Prevention is possible by administering antenatal antibiotics and PPIs
4. Surgery is ideal after necrosis and before peritonitis
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a preterm infant presenting with abdominal distension and hematochezia along with X-ray findings of pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall) is suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). Statements 2 and 4 are correct regarding this condition.

Necrotizing enterocolitis is a multifactorial disease primarily associated with intestinal immaturity characterized by mucosal or transmural necrosis of the intestine. It is more common in preterm infants. Other risk factors include bacterial colonization in the gut and formula feeding. Breast milk is protective against necrotizing enterocolitis.

The triad of intestinal ischemia (injury), enteral nutrition (metabolic substrate), and bacterial translocation have classically been linked to necrotizing enterocolitis.

Pathological changes include necrotic segment(s) of the intestine, gas accumulation in the submucosa of the bowel wall (pneumatosis intestinalis), and progression of the necrosis to perforation (pneumoperitoneum), and peritonitis.

Intestinal strictures can occur as sequelae and can lead to short bowel syndrome after surgical treatment. (Statement 2)

Surgery is ideal after necrosis and before peritonitis. (Statement 4). Surgery is an absolute indication after pneumoperitoneum. Surgical methods include primary peritoneal drainage or exploratory laparotomy.

Other options:

Early and aggressive feeding in very low-birth infants increases the incidence of necrotizing enterocolitis (statement 1).

Antenatal antibiotics and PPIs are risk factors for the development of necrotizing enterocolitis and, therefore have no role in prevention (statement 3).

questions.text: The lack of alpha oxidation of fatty acid leads to which of the following?

choices.text: Oxidation of branched chain fatty acids

questions.solution:
The lack of alpha oxidation of fatty acid leads to accumulation of phytanic acid.

Alpha oxidation is the removal of one carbon atom at a time from alpha carbon atom. Here the fatty acid does not need activation unlike beta oxidation. It occurs in branched chain fatty acid to remove methyl group at branch points. It neither consumes nor generate energy. Oxidation of phytanic acid is by alpha oxidation , phytanic acid is major dietary methylated fatty acid seen in dairy products.

Defect in alpha oxidation of phytanic acid in peroxisomes is called refsum's disease, the deficient enzyme is phytanoyl-CoA dioxygenase.

questions.text:
Which of the following instruments can be sterilized by the device given below?

1) A scalpel's metal handle
2) Cytotoxic drugs
3) Catgut suture
4) Liquid culture media 
5) A glass petri dish
questions.solution:
The above image shows an autoclave machine that can be used for sterilizing scalpel metal handle, liquid culture media, and a glass petri dish.

Autoclaving is a method of heat sterilization. The autoclave is a device that uses steam under pressure to sterilize linen, instruments, laboratory ware, media, pharmaceutical products, aqueous solutions, surgical instruments, cardiac catheters, and implants. It uses steam under pressure. Steam at atmospheric pressure is used in Koch or Arnold steamer. It is a method of sterilization by moist heat (steam under pressure), high penetrative power with a temperature of 121°C for 15 min. Spores of Geobacillus stearothermophilus act as a control. It is also not used to sterilize endoscopes because most of them are heat-sensitive. 

Other options:

Options B, C: It is not used to sterilize cytotoxic drugs as it is a hazardous waste and also not used to sterilize catgut due to its proteinaceous nature leading the suture material to lose a lot of its tensile strength.

questions.text: Which of the following is a predisposing factor for severe anaphylactic reaction to transfusion of blood and blood products?
questions.solution:
Severe, potentially fatal, allergic reactions to blood transfusion are likely to occur in patients with IgA deficiency. It is triggered by recipient IgG antibodies that recognize IgA in the infused blood product.

IgA-deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components can be used to prevent allergic reactions in individuals with IgA Deficiency. Treatment of severe anaphylaxis involves stopping the transfusion. Vascular access is maintained and administration of 0.3–0.5 mg of adrenaline is done. Administration of steroids, antihistamine drugs, and bronchodilators is done.

The various blood transfusion reactions according to their time of occurrence are as follows:

  • Anaphylactic reaction - Within a few seconds to minutes of the transfusion
  • Allergic/Urticarial reactions - Within 2-3 hours of transfusion
  • Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR) - Within 6 hours of transfusion
  • Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) - Within 24 hours of transfusion
  • Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR) - After 24 hours of transfusion

Other options:

Option B: Antibodies to HLA will cause febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction within a few hours and usually present with mild symptoms like fever, headache, nausea and vomiting. 

Option C: ABO incompatibility will cause acute hemolytic transfusion reaction within 24 hours due to preformed anti-A and anti-B antibodies in the donor and clinically presents with fever, chills, and hemoglobinuria, and may cause renal failure later.

Option D: Cytokines in the stored blood will cause a febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction due to transfusion of platelet concentrates which are not leukoreduced and will clinically present with mild symptoms like fever, headache, nausea and vomiting. 

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Mild fever, hemolytic anemia

  • Transient hypotension
  • Immunomodulation
  • Blood-borne infections

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the brachial plexus is most likely to have been injured in the following condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a typical presentation of a policeman's tip or waiter's tip hand deformity seen in Erb’s palsy, which occurs in injuries to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus.

The Erb’s point in the brachial plexus is in the upper trunk, where the six nerves meet. The nerves are the C5 and C6 roots, suprascapular nerve, nerve to subclavius, and the anterior and posterior divisions of the upper trunk.

Given below is a diagram depicting the location of the Erb's point

The brachial plexus is anatomically divided into: roots, trunks, divisions, cords, and branches. (summarized in the pearl below)

The common causes of Erb's palsy are the undue separation of head and neck i.e. fall on shoulder and birth injuries. The resulting muscle weakness results in the depicted deformity which includes the following features:

  • Arm is adducted and medially rotated at the shoulder joint
  • Elbow joint is extended
  • Radioulnar joint is pronated
  • Sensory loss along the outer aspect of the arm

Given below is an image further showing the features of patients with Erb's palsy

  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

  • Upper trunk: C5 and C6
  • Middle trunk: C7.

  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is found to have a power of -1.5 D spherical and -1.0 D cylindrical at 90 degrees. What is the type of astigmatism?
questions.solution:
The girl with a power of -1.5 D spherical and -1.0 D cylindrical at 90 degrees has against the rule astigmatism, as the horizontal meridian is greater and more curved than the vertical meridian.

Step 1: -1.5 D spherical indicates power of -1.5 on vertical and horizontal axes.
Step 2: -1.0 D cylindrical at 90 degrees indicates a power of -1.0 D at 180 degrees (perpendicular to 90). 

Hence, as the horizontal meridian (-2.5D) is greater than the vertical meridian (-1.5D), this would be against the rule astigmatism.

Astigmatism refers to the condition where there is different refractory power in both the principal meridians of the eye. Astigmatism is classified into two broad varieties - regular and irregular astigmatism.

Regular astigmatism: there are two principal meridians.
- With the rule (Option B) -  principal meridians are vertical and horizontal; both meridians at 90°; and the vertical meridian is more curved than horizontal.
- Against the rule -  principal meridians are vertical and horizontal; both meridians at 90°; and the horizontal meridian is more curved than vertical.
- Oblique - the principal meridians are not vertical and horizontal, but they are at 90° to each other; e.g., at 45° and 135°.
- Bi-oblique -  the two principal meridians are not vertical and horizontal, and they are not at 90° each other; e.g., at 40° and 100°.

Irregular astigmatism: there are multiple meridians.

Other options: 

Option A: In simple astigmatism, one of the meridia focuses on the retina. The other meridian focuses either in front of the retina (simple myopic) or behind the retina (simple hyperopic). Example, -1.00 DC × 180 degree.

Option C: Mixed astigmatism: Light rays in one meridian are focused in front of the retina and those in the other meridian are focused behind the retina. Example, -1DS with +2DC at 180 degree.

questions.text: A patient presents with invasive aspergillosis after undergoing a liver transplantation and is prescribed voriconazole. The dosage of which of the following immunosuppressive medications needs to be altered due to the effects of this drug interaction?
questions.solution:
Voriconazole inhibits hepatic cytochrome P450 (CYP2C19, CYP2C9, CYP3A4, CYP3A5) and thus interacts with various drugs. Tacrolimus is metabolized by CYP3A, therefore dose reduction of tacrolimus is necessary to prevent drug toxicity if it is to be used concurrently with voriconazole.

Tacrolimus is a calcineurin inhibitor and is the common agent used for immunosuppression following liver transplantation. They are metabolized by the CYP3A enzyme (CYP3A4, CYP3A5, CYP3A7).

Voriconazole is an enzyme inhibitor which can increase the concentration of tacrolimus in patient with liver transplant. These patient will develop coarse tremors a few months after liver transplantation and who is on tacrolimus will likely to suffer from tacrolimus-induced tremors and it requires tacrolimus dose reduction. 

Enzyme inducers Enzyme inhibitors

Mnemonic: CRAP GPS

  • Carbamazepine
  • Rifampicin
  • Alcohol (chronic)
  • Phenytoin
  • Griseofulvin
  • Phenobarbitone
  • Sulfonylureas

Mnemonic: RED VICK

  • Ritonavir
  • Erythromycin
  • Diltiazem
  • Verapamil, Valproate
  • Itraconazole
  • Clarithromycin, Cimetidine
  • Ketoconazole

Other options : 

Option B : Mycophenolate mofetil is a prodrug that is hydrolyzed to mycophenolic acid by plasma esterases.  CYP3A ezyme is not involved in the metabolism of mycophenolate mofetil.

Option C : Belatacept shows no specific pharmacokinetic drug-drug interactions.

Option D :  The major enzyme involved in the catabolism of azathioprine and its metabolites is xanthine oxidase. The administration of a xanthine oxidase inhibitor such as allopurinol for the treatment of gout would interfere with the metabolism of azathioprine. This would lead to an increased concentration of azathioprine and ultimately toxicity of the drug.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was asked to blow-off a paper repeatedly while doing an EEG. The recording shows symmetric, 3-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharges that begins and ends suddenly, superimposed on a normal EEG background. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is absence seizures. Hyperventilation provokes it.

The electrophysiologic hallmark of typical absence seizures is a generalized, symmetric, 3-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharges that begin and end suddenly, superimposed on a normal EEG background.

An absence seizure is characterized by a sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and without post-ictal confusion. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds. The patient presents with subtle, bilateral motor signs such as rapid blinking of the eyelids, chewing movements, or small-amplitude, clonic movements of the hands. The seizures can occur hundreds of times per day, but the child may be unaware of or unable to convey their existence.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the outpatient department with a complaint of worsening pain in his right buttock and right thigh, especially at night. X-ray reveal central lytic bone lesions with popcorn calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with worsening pain in the hip and osteolytic lesions with popcorn calcification is likely to have chondrosarcoma.

Chondrosarcoma is the second most common malignant matrix-producing bone tumor after osteosarcoma. It typically affects the pelvis, proximal femur, or humerus of individuals aged 40-70 years. The patient presents with progressively worsening pain and tenderness.

X-ray reveals osteolytic lesions and popcorn calcification or ring and arc calcification. Biopsy typically reveals cartilaginous growth with a lobulated appearance. It has the best prognosis among malignant bone tumors. It is radio and chemo-resistant. Treatment is surgery.

Other options:

Option a: Ewing sarcoma has an onion-peel appearance on X-ray due to an aggressive periosteal reaction. It typically occurs before the age of 30 years and affects diaphyses of long bones more commonly. 

Option b: Osteoclastoma has a soap bubble appearance on X-ray and typically affects individuals 20-40 years of age. Axial skeleton involvement is not common.

Option c: Osteochondroma appears as a small bony protrusion at metaphysis on X-ray. They are benign and rarely transform into chondrosarcomas.

Chondrosarcoma Any site in the bone - mc in proximal femur 3rd-5th decade
Clear cell chondrosarcoma Proximal femoral epiphysis  3rd-5th decade
Adamantinoma Diaphysis of Tibia  20-40 years
 Fibrous dysplasia  The upper end of femur > tibia  1st to 3rd decade
 Chordoma  Sacrum  5th to 7th decade
Multiple myeloma Vertebrae 5th to 7th decade

questions.text: As an intern in the department of community medicine, you are tasked with calculating Chandler's index for a rural community near your medical college. This index is used to calculate the load of which parasite in the community?
questions.solution:
Chandler's index is used to identify the importance of hookworm infestation as a public health problem in a community. It is calculated based on the average number of hookworm eggs/gram of stool:

  • <200: no significance
  • 200-250: the potential danger
  • 250-300: minor public health problem
  • >300: major public health problem

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

Related Pearl: Recommendations - WHO Guidelines for preventive chemotherapy to control soil-transmitted helminth infections in at-risk population groups

WHO has recently in September 2017 has proposed guidelines for preventive chemotherapy (deworming) to control soil-transmitted helminth infections in at-risk population groups.

The main soil-transmitted helminths includes the roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides), the whipworm (Trichuris trichiura) and the hookworms (Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus).

The following table shows various recommendations:

 

Risk group Prevalence Frequency Drugs and Dosage

Single-dose albendazole (400 mg)

Or

mebendazole (500 mg). 

Note: A half-dose of albendazole (i.e. 200 mg) is recommended for children 12–23 months of age.
Any soil-transmitted infection > 50%l Biannual
Non-pregnant adolescent girls and non-pregnant women of reproductive age Any soil-transmitted infection ≥ 20% Annual

Single-dose albendazole (400 mg)
