questions.text: A woman brings her 72-year-old father to the OPD with a history of multiple episodes of him forgetting his way back home. She also says that her father is not able to make a sandwich for himself, unlike before. What is the expected histopathological feature in the patient's brain?

choices.text: Loss of dopaminergic neurons of substantia nigra pars

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette described here shows impaired memory and other executional functioning loss suggesting Alzheimer's disease. Neurofibrillary tangles on histopathological section confirm the diagnosis.

In the early stages, the memory loss may go unrecognized or be ascribed to benign forgetfulness of ageing.

In the middle stages, the patient is unable to work, is easily lost and confused, and requires daily supervision. Apraxia emerges, manifesting as trouble performing learned sequential motor tasks such as using utensils or appliances.

In the late stages, some persons remain ambulatory, wandering aimlessly.

Neurofibrillary tangles are seen in Alzheimer's disease.

Neurofibrillary tangles are intracellular, hyperphosphorylated tau protein = insoluble cytoskeletal elements, the number of tangles correlates with degree of dementia.

Other options :

Option B : Loss of dopaminergic neurons of substantia nigra pars compacta is seen in Parkinson's.

Option C : Lewy bodies are seen in Parkinson's and Lewy body dementia.

Option D : Beta pleated sheets are seen in Prion disease. PrP (Prion protein) undergoes a conformational change from its normal α-helix (PrPc) to an abnormal β-pleated sheet (PrPsc) isoform and PrP becomes resistant to digestion with proteases.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man is brought to the casualty after falling at the bus stop. An ECG was done, as depicted below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
A shot of 1mg epinephrine IV is the best next step for a patient with an ECG showing asystole.

Asystole is the complete and sustained absence of electrical activity. It is usually seen as a terminal rhythm in a resuscitation attempt that started with another rhythm, or in a patient with unwitnessed or prolonged cardiac arrest. The prognosis for persistent asystole is poor. A pulseless electrical activity involves a heterogeneous group of cardiac rhythms, all without a pulse.

Shockable rhythms of cardiac arrest include Pulseless ventricular tachycardia and Ventricular fibrillation whereas Non-shockable rhythms of cardiac arrest include Pulseless electrical activity (PEA) and Asystole. (Option B)

Given below is a flow chart showing the adult ACLS algorithm.

Other options:

Option C: Atropine was removed from the 2010 ACLS guidelines as standard treatment for cardiac arrest patients with a non-shockable rhythm or adults with pulseless electrical activity (PEA) or asystole due to a lack of clear benefit. 

Option D: Performance of endotracheal intubation should not precede an injection of 1mg epinephrine as the latter would be very beneficial to kickstart the failing heart. Also, an endotracheal intubation may be performed particularly in patients with a compromised airway.

questions.text:
The following are events involved in phototransduction in rods and cones in response to light. Arrange them in sequence.
  1. Decreased release of glutamate
  2. Activation of transducin
  3. Closure of cGMP-gated cation channels
  4. Decrease in intracellular cGMP
  5. Structural changes in rhodopsin
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events is as follows

5 - Structural changes in rhodopsin

2 - Activation of transducin

4 - Decrease in intracellular cGMP

3 - Closure of cGMP-gated cation channels

1 - Decreased release of glutamate

The sequence of events involved in phototransduction in rods and cones in response to light is:

  • Structural changes in rhodopsin due to the incident light 
  • Activation of transducin 
  • Activation of phosphodiesterase
  • Decrease in intracellular cGMP 
  • Closure of cGMP-gated Na+ channel
  • Hyperpolarization
  • Decreased release of glutamate
  • Response in the bipolar cells

Below is an image further reiterating the phototransduction in rods and cones.

Related Pearl: Properties of Rod Vision and Cone Vision

Rods Cones
  • 120 million
  • More in peripheral retina
  • High sensitivity
  • Night vision (Scotopic vision)
  • Low acuity
  • Gray colour vision (achromatic vision)
  • On activation produces hyperpolarising current
  • 6 million in number
  • More Concentrated in fovea
  • Low sensitivity
  • Day vision (Photopic vision)
  • High acuity
  • Colour vision (Chromatic vision)
  • On activation produces hyperpolarising current

Related Pearl: Order of neurons in the visual pathway

Order of neurons in the visual pathway

First-order neurons

Photoreceptors
(rods and cones)

Second-order neurons

Bipolar cells

Third-order neurons

Ganglion cells
(optic nerve)

Fourth-order neurons

Axons from the lateral geniculate body
(optic radiation)

questions.text: A man presenting with high-grade soft-tissue sarcoma was administered radiotherapy. Due to lack of response, he was started on chemotherapy.  After 3 days of initiating chemotherapy, he developed lesions as shown in the image below. All of the drugs can be implicated in the development of these lesions except?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient developing lesions on the neck within 7 days of initiation of chemotherapy is suggestive of radiation sensitization. Amifostine is a known radioprotector and cannot be implicated in this case. 

Amifostine must be administered 30 minutes before irradiation. Other examples of radioprotectors include zinc oxide and chlorhexidine.

If the incidence of the lesion is within a period of 7 days it is called radiation sensitization and if the lesion appears after a period of 7 days it is called radiation recall syndrome. 

Radiation sensitization is more common than radiation recall. This is a period of enhanced sensitivity in the days after irradiation when the reaction to systemically administered drugs and the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is <7 days. Such reactions can be considered radiation enhancement or sensitization.

Radiation recall is less common than radiation sensitization. When the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is >7 days, months, or even years.

Other options:

Option A: Gemcitabine is a radiosensitizer. 

Option B: Cyclophosphamide when given as a combination with 5-Fluorouracil and epirubicin can cause radiation recall syndrome.

Option C: Doxorubicin can result in a radiation recall reaction or radiation sensitization. 

Related Pearl: Radioprotectors and Radiosensitizers

Radioprotectors:

Radioprotectors are substances that protect normal tissues from the effect of radiation. These include:

  • Zinc oxide
  • Pentoxifylline
  • Estramustine
  • Amifostine
  • Chlorhexidine (radiation-induced stomatitis)
  • Potassium iodide (for thyroid against radioactive iodine)
  • Melatonin
  • Antioxidants

Radiosensitizers:

Radiosensitizers make the tumor more susceptible to the action of radiotherapy. These include:

  • Oxygen
  • Cisplatin
  • 5 FU
  • Gemcitabine
  • Nitroimidazoles

Radiation potentiators:

The following drugs potentiate the action of radiation when used in conjunction: 

  • Doxorubicin
  • Dactinomycin

questions.text: A 23-year-old man came to you for nutritional advice. He is an alcoholic. Which of the following measures would not prevent the development of Wernicke's encephalopathy?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, vitamin C supplementation would not prevent the development of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

In an alcoholic person, thiamine deficiency can cause Wernicke's encephalopathy. Hence, the measures to prevent thiamine deficiency are:

  • Cessation of alcohol (Option A) 
  • Including gingelly seeds (sesame seeds) in the diet because they have the highest content of thiamine. (Option B)
  • Consuming parboiled rice instead of milled or highly polished rice. Thiamine is lost from rice during the process of milling. (Option C)
  • Direct supplementation with thiamine.

The two principal deficiency diseases of thiamine are:

  1. Beriberi may occur in three main forms :
    • The dry form is characterized by nerve involvement (peripheral neuritis)
    • The wet form is characterized by heart involvement (cardiac beriberi)
    • The infantile form is seen in infants between 2 to 4 months of age. The affected baby is usually breast-fed by a thiamine-deficient mother who commonly shows signs of peripheral neuropathy.
  2. Wernicke's encephalopathy is often seen often in alcoholics. It is characterized by ophthalmoplegia, polyneuritis, ataxia and mental deterioration. It occurs occasionally in people who fast.

High-risk groups for thiamine deficiency are:

  • Lactating mothers
  • Patients on regular haemodialysis
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Prolonged gastric aspiration 
  • People who go on long fasts

High-risk groups should be treated with direct supplementation of thiamine.

Note: Vitamin C supplementation in the dose of 500-1000mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is likely to have the largest volume of distribution?

choices.text: Drug A- large molecular weight and extensively bound to albumin
Drug B- large and lipid-insoluble molecule
Drug C- small lipophilic molecule with a tendency for sequestration in adipocytes

questions.solution:
Among the given options, Drug C, which is a small lipophilic molecule with a tendency for sequestration in adipocytes, will have the highest volume of distribution.

The difference in the volume of distribution based on drug type:

  • Low Vd 
    • Restricted to the intravascular compartment 
    • Seen in drugs with high molecular weight (e.g., heparin) or high protein binding (e.g., warfarin - 9.8L)
  • Medium Vd 
    • Lipid-insoluble drugs (e.g., gentamicin - 20 L) do not enter the cells and are distributed in the extracellular fluid volume.
    • Small water-soluble molecules (e.g., ethanol - 42 L) are distributed in the total body water.
  • High Vd
    • Sequestered and accumulated in the tissues
    • Small lipophilic molecules (e.g., chloroquine - 13000 L)

questions.text: The vaccine for which of the following diseases is a part of the Intensified Mission Indradhanush program?
questions.solution:
Japanese Encephalitis is a mosquito-borne viral disease that is a major public health concern in India, especially in rural areas. Outbreaks in the recent past and concerns about rising cases led to its inclusion in the Intensified Mission Indradhanush program for targeted vaccination in endemic regions.

Mission Indradhanush was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in 2014 to fully immunize children (>90%) who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. It was later modified in 2017 to the Intensified Mission Indradhanush, to achieve the same goal by December 2018. 

Intensified Mission Indradhanush includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 diseases that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th- 13th of each month).

The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are:

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are:

  • Rotavirus diarrhoea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis

Other options:

Option A: Meningococcal infections are usually asymptomatic. If invasive disease occurs, then the clinical spectrum varies widely from meningococcal meningitis (highest proportion) to bacteremia without sepsis, meningococcal septicemia with or without meningitis, pneumonia, chronic meningococcemia, and occult bacteremia.It is important to note that vaccines for prophylaxis against this organism is not part of the Intensified Mission Indradhanush.

Option B: Varicella Zoster although accounted as a common childhood illness, chickenpox vaccination is not part of the routine immunization program in India.

Option C: Human Papillomavirus vaccination is primarily targeted at preventing cervical cancer and is not included in the routine immunization program for children. While pilot programs for HPV vaccination exist, nationwide inclusion in Indradhanush is not currently planned.

questions.text: A young patient is pulled from the rubble of a collapsed building in a war zone. The patient is conscious and hemodynamically stable, however, he complains of inability to move his legs. After examination, you suspect a spinal cord injury. Under the wartime triage system, what code would you assign to this patient?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate category for this patient is yellow (medium priority) due to the potential spinal injury but no immediate life-threatening condition.

The yellow (medium priority) category includes patients who need resuscitation or surgery within 24 hours and have a good chance of survival with prompt treatment. Spinal injuries, along with moderate head injuries and pelvic fractures, typically fall under this category due to the potential for delayed complications like paralysis or shock if not addressed in time.

Triage means ‘to sort’ and is essential in the management of mass casualties. It aims to identify the patients in whom treatment at the earliest produces the maximum benefit. It is carried out at the site of the disaster to determine the priority for immediate medical attention, transportation, and admission to the hospital. Triage includes rapid classification of the injured based on their injuries and the chances of survival with prompt medical intervention. 

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: A young man met with a bike accident. He lost all his motor, sensory, and autonomic functions of the spinal cord below the level of the lesion. However, vibration and position sensations are preserved. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis of the patient is Anterior spinal artery (ASA) syndrome. 

ASA infarct typically presents as loss of motor function and pain/temperature sensation, with relative sparing of proprioception and vibratory sense below the level of the lesion. Since the dorsal column is located in the posterior or dorsal aspect of the spinal cord, it is spared.

Other options:

Central cord syndrome:

It results from selective damage to the gray matter nerve cells and crossing spinothalamic tracts surrounding the central canal. In the cervical cord, the central cord syndrome produces arm weakness out of proportion to leg weakness and a “dissociated” sensory loss, meaning loss of pain and temperature sensations over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk (cape distribution), in contrast to the preservation of light touch, joint position, and vibration sense in these regions.

Foramen magnum syndrome:

Around the clock pattern of weakness is described and manifests as a sequential weakness of the ipsilateral shoulder and arm followed by weakness of the ipsilateral leg, then the contralateral leg, and finally the contralateral arm. The pattern of the weakness may begin in any of the limbs. 

Brown–Sequard Syndrome: ipsilateral weakness (corticospinal tract) and loss of joint position and vibratory sense (posterior column), with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense (spinothalamic tract) one or two levels below the lesion

Related Pearl: Ascending tracts of spinal cord

 

Pathway Dorsal column Anterior spinothalamic tract Lateral spinothalamic tract
Receptor Meissner corpuscles, pacinian corpuscles, muscle spindles, golgi tendon organs Free nerve endings Free nerve endings 
First-order neuron

First-order neurons from the receptors enter spinal cord from dorsal root >

ascend ipsilaterally as fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus >

synapse in nucleus gracilis and nucleus cuneatus in medulla > 

 First-order neurons from dorsal root ganglion ascend for a few segments and synapse with the cells in the posterior gray column >
Second-order neuron

second-order neurons from nucleus gracilis and nucleus cuneatus continue as internal arcuate fibers > 

decussate in the lower medulla and ascends as medial lemniscus on the contralateral side >

synapse in the ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus

Second-order neurons from the posterior gray column crossover to the opposite side and ascend as anterior and lateral spinothalamic tract >

form the spinal lemniscus in the medulla >

ascend through pons and synapses in the ventral posterolateral nucleus of thalamus >
Third-order neuron third-order neuron from the ventral posterolateral nucleus of thalamus ascend in the posterior limb of internal capsule and corona radiata and terminate in somatosensory cortex Third-order neurons from the ventral posterolateral nucleus of thalamus ascend through the posterior limb of internal capsule and corona radiata and terminate in the somatosensory cortex
Decussation Medulla Spinal cord - few segments above the entry point   Spinal cord- one segment above the entry point
Sensations carried Proprioception, Fine touch(discriminative touch), pressure intesity, vibration, position sense Crude touch, pressure  Pain and temperature

 

Related Pearl: Descending tracts of spinal cord

Tract Corticospinal tract Reticulospinal tract Tectospinal tract Rubrospinal tract Vestibulospinal tract Olivospinal tract

Reticular formation

questions.text:
Match the following E. coli with their respective toxins.
E. coli Mechanism of action
1. ETEC a. Produces EAST-1 toxin 
2. EHEC b. Produces a heat-stable and heat-labile toxin 
3. EAEC c. Produces verocytotoxin against vascular endothelial cells
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are as follows:

E. coli Mechanism of action
1. ETEC b. Produces a heat-stable and heat-labile toxin 
2. EHEC c. Produces verocytotoxin against vascular endothelial cells
3. EAEC a. Produces EAST-1 toxin

The various strains of Escherichia coli are:

Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) is the most common organism causing traveler’s diarrhea. It produces the following toxins:

  • LT (heat-labile toxin)- acts by ↑cAMP.
  • ST (heat-stable toxin)- two types of ST are known, ST-A (ST-I) and ST-B (ST-II)
    • ST-A is soluble in methanol and acts by ↑cGMP in the intestine. 
    • ST-B is insoluble in methanol, and the mode of action is not known.

Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces verocytotoxin, which targets vascular endothelium. It causes hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome.

Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) produces the stacked brick pattern of adherence on hep-2 cells. EAEC has been associated with persistent diarrhea. Intestinal colonization of EAEC is mediated by AAF (aggregative adherence fimbriae). EAEC produces EAST-1 toxin (enteroaggregative heat-stable toxin) which is considered to be a major virulence factor.

Enteroinvasive E.coli (EIEC) invades interstitial epithelial cells in the intestine and causes a condition resembling shigellosis. This ability is determined by a plasmid, which can be detected as a diagnostic test. 

Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) causes infantile diarrhea in developing countries. It adheres to the mucosal surface of the small intestine using E. coli adherent factor (EAF) and locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) and causes effacement of microvilli.

questions.text:
While administering an axillary nerve block for a patient, the resident accidentally injects the anesthetic agent into the axillary artery. Which of the following co-morbidities if present can accentuate the condition?
  1. Increased age
  2. Hypercapnia
  3. Renal failure
  4. Metabolic alkalosis
  5. Cardiac failure
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST). Increased age, hypercapnia, renal failure, and cardiac failure can accentuate LAST. Acidosis (respiratory or metabolic), and not alkalosis, can also increase LAST.

LAST can occur due to inadvertent injection of a local anesthetic (LA), intravascular migration of a catheter used for continuous LA infusion, and absorption from the mucus membranes and the GI tract when swallowed (used during bronchoscopy).

The risk factors for LAST are:

  • Extremes of age: Infants and the elderly
  • End organ dysfunction: Cardiac disease, renal insufficiency, hepatic disease
  • Metabolic disturbances: Acidosis, hypoxia, hypercarbia
  • Pregnancy

LAST affects the following systems:

  • Central nervous system (CNS): LAs predominantly block the cortical inhibitory pathways, thereby causing excitatory symptoms and signs like a metallic taste, perioral numbness, mental status changes, visual changes, muscle twitching, and seizures. Further increase in blood levels causes CNS depression, leading to respiratory depression and coma. 
  • Cardiovascular system (CVS): Bradycardia and hypotension are usually seen. Cardiovascular toxicity may progress to ventricular arrhythmias, asystole, conduction disturbances, impaired cardiac contractility, and loss of vascular tone.

Management includes:

  • Stop administration of the agent
  • Arrange for cardiopulmonary bypass
  • Manage airway to prevent hypoxia and acidosis
  • Suppress seizures with appropriate medication (benzodiazepine is preferred) to improve oxygenation
  • Provide cardiovascular support with appropriate medication (amiodarone for arrhythmia) to maintain coronary perfusion
  • Administer 20% lipid emulsion:
    • Rapid administration of bolus lipid emulsion over 2-3 min
    • Begin infusion based on patient's body weight
    • Repeat bolus and double the infusion rate for persistent cardiovascular toxicity
    • Continue infusion for at least 10 min after hemodynamic stability is achieved

Related Pearl: Systemic Absorbtion of Local Anaesthetic in the Order of Occurrence

Systemic absorption of a local anesthetic depends on vascularity.

The highest blood concentrations are seen following:

  1. Intravenous (intraarterial) injection (maximum)
  2. Intercostal nerve blockade
  3. Paracervical block
  4. Caudal epidural block
  5. Lumbar epidural block
  6. Brachial plexus block
  7. Sciatic block
  8. Subcutaneous injection (minimum)

Related Pearl: Maximum dose of local anaesthetics

Local Anesthetic

Maximum dose
  Plain

With adrenaline

Lidocaine

4.5 mg/kg up to 300 mg 

7 mg/kg up to 500 mg

Bupivacaine 

175mg

 200 mg

Ropivacaine

200 mg

 250 mg

 

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine: 

  • Naturally occurring
  • Vasoconstrictor
  • 1st local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine: Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine: 

  • Safest
  • Causes maximum methemoglobinemia
  • Suitable for Bier’s IV block
  • EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

  • Long-acting
  • Most cardiotoxic
  • Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia
  • Toxicity is treated with amiodarone, bretylium(for VT), vasopressors (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

  • LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia
  • 1st synthetic LA
  • Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

questions.text: A child presenting with growth retardation is found to have aminoaciduria, glycosuria, and phosphaturia. His urine pH is acidic (pH < 5.5). What is the location of the defect in this child's nephrons?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 3-year-old child  with aminoaciduria, glycosuria, and phosphaturia along with acidic pH of urine is suggestive of Fanconi syndrome. The likely location of the defect is proximal convoluted tubules. 

Tubular dysfunction in this case leads to a proximal renal tubular acidosis (type 2 RTA). This type of RTA is characterized by defects in reabsorption in the proximal tubule, leading to glycosuria, generalized aminoaciduria, and phosphaturia. There is defect in the proximal tubule HCO3- reabsorption. This leads to increased excretion of HCO3- and metabolic acidosis. There is increased delivery of the tubular fluid to the distal tubule, leading to increased Na+ reabsorption and K+ secretion in the distal tubule under the effect of aldosterone.

Note that the effect of HCO3- loss overpowers the H+ loss in the distal tubule due to aldosterone, and thus the net result is metabolic acidosis. The urine pH is mostly <5.5 because of the depletion of the HCO3- stores in the body, but it can be >5.5 early in the disease course due to excess filtered HCO3-. The causes of type 2 RTA include Fanconi syndrome, multiple myeloma, and Wilson's disease.

Other options:

Option A and B: Disorders involving distal convulated tubule and collecting duct include distal RTA (type 1), Liddle syndrome, Gitelman syndrome, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

Option D: The glomerulus filters blood to form urine, not directly involved in tubular reabsorption or the pathophysiology of Fanconi syndrome.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: An obese 35-year-old man with renal failure presents with a sudden onset of excruciating joint pain in the right knee with associated localized hyperemia. He had been having recurrent pain in his left toe for which he uses an ice pack. Which of the following is the best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Joint pain in the knee along with a repeated history of pain in the left toe could indicate gout but it is crucial to also consider septic arthritis as a differential diagnosis concerning his pain in the knee, hence requiring a joint aspiration as intraarticular steroid injection would only deteriorate the clinical status of the patient if misdiagnosed as a case of gout.

Gout is characterized by episodic inflammatory arthritis due to the formation and deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals within the joints. It occurs due to an increased pool of uric acid in the body due to chronic hyperuricemia. Acute episodes progress to chronic arthritis with persistent synovitis and joint erosions.

An acute episode of gout flare is characterized by painful, warm, red, tender, and swollen joints. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe is involved in 70–90% of cases (podagra), followed by tarsal joints, ankles, and knees. Triggers of such flares include purine-rich food, alcohol, diuretic use, local trauma, and medical illnesses such as congestive heart failure and respiratory conditions.

Diagnosis is made by synovial fluid examination, which may show needle-shaped monosodium urate crystals. These crystals show bright, negative birefringence under polarized light, as shown below.

WBC count may be increased in synovial fluid. Serum uric acid level is usually elevated in chronic gout patients, but it may remain normal or low during acute attacks, because of the uricosuric property of inflammatory cytokines.

Management of acute gout includes the application of ice packs, rest, NSAIDS, colchicine, and glucocorticoids. In patients with chronic hyperuricemia urate-lowering agents like xanthine oxidase inhibitors (like allopurinol and febuxostat) or uricosuric drugs (like probenecid) can be used. However, urate-lowering therapy is not started during an ongoing acute episode of gout because it can worsen the flare. 

Other options:

Option A: Naproxen is contraindicated in patients with compromised renal function and active peptic ulcer disease.

Option D: Serum uric acid level is usually elevated in chronic gout patients, but it may remain normal or low during acute attacks, because of the uricosuric property of inflammatory cytokines. Hence, deeming it the least useful in even diagnosing a case of gout.

Related Pearl: Difference between Gout and Pseudo-gout

Finding

Gout

Pseudogout

Crystal composition

Monosodium urate

Calcium pyrophosphate

Shape

Needle like

Rhomboid

Birefringence pattern

Negative

Weak positive

Most commonly affected joint

1st MTP

Knee

X-ray findings

Periarticular erosions with overhanging margins

Chondrocalcinosis

questions.text: An old hypertensive male patient had a recent change in his anti-hypertensive drug. He now comes with complaints of dizziness on standing for few minutes. This started soon after taking the new drug. Which of the following class of drugs would have most likely caused this effect?
questions.solution:
The patient is having drug-induced orthostatic/postural hypotension and it is caused by the effect of alpha1 - selective receptor blocker.

Alpha1 receptor blockers, such as prazosin, cause a reduction of peripheral resistance as well as venous pooling of blood. This causes a decrease in venous return and cardiac output leading to a fall in blood pressure. Postural reflex causes marked postural hypotension which leads to syncope. This dizziness and fainting are known as the first dose effect and can be minimized by starting with a minimal dose and titrating it thereafter. Other side effects include reflex tachycardia, miosis, nasal congestion, and impotence. 

They are used as an antihypertensive agent and in benign hypertrophy of the prostate to decrease prostatic tone.

Other options:

Option A: Nonselective Beta receptor blockers, such as intravenous propranolol, is used to treat life-threatening arrhythmias, etc. It produces side effects such as bradycardia, exacerbating heart failure and chronic obstructive lung diseases, etc.

Option B: Alpha2 selective receptor agonists, such as apraclonidine, are used to reduce intraocular pressure and have minimal systemic effects. Side effects include dry mouth, sleepiness, and conjunctival hyperemia. 

Option C: Beta2 selective receptor agonists, such as salbutamol, act as a bronchodilator, vasodilators, and uterine relaxants. They have side effects such as muscle tremors, palpitations, etc.

questions.text: During your ward rounds, you notice a child with peculiar eye movements as shown in the gif below. Which of the following can be the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome(OMS)  is seen in the case of neuroblastoma.

It is rapid, conjugate eye nystagmus with involuntary spasms of the limbs also called dancing eyes-dancing feet syndrome.The causes include:

When opsoclonus and myoclonus occur together, the cause is a tumour until proven otherwise.In other cases, the disorder has been designated ‘idiopathic’ or attributed to various mostly viral infections. 

Most patients do not have antineuronal antibodies. A small subset of patients with ataxia, opsoclonus, and other eye-movement disorders develop anti-Ri antibodies. Both these could be secondary to viral infections or encephalitis. 

The main treatment for OMS is early and sufficient immunotherapy with the goal of gaining a durable complete neurological remission. The general line of management includes corticosteroid administration or ACTH. If a tumour is present, surgical resection is standard. 

Neuroblastoma is an embryonal tumour of the sympathetic nervous system. It is the most common extracranial solid tumour in childhood. At the same time, brain tumour is the most common solid tumour in childhood. These tumours arise during fetal or early postnatal life from sympathetic cells derived from the neural crest. There­ fore, tumours can originate anywhere along the path which neural crest cells migrate, including the adrenal medulla, paraspinal sympathetic ganglia, and sympathetic para­ ganglia such as the organ of Zuckerkandl.

It is a malignancy of neuroblast cells in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia and typically presents as an abdominal or paravertebral mass. Raccoon eyes (periorbital ecchymoses) are seen in neuroblastoma due to orbital metastasis. Blue subcutaneous nodules represent skin dissemination of tumour-associated with the "Blueberry Muffin Syndrome".Shimada classification is used for classifying neuroblastoma.

questions.text: A dead body brought for autopsy is found to have a ligature mark around the neck. Which of the following findings is least consistent with hanging?

choices.text: Ligature mark is above the hyoid
Ligature mark has a gap at the nape of the neck

questions.solution:
The ligature mark found in a case of hanging is more likely to be non-continuous, while the ligature mark in a case of strangulation is more likely to be continuous.

In the event of a hanging, which is commonly suicidal, the ligature mark is usually above the hyoid bone (Option A). It runs obliquely, backwards, upwards, is non-continuous, and towards the point of suspension (Option B). The mark is noncontinuous because of a gap at the nape of the neck (Option D). The skin is usually depressed/grooved, yellowish-brown, dry, hard, with small abrasions called rope burns at its edges.

Strangulation is a type of asphyxia where there is neck constriction without suspension of the body. The pressure on the neck is applied either by bare hands, a ligature, or by any other instrument. There is sudden and violent compression of the windpipe which causes immediate insensibility and death. 

Ligature strangulation, which is commonly homicidal, is characterized by a mark that is transverse and completely encircling the neck below the thyroid cartilage. There is no dribbling of saliva. Bleeding may be present in the ears, nose, and mouth. Thyroid cartilage fracture is commonly seen in strangulation. However, the hyoid bone fracture is uncommon.

Related Pearl: Difference between strangulation by Ligature and Hanging

Trait

Hanging

Strangulation by ligature

Nature of death

Mostly suicidal

Mostly homicidal

Face

Usually pale and petechiae are rare

Congested, livid, and marked with petechiae

Tongue

Swelling and protrusion is less marked

Swelling and protrusion is more marked

Bleeding

Bleeding from the nose, mouth, and ears is not common

Bleeding from the nose, mouth, and ears may be found

Saliva

Often dribbles out of the mouth

Dribbling of saliva is very rare

Ligature mark

Oblique, non-continuous, placed high up in the neck between the chin and the larynx. 

The subcutaneous tissue underneath the mark is usually hard, white, and glistening

Horizontal or transverse, continuous around the neck, low down in the neck below or across the thyroid.   

Subcutaneous tissue underneath may be ecchymosed

Abrasions and

ecchymoses

Rare

Common

Injury to muscles of

neck

Rare

Common

Carotid arteries

Internal coats are usually ruptured in violent cases of a long drop (Amussat's sign)

Damage to the internal coat is rare

Hyoid bone fracture

Less common

Less common (common in manual strangulation)

Thyroid cartilage fracture

Less common

More common

Cervical vertebrae fracture or dislocation

Common in judicial hanging

Rare

questions.text:
A resident is doing an abdominal examination in a primigravida. Sequentially arrange the uses of Leopold's maneuvers, starting from the first to the fourth.
  1. Determine the degree of descent
  2. Confirmation of fetal presentation
  3. Determine the fetal orientation
  4. Determine which fetal pole occupies the fundus.
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is as follows

Leopold First maneuvre - Determine which fetal pole occupies the fundus

Leopold second maneuver - Determine the fetal orientation

Leopold third maneuver - Confirmation of fetal presentation

Leopold fourth maneuver - Determine the degree of descent

Leopold’s first maneuver (fundal grip) is used to determine which fetal pole occupies the fundus.

Leopold’s second maneuver (lateral grip) can be used to determine the fetal orientation based on whether the back is facing anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly. The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen and gentle deep pressure is exerted. The fetal back is felt as a hard-resistant structure and the fetal limbs are felt as multiple small irregular parts.

Leopold’s third maneuver (Pawlik’s grip) helps to confirm fetal presentation. It is done by grasping the lower part of the maternal abdomen with the thumb and fingers of one hand. The palpation of a hard and round mass indicates that the presenting part is the fetal head. A movable mass suggests that the presenting part is not engaged. If the presenting part is breech, it is felt as a large nodular mass.

Leopold’s fourth maneuver (pelvic grip) helps to determine the degree of descent. The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part. They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.

questions.text:
A patient presents with drowsiness, seizures, and oliguria after consuming an engine coolant. Lab results are given below. The patient’s oliguria improves with diuretic administration. Which of the following is the likely indication for hemodialysis in this scenario?

pH: 7.3 
pCO2: 32 mmHg
pO2: 98 mmHg
HCO3-: 10 mEq/L
Serum Na+: 138 mEq/L
K+: 6.9 mEq/L
Cl-: 102 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This scenario presents a classic case of ethylene glycol (component in engine coolants) poisoning, leading to metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia, and potentially neurologic complications. In this scenario, the most likely indication for hemodialysis is severe hyperkalemia >6.5 mmol/L.

The emergent indications of dialysis or renal replacement therapy can be remembered by the mnemonic - 'AEIOU' (vowels in the English alphabet). These include

  • Severe metabolic Acidosis ( pH < 7.1) with concomitant renal injury.
  • Electrolyte abnormalities - Severe hyperkalemia (>6.5 mmol/L) or rapidly rising potassium levels.
  • Intoxication - In cases of severe poisoning of toxic substances like methanol or ethylene glycol, and cases of overdose with a dialyzable drug.
  • Fluid Overload that is not responsive to diuretic therapy.
  • Uremia - elevated BUN with signs and symptoms of uremia like bleeding, pericarditis, and altered mental status.
  Hemodialyzable drugs  Non-hemodialyzable drugs
  • Methanol
  • Salicylate
  • Valproic acid
  • Phenobarbital
  • Lithium
  • Metformin
  • Digoxin
  • Diazepam
  • Verapamil
  • Opioids
  • Metoprolol
  • Amphetamines

Other options: 

Option A: Persistent metabolic acidosis can still warrant dialysis if severe enough (pH < 7.1). However, given the pH of 7.3, this is unlikely the primary indication.

Option B: Fluid overload is not a major concern since the patient is responding to diuretics.

Option D: Seizures are a common complication, but dialysis is not typically indicated unless other causes are ruled out and anticonvulsants are ineffective.

questions.text:
During your neonatal rotation, a final year student asks you to explain the score which evaluates the baby at 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth. Which among the following is an incorrect statement regarding it?
  1. 1 point is assigned if the baby is pink with blue extremities
  2. 0 points are assigned if the baby is floppy
  3. 2 points are assigned if the pulse is absent 
  4. 1 point is assigned if the respiratory rate is less than 40
  5. 2 points if the baby coughs in response to the insertion of a nasal catheter
questions.solution:
The score which evaluates the baby at 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth is the APGAR score, and statements 3 and 4 are incorrect.

The Apgar score is a method of systematically evaluating newborn infants immediately after birth. It measures appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, and respiration. It is performed at 1 minute and again at 5 minutes after birth.

Statements 3 and 4 are incorrect because 0 points are assigned if the pulse is absent, and respiratory rate is not used in calculating the APGAR score, but the respiratory effort is considered.

The maximum score is 10 which indicates the fetus is in the best possible condition. Scores of 0-3 require immediate resuscitation, although resuscitation should ideally be started before the  1-minute APGAR score is calculated. 

APGAR score can be used to assess the response to resuscitative efforts and should be calculated every 5 minutes for up to 20 minutes if the 5-minute Apgar score is less than 7.

Causes of Low APGAR scores include:

  • Fetal distress
  • Prematurity
  • Analgesics, narcotics, sedatives
  • Airway obstruction (Eg: choanal atresia)
  • Pneumonia and sepsis
  • Previous episodes of fetal asphyxia (recovered)

False-negative APGAR score is when the score is normal, but there is acidosis or high fetal catecholamine levels.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient developed a nerve palsy following a Holstein Lewis fracture. Which of the following splints is likely to be used in this case?
questions.solution:
Cock-up splint corresponding to option “1” is recommended for this patient as the Holstein Lewis fracture is commonly associated with radial nerve injury. 

Holstein-Lewis fracture is a spiral fracture at the middle and distal third junction of the humerus. Radial nerve injury at this junction can lead to paralysis of all the muscles supplied by the radial nerve except the triceps and anconeus. The patient presents with an inability to extend wrist and fingers (wrist drop and finger drop). 

Other options:

Option 2: It corresponds to a knuckle bender splint used in the management of ulnar nerve palsy.

Option 3: It corresponds to an aeroplane splint used for brachial plexus injury. 

Option 4: It corresponds to a Volkmann's splint which is used for the management of mild cases of Volkmann’s ischemic contracture

questions.text: Which of the following are glycoprotein projections found on the surface of the virus?
questions.solution:
The peplomers are glycoprotein projections found on the surface of the viral envelope.

Structure of a virus has the following:

  • Nucleocapsid: The capsid with enclosed nucleic acid is known as Nucleocapsid.
  • Envelope: A lipid-containing membrane that surrounds some virus particles. It is acquired during viral maturation by a budding process through a cellular membrane.
  • Tegument: Proteinaceous structure present between the envelope and capsid.

Note: Coronaviruses are a group of spherical or pleomorphic enveloped RNA viruses having club or petal-shaped peplomers. Coronaviruses are named for the crown-like spikes on their surface.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen as a side effect of lithium therapy?
questions.solution:
Dry mouth and not sialorrhea, is a known side effect of lithium therapy.

Known significant side effects of lithium therapy include

  • Polyuria-polydipsia 
  • Dry mouth 
  • Leukocytosis 
  • Headache
  • Hand tremors
  • Confusion 
  • Decreased memory
  • Muscle weakness
  • Hyperreflexia 
  • Muscle twitch 
  • Vertigo 
  • ECG changes
  • Nausea & vomiting
  • Diarrhea 

 

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text:
Correctly match the disease with its pathophysiology:
DISEASE MECHANISM
1. Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome a. Increased destruction of platelets
2. Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia b. Decreased platelet aggregation
3. Glanzmann’s Thrombasthenia c. Decreased platelet production
4. Bernard Soulier Syndrome d. Decreased platelet adhesion
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is: 1-c; 2-a; 3-b; 4-d (option A).

DISEASE MECHANISM
1. Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome c. Decreased platelet production 
2. Heparin induced thrombocytopenia a. Increased destruction of platelets 
3. Glanzmann’s Thrombasthenia b. Decreased platelet aggregation
4. Bernard Soulier Syndrome d. Decreased platelet adhesion


Bernard Soulier Syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder due to an inherited deficiency of platelet membrane glycoprotein complex Ib-IX. This glycoprotein is a receptor of the von Willebrand factor, which is needed for normal platelet adhesion to the subendothelial extracellular matrix.

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive platelet disorder that results from a deficiency of the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa complex.

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome(WAS) is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder. It is caused by mutations in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASp) that primarily affects the T lymphocytes.it  is characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and a marked vulnerability to recurrent infection, resulting in early death.

Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is a life-threatening complication of exposure to heparin (ie,unfractionated heparin, low molecular weight [LMW] heparin).HIT results from an autoantibody directed against endogenous platelet factor 4 (PF4) in complex with heparin. This antibody activates platelets and can cause catastrophic arterial and venous thrombosis with a mortality rate as high as 20 percent.

Related Pearl: Platelet disorders

Finding

Bernard–Soulier syndrome

Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia

von Willebrand Disease
 Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Autosomal recessive

 Most common (type 1): Autosomal dominant
 Defect

Absence of Gp Ib-IX-V receptor

 Absence of Gp IIb/IIIa receptor

Type 1: Partial quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (VWF)

Type 2: Qualitative defect of VWF

Type 3: Complete quantitative deficiency of VWF 
 Mechanism

Lack of Gp Ib-IX-V prevents platelet adhesion to VWF

 

Platelets cannot aggregate as Gp IIb/IIIa normally binds fibrinogen and forms bridges between platelets 

There are 2 mechanisms:

Platelet adhesion defect - due to absent vWF that normally binds to GPIB-IX and collagen in the subendothelium

Factor VIII deficiency as vWF usually prevents its degradation
Platelet count  Normal platelet count/ mild thrombocytopenia  Normal Normal (except in type 2B- thrombocytopenia)
Platelet morphology Large platelets/ megathrombocytes with dense granules Normal  Normal/ large
Bleeding time

Prolonged

 Prolonged  Prolonged
Platelet aggregation tests (collagen, ADP, thrombin) Normal Abnormal  Normal
Ristocetin aggregation test

Abnormal (platelets does not aggregate)

Does not normalize after addition of normal serum

Normal

(aggregation of platelets)

 Abnormal, Normalizes after addition of normal serum
VWF factor levels Normal Normal  Decreased
PT/PTT Normal Normal  PT normal, aPTT prolonged

Related Pearl: Differences between Bleeding Disorders and Coagulation disorders

Superficial ecchymosis Small and Multiple Large and Solitary
Bleeding from superficial cuts  Profuse Minimal persistent
Hemarthrosis Rare Characteristic (most common-knee)

Inherited: Hemophilia A

VWD: von Willebrand disease

questions.text: A patient has profuse rhinorrhea and sneezing. He was prescribed fexofenadine. Which of the following is false regarding this drug?

choices.text: It is an active metabolite of terfenadine
It is a second-generation H1 receptor antagonists

questions.solution:
Fexofenadine is the active metabolite of terfenadine and it lacks serious side effects like torsade de Pointes of its parent molecule. 

Torsade de pointes occurs due to the inhibition of delayed rectifier K+ channels in the heart at elevated concentrations. Fexofenadine has a low propensity of blocking delayed rectifier K+ channels and does not lead to prolongation of the QTc interval.

H1 antagonists are divided into first-generation and second-generation drugs.

First-generation antihistamines are lipophilic and cross the blood-brain barrier easily and should not be prescribed to drivers and heavy machine workers and pilots because they can cause sedation. They include:

  • Carbinoxamine
  • Diphenhydramine
  • Dimenhydrinate
  • Promethazine
  • Hydroxyzine
  • Chlorpheniramine
  • Cyproheptadine

Second-generation antihistamines are less sedative because of less central nervous system penetration and do not block autonomic receptors. They include:

  • Fexofenadine
  • Loratadine
  • Desloratadine
  • Cetirizine, Levocetirizine

Important uses of H1 receptor blockers:

  • Allergic rhinitis and urticaria- They block histamine-mediated actions
  • Antinausea and antiemetics- scopolamine and dimenhydrinate are used in the treatment of motion sickness. Doxylamine is used in the treatment of vomiting in pregnancy.
  • Antiparkinsonism- Diphenhydramine can be used to suppress extrapyramidal symptoms caused due to antipsychotic medications

Adverse effects

  • Sedation
  • Antimuscarinic action- dry mouth and respiratory passages, urinary retention or frequency

questions.text: Which of the following blood vessels is present in the hepatic fissure that corresponds to Cantlie’s line?
questions.solution:
The main portal fissure corresponds to the Cantlie’s line, and it contains the middle hepatic vein.

The Cantlie line is an imaginary line that extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver back to the midpoint of the inferior venacava (IVC). It anatomically divides the liver into the right and left halves. The clinical significance of this line is that it separates the left and right lobes of the liver. It is useful during a right or a left hepatectomy to determine the line of transection.

The liver has 3 major fissures which are:

  • The main portal fissure, corresponding to Cantlie's line divides the liver into right and left hemi-livers. It contains the middle hepatic vein.
  • The left portal fissure divides the left hemi-liver into medial (anterior) and lateral (posterior) segments. It contains the left hepatic vein. (Option B)
  • The right portal fissure divides the right hemi-liver into medial( anterior) and lateral (posterior) segments. It contains the right hepatic vein. (Option C)

Couinaud's classification is a functional classification which divides the liver into 4 sectors based on supply by portal venous branches (Option D). It is summarized in the pearl below.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text:
Which of the following does not occur as the blood passes through muscle tissue capillaries?

Hb: Hemoglobin

choices.text: Left shift of Hb:O2 dissociation curve

questions.solution:
As the blood passes through the capillaries, there is a right shift of the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve (not left).

Gaseous and nutrient exchange occur between the capillaries and the tissues. At the tissue level, this leads to higher concentration of CO2, less concentration of oxygen, and lower pH (option D). This higher CO2 concentration and lower pH shifts the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve to the right. This in turn reduces the affinity of hemoglobin towards oxygen and thereby releases more oxygen to the tissue to facilitate gas exchange.

Other options:

Options A and C: As blood passes through systemic capillaries , there is net pressure towards the adjacent tissues leading to absorption of water and in return toxins are returned to the capillaries leading to increased protein content and increased hematocrit.

questions.text:
According to Gurd's criteria, which of the following are the major criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome?

1. Petechial rash
2. Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
3. Fat globules in sputum
4. Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes
5. Central nervous system depression
questions.solution:
The major criteria in Gurd’s criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome include petechial rash, respiratory insufficiency, and central nervous system depression. 

At least one major and four minor criteria are required to diagnose fat embolism syndrome. Fat embolism syndrome occurs due to the embolism of fat globules from bone marrow into systemic circulation within 12 to 72 hours following a traumatic skeletal injury. Management is mainly supportive. 

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Petechial rash
  • Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes
  • CNS depression.

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia
  • Pyrexia
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)
  • Acute thrombocytopenia
  • Acute decrease in hemoglobin
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: A 10-month-old baby who accidentally put a tiny plastic ball in his mouth suddenly developed a violent cough, wheezing, and dyspnea. The baby is conscious and while you attempted back slaps on the baby, he lost consciousness. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Continue back slap till foreign body dislodges

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of cough, wheezing and dyspnea following accidental ingestion of a plastic piece is suggestive of a foreign body airway obstruction(choking). As the child becomes unconscious after giving back slaps, the next step is to perform chest compressions.

Back slaps are given by placing the infant's torso on the rescuer's nondominant arm or draping an older child across the knees. They are given between the shoulder blades using the heel of the rescuer’s hand. In the case of choking, 5 back slaps and 5 chest thrusts are given alternatively.

Chest thrusts are given by putting the patient supine, and the rescuer should kneel close to the victim’s side. Hands are placed in the same manner as is done to perform CPR chest compressions. Each thrust is given in such a way as to relieve the obstruction. 

The images below depict back slaps and chest thrusts respectively.

 

If the child becomes unresponsive after performing back slaps and chest thrusts, then chest compressions should be started immediately after stopping back slaps and chest thrusts(option D).

Other options

Option A: Heimlich manoeuvre is contraindicated in children less than 1 year.

Option C: While performing back slaps if the child becomes unresponsive it is not advised to perform rescue breaths. An attempt to provide two rescue breaths can be provided after the healthcare provider provides 30 compressions with reassessment of the airway.

questions.text:
Match the following drugs with their corresponding teratogenic effects:
1. Fluconazole A. Strabismus
2. Carbamazepine B. Craniosynostosis
3. Androgen C. Spina bifida
4. Misoprostol D. Labial fusion
questions.solution:
Corret option is 1-B, 2-C, 3-D, 4-A.

1. Fluconazole B. Craniosynostosis
2. Carbamazepine C. Spina bifida
3. Androgen D. Labial fusion
4. Misoprostol A. Strabismus

Fluconazole has been known to cause a syndrome known as Antley-Bixler syndrome which is characterized by craniosynostosis, midface hypoplasia, and trapezoidocephaly.

Carbamazepine is known to cause spina bifida and neurodevelopmental delay.

Androgens in female fetuses can cause clitoromegaly or labial fusion.

Misoprostol in the first trimester can lead to Mobius syndrome in babies which is characterized by convergence of eyes, facial paralysis, abnormalities of digits but normal intelligence.

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Hypoplasia of organs, anuria, irreversible renal failure
Carbimazole and Methimazole

questions.text: Which of the following mutations is seen in Zellweger syndrome ?
questions.solution:
The mutation seen in Zellweger syndrome is in the PEX family of genes. 

It is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. The affected child presents with dysmorphic facial features, weakness, hypotonia, neonatal seizures and eye abnormalities. The production of bile acids, alpha-oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids, beta-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA), catabolism of amino acids and ethanol, and plasmalogen formation are all carried out by peroxisomes. PEX gene mutation will cause defective synthesis of peroxisomes.

Since there are defective peroxisomes, biochemical findings will show the accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids and phytanic acid, abnormalities in the synthesis of bile acids, and a marked reduction of plasmalogens. There is no appropriate treatment for Zellweger syndrome. It is very severe and infants mostly die within a year.

Other options :

Option A: Mutation in ABCA1 gene leads to reduced HDL levels called as Tangier’s disease.Enlarged orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Clinical features of Tangier disease include hyperplastic yellow-orange tonsils, hepatosplenomegaly, and peripheral neuropathy.

Option C: Mutation in ATP7A gene leads to Menkes disease, a rare X-linked recessive progressive multisystemic disease of copper metabolism. In this condition, dietary copper is absorbed from the GI tract but it cannot be transported to blood due to the absence of an intracellular copper binding ATPase.This condition shows kinky colorless, and sparse hair with truncal hypotonia on examination.

Option D : Mutation in the COL1A and COL2A genes leads to Osteogenesis imperfecta, also called brittle bone disease. It is an autosomal dominant disorder. Mutations lead to the replacement of glycine amino acid with another amino acid resulting in an abnormal triple helix of collagen. This results in the abnormal formation of type 1 collagen.

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female patient with multiple painful blisters on the forearms, trunk, and mouth is suspected to have pemphigus vulgaris. Which of the following are helpful in the diagnosis of this condition?
  1. Diascopy
  2. KOH mount microscopy
  3. Direct immunofluorescence
  4. Tzanck smear
  5. Patch testing
questions.solution:
Direct immunofluorescence and Tzanck smear (3 and 4) are helpful in the diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris. 

The diagnostic and most accurate investigation for pemphigus vulgaris is direct immunofluorescence microscopy which shows a characteristic fishnet appearance due to intraepidermal intercellular deposition of IgG and C3.

Tzanck smear is done by opening an intact blister and scraping material from the base of the ulcer formed. It is then smeared onto a microscopic slide, air-dried, and stained with Giemsa stain. The presence of acantholytic cells in cytology is indicative of pemphigus vulgaris, but is not specific.

Pemphigus is a group of immunobullous disorders that are characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins, desmoglein 1 and desmoglein 3.

Clinically, it presents with multiple flaccid bullae over oral mucosa. The disease then progresses to involve the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back. The blisters are filled with clear fluid which may become turbid and rupture to form erosions. The Nikolsky sign is positive at this stage. It refers to the separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis, producing an erosion when firm sliding pressure is applied.

Histopathology shows suprabasal clefts and blisters, acantholysis and a row of tombstone appearance.

Topical steroids, oral prednisolone, and oral azathioprine are used for the treatment depending on the severity of the disease.

The image below shows the presence of acantholytic cells on the Tzanck smear seen in pemphigus -

 

The image below shows the characteristic fish net appearance seen in pemphigus on DIF-

Other statements:

Statement 1- Diascopy is a method of assessing superficial erythema, where a glass slide is pressed against the skin. Indications include telangiectasia, petechiae and purpura, and granulomatous nodules like sarcoidosis and lupus vulgaris.

Statement 2- KOH mount microscopy permits visualization of the hyphae and spores of dermatophytes or other fungal infections.

Statement 5- Patch testing is a test of cell-mediated immunity, to determine whether a patient has a contact sensitivity to a given allergen.

Related Pearl: Tzanck Smear in Dermatology

The Tzanck smear, introduced by the Frenchman Tzanck, is a simple to perform, inexpensive bed side cytological test that aids in the diagnosis of vesicular, pustular and bullous diseases, in particular herpes.

The sensitivity of the Tzanck smear exceeds 80%, and the specificity 90% when the investigators are experienced.

Preparation of Tzanck smear:

  • Viral infections and Blistering disorders - fresh vesicle or intact blister is de-roofed and base is scraped 
  • Suspected tumors - any crust should be removed from ulcerated tumors, and non-ulcerated tumors should be incised with a sharp, pointed scalpel and sample is then obtained with either a blunt scalpel or a small curette
  • The smear should preferably be fixed immediately using Formol-Zenker solution since significant artifacts can result from drying.
  • Tzanck smear can be stained by a variety of methods, most commonly by Giemsa stain. Other stains used are hematoxylin and eosin, Wright, methylene blue, Papanicolaou and toluidine blue. 

Results in Tzanck Smear:

A typical Tzanck cell is a large round keratinocyte with a hypertrophic nucleus, hazy or absent nucleoli, and abundant basophilic cytoplasm. The basophilic staining is deeper peripherally on the cell membrane ("mourning edged" cells) due to the cytoplasm's tendency to get condensed at the periphery, leading to a perinuclear halo.

Immunobullous Disorders 
Pemphigus Vulgaris Multiple acantholytic cells (Tzanck cells)
Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) Dyskeratotic acantholytic cells with very few inflammatory cells
Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis(TEN) Necrotizing or degenerating basal cells with scattered inflammatory cells and fibroblasts 
Bullous pemphigoid (BP), Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and erosive lichen planus No acantholytic cells ; Many leucocytes
Cutaneous Infections 
Herpes simplex, varicella, herpes zoster Ballooning degeneration and multinucleated giant cells are seen
Molluscum contagiosum Diagnostic intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson-Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies (30-35 microns)
Vaccinia, orf, milker's nodules and variola Acantholytic squamous keratinocytes , eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion called a "Guarnieri body"
 Leishmaniasis Leishman-Donovan (LD) bodiesgrouped together in a typical "swarm of bees" fashion, within large macrophages (Wright's cells)
Bullous Impetigo Dyskeratotic acantholytic cells with abundant neutrophils and clusters of coccoid bacteria
Genodermatoses 
Hailey-Hailey disease Multiple acantholytic cells; Direct Immunofluorescence Negative
Darier's Disease "Corps ronds" are isolated keratinocytes with a round shape and an acidophilic cytoplasm. The corps grains are seen as small, hyaline, acidophilic ovoid bodies resembling pomegranate seeds.
Cutaneous Tumours 
Squamous Cell Carcinoma Atypical Squamous Cells
Basal Cell Carcinoma Clusters of Basaloid cells

 

Image : Tzanck smear , showing three multinucleated giant cells in center.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child was brought to the ER by her mother after filing a complaint with the police about an alleged incidence of sexual violence against her daughter two days earlier.  You being the registered medical practitioner should perform all of the following, except?

choices.text: Request a legal document before rendering care
Address cuts or bruises on the arm

questions.solution:
The registered medical practitioner should perform all of the following, except obtaining a legal mandate before providing care

According to the Indian Penal Code and the POSCO Act 2012, no medical practitioner shall demand any legal mandate as a prerequisite to rendering medical care.

Medical practitioners shall attend to the following needs of the child:

  • Management of cuts or bruises or any other injuries including genital injuries.
  • Prophylaxis and treatment of STDs and HIV
  • Psychiatry consultation if deemed necessary
  • Emergency contraceptives must be discussed with the pubertal child

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory investigation findings is unlikely to be seen in a patient with hemolytic anemia?
questions.solution:
The presence of bilirubin in urine is not seen in hemolytic anemia.

In hemolysis, there is increased production of bilirubin. This leads to an increase in indirect bilirubin in the blood (option A). This results in the increased production of urobilinogen in the intestine which is excreted as fecal urobilinogen (option C). Excess urobilinogen is also reabsorbed into the blood and appears in increased amounts in the urine (option D). The increased levels of urine urobilinogen and the absence of urine bilirubin are characteristic of hemolytic jaundice.

Obstructive jaundice has the following features:

  • Increased serum direct bilirubin: Due to obstruction in the biliary tree, the bilirubin conjugates diffuse into the blood, causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • Increased urine bilirubin: Being water-soluble, conjugated bilirubin appears in the urine in excess amounts.
  • Absent urobilinogen: In complete obstruction of the CBD, conjugated bilirubin cannot enter the intestine and be metabolized by the intestinal flora. Hence, urobilinogen is not formed and is absent in the urine.

 

Related Pearl: Types of Jaundice

Type of jaundice Serum bilirubin Urine Urobilinogen Urine bilirubin
Pre-hepatic ↑ Indirect          ↑        -
Hepatic ↑ Direct and indirect   Normal/ ↓       +/-
Post-hepatic ↑ Direct          -        +

questions.text: You are in a daycare center and you observe a child scribbling on a pad and building a tower of 3 blocks. However, he was not able to build a tower of 6 blocks. The age of this child is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
The most likely age of this child is 18 months as scribbling on a pad and building a tower of 3 blocks are fine motor skills achieved at the age of 18 months.

The milestones attained by a child at the age of 18 months are:

  • Gross motor development: Running
  • Fine motor development: Scribbling and building a tower of 3 blocks
  • Social and adaptive:  Copying parents in the task
  • Language: 8 to 10-word vocabulary

Other options:

Fine motor milestones achieved at the age of:

  • 1 year/12 months  - mature pincer grasp. (Option C)
  • 2 years - building a tower of 6 blocks. (Option A)
  • 3 years - building a tower of 9 blocks and copying a circle. (Option B)

questions.text: Which of the following parameters can be determined by the diatom test?

choices.text: Intoxication at the time of drowning

questions.solution:
The diatom test can differentiate between antemortem and postmortem drowning.

Diatoms are a class of microscopic unicellular algae found suspended in most natural waters. Their cell walls are thick and pigmented, resisting decomposition, and hence they can be detected even after death. Diatoms enter the pulmonary circulation during drowning. Only a live person's body with circulation could transport diatoms from the lungs to the brain, bone marrow, liver and other viscera, and skeletal muscle, which would not occur in a dead body, hence the test is useful in differentiating between antemortem and postmortem drowning. The diatom test should currently be utilized as a suggestive tool, not as definitive legal evidence of drowning. Soft-bodied protozoa and crustaceans are now being suggested as alternative indicators for drowning.

The diatom test should be used only as an indicative aid and not as legal proof of drowning.

Other options: 

Option B: Diatoms have also been found in putrified bodies due to their high refractiveness to stress and does not help in determining the degree of putrefaction in dead bodies.

Option C: Duration of drowning is not determined by diatom test, but based on the visible postmortem changes after considering the circumstantial history and environmental conditions.

Option D: Poisoning is ruled out by toxicological assays on organ specimens, and not by the diatom test.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between Antemortem amd Postmortem drowning

Feature        Antemortem drowning       Postmortem drowning
Froth/ foam at nostrils or mouth Present Absent
Cadaveric spasm Present Absent
Lungs

Emphysema aquosum

Edema aquosum(seen in unconscious) 

Lungs are voluminous, bulky, water-logged and over-inflated

 

Passive collection of water in the lungs
Presence of foreign bodies (fluid, debris, weeds, vegetation, etc) Present in bronchi and bronchioles Passively collected only in upper respiratory passage
Demonstration of diatoms  Present in the lungs, liver, brain, bone marrow, etc.

Present only in the lungs

Not spread to distant organs because of absence of circulation
Stomach contents 

Water

Foreign material like sand, weed, dirt etc  (swallowed while struggling for life)

Water (lesser quantity)

questions.text:
After an RTA, a patient's blood pressure (BP) was 80/40 mmHg. After receiving 2L of normal saline, the patient’s BP in the emergency room is 110/70 with a pulse rate of 100/min. The patient has left quadrant tenderness and FAST shows perisplenic fluid. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

RTA: Road traffic accident; FAST: Focused Assessment of Sonography in Trauma; CECT: Contrast Enhanced Computed Tomography; ICU: Intensive Care Unit
questions.solution:
The presence of perisplenic fluid in a case of blunt trauma to the abdomen is suggestive of splenic trauma. In all hemodynamically stable patients, CECT is the investigation of choice and should be performed next for identifying concomitant injuries and characterizing splenic injuries.

In hemodynamically unstable patients not responding to fluid resuscitation focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) is done to assess for free fluid. If perisplenic free fluid is detected these patients are usually taken to the operating room for immediate exploratory laparotomy.

The spleen is the most commonly injured organ in blunt trauma to the abdomen. The severity of splenic injury is graded by the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) spleen injury scale. The management is based on hemodynamic stability and the grade of the injury:

  • Grade I and Grade II injuries: Usually, patients remain hemodynamically stable so they can be managed nonoperatively. It includes adequate bed rest, serial abdominal CECT, and monitoring of vitals. For any shift to a high-grade injury, angioembolization can be done. If the angioembolization fails, a spleen-sparing technique called splenorrhaphy can be done.
  • Grade III injury: If they are hemodynamically stable, they are usually managed conservatively (similar to grades I and II) while surgical management is preferred for hemodynamically unstable patients.
  • Grade IV and V injuries: Usually present with hemodynamic instability and splenectomy may be performed. In selected cases with hemodynamic stability, a trial of non-operative management may be given on a case-to-case basis.

Other options:

Option A: Admission to ICU and observation is indicated for stable patients after assessing the grades of splenic injury. A CECT scan would be required to classify the grade of injury and therefore would take precedence over ICU admission.

Option B: Immediate exploratory laparotomy would be indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients not responding to fluid resuscitation.

Option D: Diagnostic laparoscopy is not indicated in blunt trauma to the abdomen. 

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation for diagnosis of the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a chocolate cyst of the ovary which is classical in endometriosis. Diagnostic laparoscopy is the gold standard in the diagnosis of endometriosis. 

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. The patient usually presents with symptoms of abdominal pain, dyspareunia, dysmenorrhea, and infertility. It is an estrogen-dependent disease of the childbearing age group. The most common site of occurrence is the ovary followed by the pouch of Douglas.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis is visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation. Role of laparoscopy in endometriosis includes detection of pelvic endometriosis; location of the site of endometriosis and its staging, biopsy for histopathological confirmation and surgical treatment by ablation and / or removal.

Other investigations in endometriosis include:

  • CA-125 levels : Raised (Option D)
  • Monocyte chemotactic protein (MCP-1) levels : Raised
  • Transvaginal ultrasound: Echo-free cysts or pelvic mass (Option C)
  • Colour doppler: Increased blood flow
  • Anti-endometrial antibodies 

Other option (s):

Option A: Pituitary-ovarian axis disruption has been identified as affecting feedback pathways thereby limiting normal cyclic changes in the ovary in patients with endometriosis. Endometriosis causes the follicular phase to last longer. It deranges the LH and FSH values leading to variable ratio of the same.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: You are performing a postmortem as a resident and you see black postmortem lividity. Poisoning through which of the following substances will you suspect?
questions.solution:
Black/ grayish postmortem lividity is seen in case of opium poisoning.
