questions.text: Which of the following receptor actions of the drug best describes the rationale for adding epinephrine in cardiopulmonary resuscitation?

choices.text: β2 receptor−mediated increase in cardiac contractility
α1 receptor−mediated increase in renin secretion

questions.solution:
The main effects of epinephrine in cardiac arrest are related to its α1 receptor mediated peripheral vasoconstriction resulting in redistribution of blood flow to the brain.

Additionally β1 mediated increase in cardiac contractility may also exert beneficial effects.

The other options incorrectly match the receptor and its functions.

Other options:

Option B: β1 receptor - mediates an increase in cardiac contractility and results in an increase in renin secretion

Option C: β2 receptor - leads to vasodilation

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman has a history of recurrent second-trimester pregnancy loss. Ultrasound at 13 weeks reveals a cervical length of 1.9 cm. Which of the following is the preferred management for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of recurrent second-trimester pregnancy loss and a cervical length of 1.9cm (normal 2.5cm) has cervical insufficiency, a structural weakness of the cervix that predisposes to second-trimester pregnancy loss. Patients with history-based cervical insufficiency are treated with prophylactic cerclage.

Cervical insufficiency is an important cause of mid-trimester or 2nd-trimester pregnancy loss as a result of preterm labor. Cervical length screening by transvaginal ultrasound is now recommended every 2 weeks in women with a previous history of preterm birth between 16 and 24 weeks gestation. If cervical length is 25-29mm, then weekly screening may be required. For length <25mm, cerclage is offered as a treatment choice. Prophylactic cerclage before dilatation is preferred and is done between 12 and 14 weeks of gestation. Rescue or emergency cerclage is done when there is bulging or prolapse of membranes through a dilated cervix.

Shirodkar and McDonald's methods of cervical cerclage are the commonly performed procedures during pregnancy. In McDonald's method, a non-absorbable (mersilene) suture material is placed as a purse-string suture at the level of the internal os. Below is an image showing McDonald's method of cerclage.

In the Shirodkar method, non-absorbable (mersilene) tape is used. Removal of cerclage should be done at the 37th week of gestation. Below is an image showing Shirodkar's method of cerclage.

Other options : 

Option A) Rescue cerclage is done in emergency settings, when cervical incompetence is recognized in women with threatened preterm labor

Option C) In women with no prior history of preterm birth and incidentally found short cervix, progesterone therapy is preferred over cerclage. 

Option D) Pessaries were once recommended to decrease tension on the cervix from the growing uterus; however, they do not improve obstetric outcomes (ie, no decrease in preterm delivery rates) and therefore are no longer used for management of cervical insufficiency.

questions.text: An elderly multiparous postmenopausal woman presents with involuntary leakage of urine only while laughing or sneezing. Urine analysis is normal and post-void residual urine quantity is 30mL. What is the most likely reason for this incontinence?

choices.text: Abnormal communication between bladder and vagina

questions.solution:
The given clinical history of urinary incontinence on laughing or sneezing, in a multiparous female in a post-menopausal age group is suggestive of genuine stress incontinence (GSI). lt is typical of anatomical changes in the urinary tract such as hypermobility of urethra.

Urinary incontinence may be stress incontinence, urge incontinence or true incontinence. GSI is defined as a small involuntary leakage of urine with increased abdominal pressure in the absence of detrusor contraction. It occurs when the bladder pressure exceeds urethral pressure during physical stress. The usual etiological factor is hypermobility of urethra (~80% cases). The other causes include loss of posterior urethral angle or sphincter dysfunction.

Risk factors include age and menopause  (due to estrogen deficiency), multiparity (due to loss of pelvic muscle tone), obesity, smoking, constipation, chronic cough, pelvic organ prolapse, pregnancy (due to the effect of progesterone and pressure of the gravid uterus on the bladder neck), puerperium (due to descent of the bladder neck, loss of urethro-vesical angle, and reduced pelvic muscle tone) and surgical repair of vesicovaginal fistula.

Investigations are only done prior to surgery to confirm the diagnosis. They include the stress test, cotton swab or Q tip test, Marshall and Bonney’s test, urethroscopy, and urodynamic studies. These are not required prior to conservative management.

Other options:

Options A, and B: Detrusor muscle instability, and increased alpha-adrenergic activity are seen in urge incontinence. Urge incontinence is the involuntary escape of a large amount of urine following a desire to pass urine and can be differentiated from GSI based on clinical history.  

Option C: Vesicovaginal fistula is an example of true incontinence. There is an abnormal communication between the urinary bladder and vagina such a case.

questions.text:
Which of the following changes will be observed when phenytoin is added to the drug regimen of a patient who is on treatment with tiagabine for focal seizures?

AUC - Area under the curve
questions.solution:
Phenytoin is a CYP450 enzyme inducer that leads to increased metabolism of tiagabine and a decrease in the plasma levels of this drug. This reduced bioavailability results in a decreased AUC.

Different inducers are relatively selective for certain cytochrome P-450 isoenzyme families, e.g.: 

  • Anticonvulsants (phenobarbitone, phenytoin, carbamazepine), rifampin, and glucocorticoids induce CYP3A isoenzymes.
  • Phenobarbitone and rifampin also induce CYP2D6 and CYP2C8/9.
  • Carbamazepine and rifampin, in addition, induce CYP2C19 and CYP1A1/2.
  • Isoniazid and chronic alcohol consumption induce CYP2E1.
  • Other enzyme inducers are chronic alcoholism, nevirapine, griseofulvin, and DDT.

Important drugs that inhibit CYP450 isoenzyme are: 

  • Macrolide antibiotics
  • Azole antifungals
  • Chloramphenicol
  • Omeprazole
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)
  • HIV protease inhibitors
  • Cimetidine
  • Ciprofloxacin
  • Metronidazole

The rate and extent of absorption of a drug from dosage form administered by any route refer to the bioavailability of a drug. 

Bioavailability is determined by the concentration-time curve in blood or by its excretion in urine. The area under the blood concentration-time curve (AUC) is proportional to the dose and the extent of bioavailability of a drug. 

Bioavailability is defined as the fraction of unchanged drug that reaches systemic circulation. It can be represented by the formula: 

Bioavailability(F) = Quantity of drug reaching systemic circulation/ Quantity of drug administered. 

Bioavailability depends on two factors ie, Absorption and 1st pass metabolism 

The area under the plot of plasma concentration of a drug versus time after dosage is called the area under the curve or AUC. It can be used as a measure of the bioavailability of a drug and to calculate its clearance rate from the body. The image given below shows the AUC (bioavailability) in a plasma concentration-time curve:

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with complaints of right knee pain and swelling after a dashboard injury in a road traffic accident. Examination shows a swollen and tender knee. A large effusion is seen on X-ray, with no fractures or dislocations. Which of the following ligaments is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Following a dashboard injury the most likely ligament to have injured is the posterior cruciate ligament. 

During a dashboard injury, the strong force on the anterior aspect of the tibia causes posterior translation of the tibia with respect to the femur, which results in posterior cruciate ligament injury.

The patient usually presents with a swollen and tender knee with hemarthrosis. The posterior drawer test to identify the posterior cruciate ligament tear is difficult to perform because of the pain and swelling. X-ray of the knee shows effusion. The posterior cruciate ligament injury can be definitively diagnosed with MRI as shown below.

Dashboard injury can lead to 

  • Posterior hip dislocation
  • Patellar fracture
  • Fracture neck of femur
  • Acetabular fracture
  • Shaft of femur fracture
  • Posterior cruciate ligament injury

Other options:

Option a : A posteriorly directed force on the anterior aspect of the tibia is unlikely to cause an anterior cruciate ligament injury.

Options c : Medial collateral ligament injury occurs due to stress on the lateral knee during sports (valgus stress injury).

Option d : Lateral collateral ligament injury occurs due to stress on the medial aspect of the knee (varus stress injury).

Related Pearl: Mechanism of injury and tests for knee injuries

Structures Mechanism of injury Tests
Menisci Rotational force

McMurray test

Apley's grinding test

Squat test

Thessaly test
Medial collateral ligament Valgus force Valgus stress test
Lateral collateral ligament Varus force Varus stress test
Anterior cruciate ligament Anterior tibial displacement

Anterior drawer test 

Lachman test

Pivot shift test
Posterior cruciate ligament Posterior tibial displacement

Posterior drawer test

Sag sign

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy with developmental delay and seizures was diagnosed with Lennox Gastaut syndrome. On performing an EEG, which of the following is not a typical EEG finding that you would expect to see?
questions.solution:
Hypsarrythmia is seen in West syndrome.

EEG in Lennox Gastaut syndrome shows 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep with a slow background in wakefulness.

  • It typically starts between the age of 2 and 10 years
  • Consists of a triad of developmental delay, multiple seizures, and EEG findings 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep.
  • Patients will have long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies.
Disease Typical EEG feature
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome
  • 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves
  • polyspike bursts in sleep
  • slow background in wakefulness
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike
West syndrome Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)

questions.text: An ophthalmology resident while performing a Purkinje image test of the normal eye notices an inverted Purkinje image. Which of the following surface is responsible for an inverted image?
questions.solution:
The posterior surface of the lens is responsible for the inverted Purkinje image (Image 4).

Purkinje images are reflections of objects from the structure of the eye. They are also known as Purkinje reflexes or as Purkinje–Sanson images.

  • Image 1—Anterior surface of the cornea: Erect
  • Image 2—Posterior surface of the cornea: Erect
  • Image 3—Anterior surface of the lens: Erect
  • Image 4—Posterior surface of the lens: Inverted
  • In aphakia: Image 3 and Image 4 are absent.
  • In mature cataract: Image 4 is absent.

questions.text: Which of the following surgeries for rectal prolapse is done via the perineal approach?
questions.solution:
The Altemeier procedure is done for rectal prolapse via the perineal approach.

Rectal prolapse occurs when a mucosal or full-thickness layer of rectal tissue protrudes through the anal orifice. Surgical management includes:

Perineal approach-

  • Thiersch operation- a steel wire, silastic, or nylon tape, is placed around the anal canal. Largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defaecation
  • Delorme's operation
  • Altemeier's procedure- involves removal of the prolapsed rectum and associated sigmoid colon, followed by which a coloanal anastomosis is created. It is often complicated by poor bowel control with fecal soiling secondary to the loss of rectal reservoir.

The advantages of a perineal approach include minimal postoperative pain, early mobility, and low levels of morbidity. However, given the higher recurrence rates, it is best reserved for patients at a higher risk of developing complications post major surgeries.

Abdominal procedures:

  • Sutured rectopexy
  • Posterior mesh rectopexy (modified Ripstein operation) (Option C)
  • Laparoscopic ventral mesh rectopexy (Option B)
  • Resection rectopexy (Option A)

The principle of all abdominal operations for rectal prolapse is to fix the rectum in its normal anatomical position.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy born to an HIV-positive mother is brought to the clinic with the findings shown in the image below. Which other condition can this child develop in the clinical stage that he is currently in?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of esophageal candidiasis and the image showing Kaposi's sarcoma is suggestive of HIV Stage IV according to the WHO staging of HIV/AIDS in children with confirmed HIV infection. The other condition that can develop in this stage is cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis.

Other Options:

Option A: Persistent parotid enlargement is seen in stage 2. 

Option B: Persistent oral candidiasis is seen in stage 3. 

Option D: Persistent hepatosplenomegaly is seen in stage 2. 

Related Pearl: Clinical stages of HIV in children/ infants

Stage 1

  • Asymptomatic
  • Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy

Stage 2

General-

  • Unexplained persistent hepatosplenomegaly
  • Recurrent or chronic upper respiratory infections (otitis media, otorrhoea, sinusitis, tonsilitis)
  • Fungal nail infections

Oral-

  • Recurrent oral ulcerations
  • Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement
  • Linear gingival erythema

Skin- 

  • Papular pruritic eruptions
  • Extensive wart virus infection
  • Extensive molluscum contagiosum
  • Herpes zoster

Stage 3

General-

  • Unexplained moderate malnutrition not adequately responding to standard therapy
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea (14 days or more)
  • Unexplained persistent fever (above 37.6 °C intermittent or constant, for longer than one month)
  • Unexplained anemia (<8 g/dL), neutropenia (<0.5 x 109/L) or chronic thrombocytopenia (<50 × 109/L)

Oral-

  • Persistent oral candidiasis (after first 6-8 weeks of life)
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia
  • Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis/periodontitis

Respiratory-

  • Pulmonary TB/ Lymph node TB
  • Severe recurrent bacterial pneumonia
  • Symptomatic lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis
  • Chronic HIV-associated lung disease including bronchiectasis

Stage 4

General-

  • Unexplained severe wasting, stunting or malnutrition not responding to standard therapy
  • Chronic herpes simplex infection; (oro-labial or cutaneous of more than one month's duration or visceral at any site)
  • Extrapulmonary TB and disseminated non-tuberculosis mycobacterial infection
  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Oesophageal candidiasis (or candidiasis of trachea, bronchi or lungs)
  • Cytomegalovirus infection; retinitis or CMV infection affecting another organ, with onset at age over 1 month)
  • Disseminated endemic mycosis (extrapulmonary histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis)
  • Chronic cryptosporidiosis and isosporiasis
  • Symptomatic HIV-associated nephropathy or HIV-associated cardiomyopathy

Neurological-

  • Central nervous system toxoplasmosis (after one month of life)
  • HIV encephalopathy
  • Cerebral or B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis (including meningitis)

Respiratory-

  • Pneumocystis pneumonia
  • Recurrent severe bacterial infections (e.g., empyema, pyomyositis, bone or joint infection, meningitis, but excluding pneumonia)

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of excess uncontrollable worry over daily life activities, finances, and his health for the past 2 years. Because of this, he feels restless most of the time. He also complains of fatigue and disturbed sleep. Which of the following screening tools is useful for identifying this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a generalised anxiety disorder(GAD). The GAD-7 scale is used in the assessment of generalized anxiety disorder. 

When assessing for GAD, clinical professionals look for the following according to the DSM-5 (and ICD-11) criteria: 

  • The presence of excessive anxiety and worry about a variety of topics, events, or activities.
  • Worry occurs more often than not for at least six months and is clearly excessive.
  • The worry is experienced as very challenging to control.
  • The worry in both adults and children may easily shift from one topic to another.
  • The anxiety and worry are accompanied by at least three of the following physical or cognitive symptoms (In children, only one of these symptoms is necessary for a diagnosis of GAD):
  • Edginess or restlessness
  • Tiring easily; more fatigued than usual Impaired concentration or feeling as though the mind goes blank
  • Irritability (which may or may not be observable to others)
  • Increased muscle aches or soreness
  • Difficulty sleeping (due to trouble falling asleep or staying asleep, restlessness at night, or unsatisfying sleep)

Other options:

Option A: Patient Health Questionnaire 9 (PHQ-9) is a tool used to assess depressive symptoms in patients with major depressive disorder. 

Option B: CHAT checklist is used in autism (CHecklist for Autism in Toddlers).

Option D: Confusion assessment method (CAM) is a bedside screening test used in the diagnosis of delirium.

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Disorder 
Feature
Panic disorder
1. Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:
  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain
  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms
  • Feeling that something catastrophic is
    about to happen.

2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about an additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

Immediate: Benzodiazepines
Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy
Phobias
Exaggerated anxiety responses that occur
during exposure to relatively innocuous stimuli or situations.
Specific phobias entail phobic responses to
particular stimuli or situations.
Social
anxiety disorder (Social phobia)
Phobic responses to specific social situations.
Generalized anxiety disorder
Excessive worry about
a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.
 
3 or more of the following symptoms:
  • Restlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Treatment:

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line: Benzodiazepines, Buspirone

questions.text:
A 34-year-old female patient on maintenance hemodialysis presents with exertional dyspnoea. Further evaluation reveals that her symptoms are due to a large arteriovenous fistula that was used for the hemodialysis. Which of the following physiologic changes are expected in this patient?

CO - Cardiac output

SVR - Systemic vascular resistance

VR - Venous return
questions.solution:
Correct option is A : CO (Cardiac output) ↑, SVR (systemic vascular resistance)  ↓, VR (Venous return) ↑

A large arteriovenous fistula allows for blood to bypass the resistance of the systemic arterioles leading to a reduced systemic vascular resistance (SVR) i.e decreased afterload. Low peripheral resistance allows blood to quickly return to the heart leading to increased venous return and a high preload. A combination of high preload and low afterload increases the cardiac output.

Excessively large fistulas can lead to high-output heart failure as the left ventricle fails to keep up with the increased venous return.

Few causes of high output cardiac failure include:

  • Pagets disease
  • Acquired or congenital arteriovenous fistula
  • Severe anemia
  • Thiamine deficiency
  • Hyperthyroidism

questions.text:
You are assisting in an exploratory laparotomy. The surgeon asks for a non-absorbable monofilament suture material. Which of the following materials can you give the surgeon?

1. Silk
2. Polypropylene
3. Polydioxanone
4. Polyglycaprone
5. Nylon
questions.solution:
Polypropylene and nylon are non-absorbable monofilament suture materials. 

Other options:

Option A: Silk is a braided non-absorbable suture material used for ligation and suturing when long-term tissue support is necessary. It is also used for securing drains externally and two-layer bowel anastomoses.

Option C: Polydioxanone is an delayed absorbable suture material with a longer wound support period.

Option D: Polygylcaprone (Monocryl) is an absorbable suture material and is used in the subcuticular suturing in the skin. 

Related Pearl: Suture materials

Monofilament

Used in tissues where slightly longer wound support is required

Soft tissue ligation

Gastrointestinal and muscle surgery

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive man presents with chronic watery diarrhea. Oocysts identified in stool microscopy raise suspicion of Cystoisospora belli. Which characteristic of the sporulated oocyst confirms the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
2 sporocysts with 4 sporozoites each accurately describes the key diagnostic feature of Cystoisospora oocysts.

The presence of two sporocysts, each containing four sporozoites (a total of eight sporozoites), is highly specific to Cystoisospora and helps differentiate it from other diarrheal parasites.

The oocyst of Cystoisospora undergoes sporulation of oocysts occurs in the soil, which is the infective stage of the parasite. The immature oocysts identified in stool samples are acid-fast, elongated-ovoid, and contain two sporoblasts. They cause profuse diarrhea in immunocompromised patients.

On maturation, the sporoblasts convert into sporocysts. Each sporocyst contains four crescent-shaped sporozoites. 

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host :

PROPERTY CRYPTOSPORIDIUM CYCLOSPORA CYSTOISOSPORA

Sporulated oocyst

4-6 μm, round,  contains four sporozoites

8-12 μm, round, contains 2 sporocyst each having two sporozoites

23-36 μm, oval, contain two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites.
Acid-fast detection  Uniformly acid-fast Variable acid-fast Uniformly acid-fast
Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside the host cell Occurs in soil Occurs in soil
Diagnostic form Sporulated cyst Unsporulated cyst Unsporulated oocyst

questions.text:
An elderly man presents with acute pancreatitis. The results of the examination and investigations are given below. According to the BISAP scoring system, the presence of which of the following indicates a worse prognosis?

1) Age: 62 years
2) Blood Urea Nitrogen: 27 mg/dL
3) Serum lipase: 500 U/L
4) Hematocrit: 40%
5) Chest x-ray: Left-sided pleural effusion
questions.solution:
This patient with acute pancreatitis has 3 parameters ie an age > 60 , BUN> 25mg/dl and chest x-ray showing pleural effusion which are indicative of poor prognosis according to the BISAP score.

The severity of acute pancreatitis is determined to assist in patient triage. The Bedside Index of Severity in Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP) includes five parameters obtained within the first 24 hours of hospitalization.

These are as follows: 

  • BUN >25 mg/dL
  • Impaired mental status (Glasgow coma scale score <15)
  • SIRS
  • Age >60 years
  • Pleural effusion on radiography

The presence of three or more of these is associated with increased risk of in-hospital mortality among patients with acute pancreatitis. 

Other scoring systems Used for Acute Pancreatitis: 

  • RANSON criteria
  • HAPS (Harmless acute pancreatitis score)
  • Revised Atlanta classification

Other options: 

Statement 3: Serum lipase is not part of the BISAP scoring system

Statement 4: An elevated hematocrit >44% is associated with more severe acute pancreatitis, but is not part of the BISAP scoring system. Also, this patient’s hematocrit is 40%.

Related Pearl: Assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis

  • Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP) includes:
    • Blood urea nitrogen, > 25 mg/dL
    • Impaired mental status, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score <15
    • Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
    • Age > 60 years
    • Pleural effusion
      One point is given for each. BISAP score ≥ 3 indicates severe pancreatitis.
  • Harmless Acute Pancreatitis Score (HAPS)
    If all the following are present then it is considered non-severe, i.e., no death, no need for dialysis, and no need for ventilation:
    • Absence of rebound tenderness or guarding
    • Normal hematocrit
    • Normal serum creatinine

  • Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE II)
    • A score of 8 or more is considered to be severe
    • Can be done at admission and repeated any time
    • Complex, not specific for AP, and based on the patient’s age
  • Ranson’s score
  • Modified Glasgow criteria - 3 or more positive criteria, the disease is considered to be severe
  • Atlanta classification

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient has been seeing his therapist for depression since the death of his wife. By the end of a few sessions, the psychiatrist unconsciously starts developing feelings towards the patient similar to the one he had for his father. Identify the phenomenon.
questions.solution:
The given phenomenon is countertransference. Here in this scenario, the psychiatrist seems to be developing unconscious feelings toward his patient and starts to relate to him as his father.

Countertransference is the positive and negative feelings/emotions expressed by healthcare professionals towards their patients. It is the process of the physician unconsciously displacing onto the patient's patterns of behaviours or emotional reactions as if he/she were a significant figure from earlier in the physician's life.

Other Options:

Option A -  Projection is an immature defense mechanism in which one attributes one’s feelings to others. For example, a person who cheats on his wife says that the wife is probably cheating on him.

Option B - Displacement is the feeling that is connected with one person and is displaced onto another person. For example, a man who has had a bad day at the office comes home and yells at his wife and children, displacing his anger from the workplace onto his family.

Option C - Transference is a situation where the feelings, desires, and expectations of one person are redirected and applied to another person. Most commonly, transference occurs in a therapeutic setting, where a person in therapy unconsciously develops feelings towards the therapist.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with fatigue, chest pain, and exertional breathlessness. On auscultation, an ejection systolic murmur that radiates to the carotids was found. The murmur intensified on squatting. Which of the following will be the character of the pulse in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical scenario is suggestive of aortic stenosis (AS) which has the characteristic pulsus parvus et tardus.

Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve. It may be caused due to the calcification of the normal aortic valve or the congenital bicuspid valve, and rheumatic heart disease. Narrowing of the aortic valve causes a decreased stroke volume. This results in a weak pulse (Parvus) which rises slowly to a delayed peak (tardus), best appreciated in the carotid arteries.

The clinical features of AS are:

  • Exertional dyspnea: This occurs due to left ventricular (LV) diastolic dysfunction. Raised end-diastolic LV volume and reduced LV compliance lead to increased LV pressure, leading to elevation of pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. 
  • Angina pectoris: This occurs due to the combination of the increased O2 needs of hypertrophied myocardium and the reduction of O2 delivery.
  • Syncope: This occurs due to the combination of decreased cardiac output and systemic arterial dilation which lead to a reduction of cerebral perfusion.

As LV systole gets prolonged, the aortic component of S2 may become synchronous with the pulmonary component. There may also be a paradoxical splitting of S2, where the aortic component follows the pulmonary component. The murmur in aortic stenosis is typically an ejection systolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space and transmitted to the carotids.

The murmur in AS increases in intensity during squatting. This is due to the increase in preload that leads to increased contractility and increased flow across the aortic valve.

Other options:

Option A: Pulsus alternans is defined as beat-to-beat variability in the amplitude of the pulse. It is seen in patients with severe LV dysfunction.

Option B: Pulsus bisferiens also known as bifid pulse has two systolic peaks. It is seen in patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. There is a rapid upstroke to the first peak (percussion wave) and a slower rise to the second peak (tidal wave). It is also rarely appreciated in patients with severe aortic regurgitation.

Option C: Pulsus paradoxus is defined as a fall in systolic pressure > 10mmHg with inspiration. It is seen in patients with pericardial tamponade, severe asthma, massive pulmonary embolism and tension pneumothorax.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect

Inspiration

(↑venous return to right atrium)
  • ↑ intensity of right-sided sounds

Handgrip

(↑afterload )
  • ↑ intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs
  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

Valsalva-Phase II, standing up

(↓ preload)
  • ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur

Rapid squatting

(↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)
  • ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • ↑ intensity of AS, MR, and VSD murmurs
  • MVP: later onset of click/murmur

questions.text:
A 65-year-old female patient with breast cancer undergoes mastectomy followed later by reconstruction with a DIEP flap. Noticing which of the following typical findings in the flap would prompt you to suspect venous compromise?

DIEP - Deep inferior epigastric perforators
questions.solution:
Capillary refill time becoming faster is typically indicative of a venous compromise. The rest of the options are features seen in arterial compromise

Deep inferior epigastric perforators (DIEP) flap is a free flap prone to vascular compromise. Below is an image of the DIEP flap.

Clinical signs of arterial and venous compromise in a free flap:

Clinical Sign

 Arterial Compromise Venous Compromise

Color

 Becoming paler Increasingly reddish or purplish

Temperature 

 Becoming cooler Becoming warmer

Tissue turgor  

 Reducing Increasing

Capillary refill time

 Becoming slower  Becoming faster

Pinprick bleeding

Increasingly sluggish

Quickening (and darkening)

Note that venous and arterial compromise may coexist, and one may lead to the other.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was diagnosed with pilocytic astrocytoma involving the superior cerebellar peduncle. Which of the following tracts may be likely involved by the tumor?
questions.solution:
The anterior spinocerebellar tract enters the cerebellum through the superior cerebellar peduncle and is likely involved by the tumor.  

The first-order neurons carrying fibers for unconscious proprioception from upper and lower limbs synapse with the nucleus dorsalis in the spinal cord. The second-order neurons form the anterior spinocerebellar tract which majorly decussates to the opposite side at the same level and ascends to reach the cerebellum through the superior cerebellar peduncle. It also sends collaterals to the same side as well. Therefore, any lesion in the superior cerebellar peduncle affects the afferents from the anterior spinocerebellar tract. 

The superior cerebellar peduncle includes fibers from deep cerebellar nuclei that project to the brainstem, red nucleus, and thalamus. 

Pilocytic astrocytomas are usually seen in children and the younger adult populations. They commonly affect the cerebellum, but can also appear in the region around the third ventricle, optic nerves, spinal cord, and cerebral hemispheres. They are grade 1 tumors (current WHO classification of CNS tumors) and have a relatively good prognosis. 

Other options:

Cuneocerebellar, olivocerebellar and posterior spinocerebellar tracts pass through the inferior cerebellar peduncle. 

Related Pearl: Cerebellar peduncles and their connections

Peduncle Afferent fibers Efferent fibers

Superior cerebellar peduncle

Anterior spinocerebellar tract
  • Globose - emboliform-rubral pathway
  • Dentatothalamic pathway
Middle cerebellar peduncle -Largest, most lateral and only afferent Corticopontocerebellar pathway -
Inferior cerebellar peduncle
  • Posterior spinocerebellar tract
  • Cuneocerebellar tract
  • Olivocerebellar tract
  • Reticulocerebellar tract
  • Trigeminocerebellar tract
  • Vestibulocerebellar tract
  • Fastigial vestibular pathway
  • Fastigial reticular pathway

questions.text:
You see an elderly man collapse in a shopping mall. He has no pulse. What is the correct sequence to be followed to provide cardio-pulmonary resuscitation to him?
  1. Call for the emergency response team
  2. Check scene safety
  3. Recheck pulse
  4. Chest compressions
questions.solution:
The correct sequence to be followed to provide cardio-pulmonary resuscitation (CPR) to the elderly man is 2-1-4-3.

For a patient in respiratory and cardiac distress, CAB-D (Circulation, Airway, Breathing, Defibrillate) must be assessed:

  1. Assess to make sure the scene is safe for you to attend to the patient.
  2. Assess responsiveness: Speak to the adult and ask if they are ok. Simultaneously look at the chest and abdomen for movement and normal breathing. 
  3. If the patient is unresponsive, call the emergency response team and bring an automatic external defibrillator (AED) to the patient or ask someone nearby to do so.
  4. Place the patient supine on a hard flat surface.
  5. Check for a carotid pulse for 5-10 sec.
  6. If the patient does not have a pulse, proceed with 5 cycles of CPR (lasting approximately 2 minutes).
    • Start with chest compressions:
      • Provide 100-120 compressions per min.
      • Place palms midline, one over the other, on the lower 1/3rd of the patient’s sternum between the nipples.
      • Press to a depth of 2-2.4 inches (5-6 cm) on the patient’s chest.
      • Press hard and fast.
      • Ensure full chest recoil with each compression.
    • Provide 2 rescue breaths for every 30 chest compressions (1 cycle of adult CPR is 30 chest compressions to 2 rescue breaths).
    • Recheck pulse every 2 min.
  7. If the patient has a pulse:
    • Provide 10 rescue breaths per min (1 breath every 6 sec).
    • Recheck pulse every 2 min.
  8. Once the AED arrives, analyze the rhythm for defibrillation:
    • If the rhythm is shockable, assure no one is near the patient, press the shock button, and resume 5 cycles of CPR.
    • If the rhythm is not shockable, initiate 5 cycles of CPR and recheck the rhythm.

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below. 

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

questions.text:
A patient presents with splenomegaly and pancytopenia. The bone marrow specimen stains positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP). Which of the following is true regarding the condition?

1) Leukemia is Annexin A1 positive 
2) It has a very poor prognosis
3) Cells are positive for CD 25 and CD 103
4) It is associated with RET mutations
5) Increased risk of atypical mycobacterial infections
questions.solution:
The given scenario depicts splenomegaly and pancytopenia along with the bone marrow specimen staining positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) indicates hairy cell leukaemia. Statements 1, 3, and 5 are correct regarding this condition.

Haematological malignancy with tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase-positive cells in a patient presenting with splenomegaly and pancytopenia is most likely to be hairy cell leukaemia.  Specific markers are CD 11c, CD 25, CD103, and annexin A1 (statements 1, 3). There can be atypical monocytopenia due to which these patients experience an increased risk of atypical mycobacterial infections (Statement 5).

Hairy cell leukaemia is a neoplasm arising from memory B cells and is associated with BRAF mutations (Statement 4). It mainly occurs in older males and follows an indolent course. Clinical manifestations result largely from infiltration of the bone marrow, liver, and spleen. Massive splenomegaly is a common physical finding. Pancytopenia occurs from marrow involvement and splenic sequestration. It is extremely sensitive to chemotherapeutic agents (Cladribine) and the overall prognosis is excellent (statement 2).

Pathology:

  • Fine hairlike projections that are best recognized under the phase-contrast microscope.
  • A "dry tap" is common on aspiration.
  • Peripheral smear shows  abnormal B cells with fine hair-like cytoplasmic projections characteristic of hairy cell leukemia.
  • Trephine biopsy: Leukemic cells have a nucleus surrounded by a cytoplasmic halo giving them a fried-egg appearance.
  • Detection of annexin A1 in bone marrow specimens has been shown to have 100% sensitivity and specificity in differentiating hairy cell leukemia from other B-cell malignancies.
  • CD11c, CD25, and CD103 are the characteristic immunophenotype diagnostic markers.
  • Cells test positive for pan-B-cell markers such as CD19, CD20, and CD22.
  • Cells stain positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP).

questions.text: A ring fracture in the skull is likely to occur in an individual who has:

choices.text: Been struck on the head with a hockey stick
Fallen on the ground after being hit by a car

questions.solution:
A ring fracture commonly occurs due to a fall from height, with the individual landing on the feet.

A ring fracture is a fracture in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum. If the kinetic energy of the fall is not absorbed by fractures of the legs, pelvis, or spine, the impact is transmitted up the cervical spine. This force may be rammed into the skull, carrying a circle of occipital bone with it.

The image given below shows the fracture line of a ring fracture :

Other Options:

Option A: A close-range gunshot to the head would likely lead to a comminuted fracture of the skull, with the skin wound edges providing more relevant details about the range of firing. 

Option B: A blunt force trauma to the skull with a heavy weapon is more likely to produce a depressed or signature fracture.

Option C: A patient who sustains a head injury by contact force spread over a large area is more likely to have a fissured or linear fracture, but may also sustain a comminuted fracture.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text:
The beneficiaries of the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) scheme are:
  1. Pregnant and nursing women
  2. Children younger than 3 years
  3. Children between 3 and 6 years of age
  4. Adolescent girls from 11 to 18 years old
  5. Other women between 15 and 45 years old
questions.solution:
All five statements with regard to the beneficiaries of the Integrated child development services (ICDS) are correct.

Integrated child development services was launched on the 2nd of October, 1975, and focuses on early childhood care and development. The scheme helps in providing preschool non-formal education and breaking the vicious cycle of malnutrition, morbidity, reduced learning capacity, and mortality. Beneficiaries under the scheme are children in the age group of 0-6 years, pregnant women, lactating mothers among others.

Related Pearl: Integrated child development services (ICDS)

questions.text: A patient presents with a productive cough, fever, and history of recurrent episodes of sinusitis and otitis media. On examination, the point of maximum cardiac impulse is palpable in the right fifth intercostal space. Which of the following proteins is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of respiratory infection with a history of recurrent sinusitis and otitis media with dextrocardia (point of maximum cardiac impulse is palpable in the right fifth intercostal space) is suggestive of Kartagener syndrome in which the dynein arm of cilia is defective. 

Kartagener’s syndrome( primary ciliary dyskinesia) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the triad of:

  • Situs inversus
  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Bronchiectasis

Dyneins(microtubules) present in the axonemes power ciliary and flagellar movement. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis. Males with this condition suffer from sperm dysmotility(asthenospermia) leading to infertility. 

Other options :

Option A,C,D : Vimentin, desmin and laminin are intermediate filaments.Vimentin is present in fibroblasts and endothelium(mesenchymal tissue). Desmin is present in muscle fibres. Laminin is present in nuclear lamina.

questions.text: The action of 5-lipo-oxygenase (5-LOX) on arachidonic acid (AA) produces a potent non-cysteinyl factor that plays a role in the chemotaxis and adhesion of neutrophils. What is this factor?
questions.solution:
LTB4 is a potent chemotactic agent and activator of neutrophils that causes the aggregation and adhesion of the cells to venular endothelium, generation of ROS, and release of lysosomal enzymes.

The cysteinyl-containing leukotrienes LTC4, LTD4, and LTE4 cause intense vasoconstriction, bronchospasm (important in asthma), and increased permeability of venules.

Leukotrienes are more potent than histamine in increasing vascular permeability and causing bronchospasm.

Systemic: fever, metabolic abnormalities, hypotension (shock)

Complement Leukocyte chemotaxis and activation, direct target killing (membrane attack complex), vasodilation (mast cell stimulation)

Note: Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is a prostaglandin, which is a potent vasoconstrictor

questions.text: Biopsy of a neck mass following chemotherapy shows multiple shrunken eosinophilic tumor cells. Which substance released by the mitochondria is responsible for the observed changes?
questions.solution:
A histopathological slide showing multiple shrunken eosinophilic cells without surrounding inflammation is suggestive of apoptosis. The mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway, initiated by the exposure of BCL proteins to substances that can damage the DNA like chemotherapy, leads to apoptosis by the release of cytochrome c which causes caspase activation and subsequent cell death.

There are two pathways that can lead to caspase activation and cause apoptosis of the cell.

  Mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway Death receptor or extrinsic pathway
Activation inside the cell Activation outside the cell

Occurs in response to:

DNA damage
Radiation
Infection

 Involved in:

Elimination of self-reactive lymphocytes
Killing of target cells by cytotoxic T-cells
Leakage of cytochrome-c results in the formation of Cyt.c-APAF1 complex, followed by apoptosome formation FasL on T-cells binds to Fas bind adapter proteins via death domain
Activation of caspase 9 Activation of caspases 8 and 10

Both pathways converge into a common pathway that involves the activation of caspases 3, 6, 7 (executioner caspases)

APAF-1 - Apoptotic peptidase activating factor-1

TNF - Tumor necrosis factor

Option A: CD95 or Fas ligand is involved in the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis and not the mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway.

Options B and C: Are involved in cellular death due to inflammation and necrosis and would not be associated with shrunken eosinophilic cells following chemotherapy.

questions.text: La-belle indifference is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
La-belle indifference is seen in conversion disorder. It is the absence of concern towards one’s problem despite the apparent severe disability.

A conversion reaction is an acute and temporary loss or alteration in motor or sensory function triggered by psychosocial stress. Most of the patients have a history of traumatic events in childhood. The symptoms or deficits of conversion disorder are not intentionally produced. 

Symptoms of conversion disorder include:

  • Mutism, blindness, and paralysis are the most common symptoms.
  • Sensory system: Anesthesia and paresthesia
  • Motor system: Abnormal movements, gait disturbance (astasia abasia), weakness, paralysis, tics, jerks, etc.
  • Central nervous system: Pseudo-seizures

Other options: 

Option A: Illness anxiety disorder - The person may or may not have a medical illness but whose anxiety is out of proportion to their diagnosis and assumes the worst possible outcome imaginable.

Option B: Factitious disorder - The person simulates, induces, or aggravates illness to receive medical attention, regardless of whether or not they are ill. They may inflict injury to themselves or people close to them to receive medical care. There is no other motivation like avoidance of duty or financial gain.

Option C: Malingering - The person seeks hospitalization, similar to individuals with factitious disorder, however, this is driven by primary motivations like avoidance of duty, legal responsibility, or financial gain.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male smoker came to the medicine emergency department with complaints of pain in the abdomen and neuro-psychiatric symptoms. ECG showed a short QT interval. Blood investigation findings are given below. What could be the likely cause of the given condition?

S. calcium- raised
S. phosphate- low
S. PTH < 50 picogram/dl

PTH - Parathyroid hormone
questions.solution:
An elderly male smoker with complaints of pain in the abdomen, neuro-psychiatric symptoms with short QT interval with elevated serum Ca2+, low serum phosphate and low PTH , points to a diagnosis of hypercalcemia of malignancy caused by PTH related peptide PTHrP) due to paraneoplastic syndrome (as seen in squamous cell carcinoma).

Squamous cell lung carcinoma produces PTH-related peptide (PTHrP), mimicking effects of PTH on bone and the kidney. In PTHrP-mediated hypercalcemia of malignancy, PTH levels are suppressed (<50pg/dl)  by the high serum calcium levels. 

Other options : 

Option B : Parathyroid adenoma will present with ↑ PTH, ↑ S.Ca2+ and ↓ S. phosphate.

Option C : Secondary hyperparathyroidism commonly occurs in chronic renal failure. There is deficiency of 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D, causing low serum calcium. This will present as ↓ Ca2+, ↑ PTH (in response to low calcium), and ↑ phosphate (because it is not getting excreted in CKD).

Option D : Vit D intoxication will present with ↓PTH, ↑Ca2 and ↑ phosphate.

questions.text: A biochemistry resident studies a reaction between succinate and succinate dehydrogenase in the presence of malonate. A Lineweaver-Burk plot is drawn for the same. Which of the following can be done to overcome the type of interaction shown below?

choices.text: Increase the concentration of succinate dehydrogenase

questions.solution:
The lineweaver burk plot shows an increase in Km with Vmax remaining the same is suggestive of competitive inhibition. The effect of competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate (succinate). 

Competitive inhibition is a type of inhibition that occurs when the inhibitor binds reversibly to the same site that the substrate would normally occupy. It, therefore, competes with the substrate for binding to the enzyme active site. In the given reaction, succinate is the substrate, succinate dehydrogenase is the enzyme and malonate is the competitive inhibitor. So, increasing the concentration of substrate which is succinate makes the reaction overcome the inhibition done by malonate.

Related Pearl: Difference between Reversible and Irreversible Inhibitors

Irreversible Inhibitors

Binds via non-covalent interaction

Binds via covalent interactions

No chemical change

Inhibitor binds to the substrate & prevent catalytic activity of enzymes

Can be reversed, as there is no bonding between the inhibitor & substrate

Irreversibility due to strong covalent bonding

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

questions.text: A 23-year-old girl who is an alleged victim of rape is brought to the casualty. Samples are collected for the detection of semen. Which of the following tests is not useful in the detection of semen?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given tests, the Teichmann test is not used for semen detection. 

The Teichmann test or hemin crystal test is used to detect suspected bloodstains. It is performed by placing a small piece of suspected material on a glass slide. Then, 2-3 drops of glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride are added to the glass slide and covered with a coverslip. The slide is then heated.

If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of hemin or hematin chloride appear. When hydrogen peroxide is added, the hematin crystals produce bubbles of gas.

Other options:

Option B: P30 assay is a test to look for a glycoprotein produced by the prostate gland present in the semen (even of aspermic male), blood, and urine of a male. It may be found in the vagina up to 27 hours after intercourse. It is a reliable indicator of semen irrespective of acid phosphatase levels or the presence of sperm. 

Option C: Barberio test is used to detect seminal fluid and probably detect the presence of prostatic secretions. When a saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Option D: Acid phosphatase test detects the presence of high levels of acid phosphatase in seminal stains (low levels may be present in the vagina). Positive reactions are found till 36 hours, after which the levels fall and disappear within 72 hours.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A middle-aged man currently on sotalol is to be switched to another antiarrhythmic belonging to the same class. Which of the following drugs could be used?
questions.solution:
Sotalol belongs to class III antiarrhythmics, to which ibutilide belongs as well. Hence, ibutilide can be used.

Sotalol has a high risk of torsades de pointes and hence should be changed to other class III antiarrhythmics with less side effects after regular evaluation.

Option A: Esmolol belongs to class II(beta blockers) antiarrhythmics and the major side effects include bradycardia and hypotension.

Option C: Propafenone belongs to the class IC antiarrhythmics and the major side effects include worsening of heart failure and bronchospasm due to its additional beta blocking action.

Option D: Diltiazem belongs to class IV antiarrhythmics and the major side effects include hypotension, bradycardia, atrioventricular block and constipation.

questions.text:
The threshold for MCA systolic velocity in moderate to severe anemia in fetus is------MOM.

MoM - multiple of meridian

MCA - middle cerebral artery
questions.solution:
• MCA PSV >1.5 multiples of the median (MoMs) for corresponding gestational age predicts moderate to severe fetal anemia.
  • In most specialized centers, serial measurement of the peak systolic velocity of the fetal middle cerebral artery has replaced amniocentesis for the detection of fetal anemia.
  • The anemic fetus shunts blood preferentially to the brain to maintain adequate oxygenation. The velocity increases because of increased cardiac output and decreased blood viscosity.

If the MCA peak systolic velocity exceeds 1.5 MoM, further evaluation by fetal blood sampling is necessary to assess the need for fetal transfusion.

questions.text: You are a medical officer at a blood bank. Following a medical camp, you have obtained around 10 units of cryoprecipitate. Which of these conditions cannot be treated with cryoprecipitate?
questions.solution:
Cryoprecipitate can be used in patients with Haemophilia A, von Willebrand disease, hypofibrinogenemia, and factor XIII deficiency as it contains factor VIII, von Willebrand factor, factor XIII and fibrinogen. Cryoprecipitate does not contain factor IX and factor XI. Therefore it cannot be used in patients with hemophilia B and factor XI deficiency.

Cryoprecipitate is prepared from fresh frozen plasma by thawing it to +4°C. The plasma is then centrifuged to obtain cryoprecipitate. It is stored at a temperature of–25°C or colder for up to 1 year after the date of phlebotomy.

During the administration of cryoprecipitate, ABO compatibility should be checked. After thawing, it should be transfused as soon as possible or maximum within 6 hours.

Uses of other blood components

Whole blood- Red cell replacement in acute blood loss with hypovolemia, and exchange transfusion.

Red cell concentrates- In patients with anaemia. Whole blood and red cell concentrates are stored between +2°C and +6°C .

Platelets concentrates- These can be stored up to 5 days at +20°C to +24°C, with agitation. It is used in thrombocytopenia, platelet function defects, disseminated intravascular coagulation, during massive blood transfusion to prevent dilutional thrombocytopenia, and in bone marrow failure.

Fresh frozen plasma- FFP is plasma prepared from whole blood, either from the primary centrifugation of whole blood into red cells and plasma or from secondary centrifugation of platelet rich plasma. It is stored at –25°C or colder for up to 1 year. Before use, it should be thawed in the blood transfusion centre between +30°C and +37°C. It contains stable clotting factors, albumin, immunoglobulin and Factor VIII. It can be used in coagulation factor deficiency, reversing the effects of warfarin, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency where the specific concentrate is unavailable.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with abdominal pain. Examination reveals slate grey skin pigmentation and hepatomegaly. His liver biopsy shows golden-yellow granules in periportal hepatocytes.  Histopathological staining with Prussian Blue is shown in the image below.  All are true about this condition except:
questions.solution:
The image shows Prussian blue-stained section of liver tissue showing extensive haemosiderin deposition stained blue. The most likely diagnosis is hereditary haemochromatosis. In haemochromatosis, the testes may be small and atrophic, secondary to a derangement in the hypothalamic-pituitary axis resulting in reduced gonadotropin and testosterone levels.

Hemochromatosis is caused by excessive iron absorption, most of which is deposited in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas, followed by heart, joints, and endocrine organs.

When hemochromatosis results from an inherited disorder, it is referred to as hereditary hemochromatosis. In hereditary hemochromatosis, HFE, HJV, or TFR2 gene mutations reduce hepcidin synthesis. Due to decreased hepcidin-ferroportin interaction, ferroportin activity and iron efflux from enterocytes increases, giving rise to systemic iron overload.

Fully developed cases exhibit
(1) micronodular cirrhosis in all patients
(2) diabetes mellitus in 75% to 80% of patients
(3) abnormal skin pigmentation in 75% to 80% of patients

Symptoms usually first appear in the fourth to fifth decades of life in men and later in women.

The manifestations of classic hemochromatosis include hepatomegaly, abdominal pain, hypogonadism, abnormal skin pigmentation (particularly in sunexposed areas), deranged glucose homeostasis or diabetes mellitus due to destruction of pancreatic islets, cardiac dysfunction (arrhythmias, cardiomyopathy), and atypical arthritis. A significant cause of death is hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: A 26 year old sexually active male was presenting with recurrent gonococcal infections.  Which of the following complement deficiency is most specific to this condition?
questions.solution:
Recurrent gonococcal infections are seen in C5 complement deficiency. This is because, neisseria gonorrhoea is a thin walled bacterium. And C5 is a terminal component of complement, required for the assembly of the membrane attack complex involved in the lysis of organisms. Hence the deficiency of these late acting components leads to recurrent Neisseria (gonococcal and meningococcal) infections.

C5 to C9 Recurrent infections with Neisseria
Properdin Meningococcal meningitis
Factor D Meningitis, sepsis - Neisseria

questions.text: A 55 year-old man with cirrhosis presents with progressive dyspnea that worsens significantly when he sits and improves when he lies down. Pulse oximetry reveals hypoxemia in the upright position. What is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This is a clinical vignette of hepatopulmonary syndrome (HPS), characterized by platypnea (dyspnea worsening on standing and relief on lying supine) in patients with portal hypertension due to cirrhosis.

Hepatopulmonary syndrome (HPS) is a rare complication of cirrhosis characterized by hypoxia without significant lung disease. The development of abnormal vascular connections within the lungs (intrapulmonary vascular shunts), bypasses gas exchange in the alveoli, and is a characteristic of hepatopulmonary syndrome. Additionally, metabolites (rich in H+ ions) produced in a cirrhotic patient leads to additional vasodilation of the lung vessels.

Since the shunts typically arise in the lung bases, an upright posture causes the patient's shunt fraction to rise.  This leads to orthodeoxia (hypoxia in the upright position) and platypnea (the sensation of shortness of breath when upright). This is due to the majority of the blood supply being diverted to the lower lobes and thus bypassing the oxygen rich upper lobes.

Other options:

Option A: Pulmonary edema is not likely to present with platypnea and orthodoxia. While fluid accumulation can occur in the lungs with advanced cirrhosis, it is also important to note that the primary mechanism of HPS-related dyspnea is shunting, not edema. 

Option C: Portopulmonary hypertension presents with hypoxia and symptoms of right heart failure. Platypnea and orthodoxia are not classical.

Option D: Ascites can cause pleural effusions, but these typically cause dyspnea regardless of posture, not the characteristic platypnea seen in HPS.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presenting with a hard breast lump was diagnosed with breast cancer. She also has a strong familial history of breast cancer in her first degree relative. She most likely inherited a mutation in a gene that is responsible for which of the following functions?
questions.solution:
Familial breast cancer should be suspected in cases of a young female presenting with breast cancer along with a strong family history. Familial breast cancer is associated with mutations of tumor suppressor genes BRCA1 and BRCA2 which are involved in the repair of double-stranded DNA breaks. 

BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes. Mutations of these genes are associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. In addition to breast cancer, women with BRCA1 mutations have a higher risk of developing epithelial ovarian cancers, and men have a slightly higher risk of prostate cancer. BRCA2 is associated with male breast cancer and cancers of the ovary, prostate, pancreas, bile ducts, stomach, melanocytes, and B lymphocytes.

Few germline BRCA2 mutations can cause Fanconi anaemia. Both BRCA proteins and Fanconi proteins function together in a DNA damage response network linked to homologous recombination repair. Defects in this pathway can lead to the activation of a nonhomologous end-joining pathway that can result in telomere shortening.

Related Pearl: Comparison between BRCA 1 and BRCA 2:

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes.

Carcinoma breast occurs at an earlier age and is bilateral and multicentric in inherited forms compared to sporadic cases.

  BRCA 1 BRCA 2
Location Long arm of chromosome 17  Long arm of chromosome 13
Differentiation Poorly differentiated Well-differentiated
Hormone receptor status ER/PR- Negative, Her-2 negative – triple negative ER/PR- Positive
Associated Cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, and prostate (lesser extent), Pancreas (lesser extent)  cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, prostate, pancreas, gall bladder, stomach cancers, and melanoma
Male breast carcinoma Low risk Increased risk
Fanconi’s anemia Not associated Associated
Medullary carcinoma Associated Not associated
