questions.text:
Choose the correct sequence of changes related to putrefaction.

1. Right iliac fossa discoloration

2. Liquefactive changes

3. Relaxation of sphincters 

4. Marbling
questions.solution:
The correct sequence regarding putrefaction is Right iliac fossa discoloration(12-18 hrs)-Marbling(36-48 hrs)-Relaxation of spinchers(2-3 days) -Liquefactive changes(5-10 days).

In putrefaction, bacteria from the gut enter into and multiply in the surrounding tissues, eventually spreading through the blood vessels to other parts of the body. The bacterium Clostridium welchii is largely responsible for the putrefactive changes spreading through the body, due to its production of the enzyme lecithinase. The first external sign of putrefaction in a body lying outside in the air is a greenish discolouration of the skin over the region of the cecum.

Marbling is seen when blood in the vessels is hemolyzed to sulfate-hemoglobin, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance. The marbling of the skin begins at about 24 hours and becomes prominent  36–48 hours after death. It is a visible postmortem change that is characterized by linear branching patterns on skin that correspond to the course of superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

Urine and faeces may escape once the sphincters relax in 2-3 days.

Liquefaction or colliquative changes begin 5 days after death and become prominent in 10 days. Soft tissues change into semisolid masses which are black and get separated from bones and fall off.

Related Pearl: Order of Putrefaction

  • Larynx and trachea – first organ to putrify   
  • Stomach, intestine, and spleen
  • Liver and lungs
  • Brain
  • Heart
  • Kidney and bladder
  • Prostate and uterus – virgin uterus resists putrefaction whereas uterus soon after delivery putrefies rapidly.
  • Skin, muscle, tendon
  • Bones


NOTE: This is only a generalised order of putrefaction, as each case must be assessed as per the attending factors, both endogenous and exogenous.

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of cells that appear at the site of a skin incision to facilitate wound healing?

1. Neutrophils
2.Platelets
3.Macrophages
4.Fibroblasts
questions.solution:
The correct order of appearance of cells after a skin incision for wound healing is platelets-neutrophils-macrophages-fibroblasts. This is an example of healing by primary intention.

Immediately after the platelets would appear at the site of injury as a part of the coagulation cascade. Following hemostasis, the neutrophils appear at the site of injury followed by the macrophages and then the fibroblasts.

The sequence of events and the cells peaking time after an injury are as follows:

  • Within 24 hours : The platelets primarily involve in hemostasis
  • 24 to 48 hours : Polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMN)s infiltrate the wound site.
  • 48 to 96 hours : Macrophages invade the wound site
  • 1 week post injury : T lymphocytes bridge the transition from the inflammatory to the proliferative phase of healing.
  • 2nd week : Continued collagen accumulation ; Fibroblast proliferation
  • End of the 1st month : Scar contains cellular connective tissue ; Covered by an essentially normal epidermis

Related Pearl: Factors Influencing Healing

  • Infection: one of the most important causes of delay in healing; prolongs inflammation; increases the local tissue injury
  • Diabetes: most important systemic cause of abnormal wound healing
  • Nutritional status: protein deficiency and vitamin C deficiency inhibit collagen synthesis and retard healing.
  • Glucocorticoids (steroids): anti-inflammatory effects; results in weakness of the scar due to inhibition of TGF-β production and diminished fibrosis
  • Mechanical factors: such as increased local pressure or torsion; may cause wounds to pull apart or dehisce
  • Poor perfusion: due to arteriosclerosis, diabetes, or obstructed venous drainage; also impairs healing
  • Foreign bodies: such as fragments of steel, glass, or even bone; impede healing
  • Type and extent of tissue injury: affect subsequent repair;
  • Location of the injury and the character of the injured tissue: also important

questions.text: A man presented with fever, cough, and chest pain for 2 weeks. Chest X-ray showed bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Bronchoscopy revealed non-caseating granulomas. What is the gold standard investigation, if you suspect histoplasmosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Culture on Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) is the gold standard for diagnosing histoplasmosis. This involves isolating and identifying the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum from a tissue sample (usually skin or lymph node) grown on SDA.

In SDA – white cottony mycelia growth can be seen.

Histoplasmosis caused by Histoplasma capsulatum is a thermally dimorphic fungus. The yeast form occurs mainly in tissues at a temperature of 37 °C and the mycelial form occurs in the soil at 25 °C. At room temperature, white, cottony, mycelial growth appears, with large (8-20 μ) thick-walled, spherical spores with tubercles (finger-like projections called tuberculate spores). Transmission is mainly via inhalation of microconidia. Treatment involves liposomal amphotericin B,  followed by itraconazole for at least 12 months.

Other options:

Option B: Chest X-ray can show findings suggestive of histoplasmosis, such as lung nodules, cavitations, or hilar adenopathy. However, these findings are not specific and can be seen in other lung diseases.

Option C: Serological tests can detect antibodies against Histoplasma capsulatum in the blood. However, these tests can be positive even in people who have had a past infection and are not currently sick. They can also be negative in people with early or disseminated histoplasmosis.

Option D: Urine antigen detection is a newer test that can detect Histoplasma antigen in the urine. This test is less invasive than tissue culture but is not as specific or sensitive.

questions.text: Identify the test given in the image below. Which of the following parameters can be measured by this test?
questions.solution:
The given image shows A-scan ultrasonography, which is used to determine the IOL power calculation

A-scan ultrasonography is used to determine the axial length of the eyeball for IOL power calculation(option B), anterior chamber depth(option A), and thickness of intraocular mass(option D). Average corneal curvature is measured by keratometry(option B) and not A-scan.

A-scan is used for determining the axial length and can be acquired by direct contact (as shown in the image) or by using a water bath over the eye (immersion ultrasonography). The sound beam must be aligned with the visual axis for maximal precision. Each reflecting surface is represented by a spike on the oscilloscope monitor.

The A-scan is also needed to measure the intraocular lens power. The most widely used formula for intraocular lens power calculation is the Sanders-Retzlaff-Kraff formula, given by: 

E = A - 2.5L - 0.9K

The value of L, which is the axial length of the eyeball, is calculated using the A-scan ultrasonographic biometry.

E is the emmetropic power designated for the eye.

A is the constant specific for each lens type.
L is the axial length of the eyeball in mm determined using the A-scan ultrasonography.
K is the average corneal curvature determined by keratometry.

A scan along with B scan helps to determine the outline of the intraocular tumour in case of hazy media. (option D)

questions.text: A child is below 3rd percentile for height. His growth velocity is normal, and chronological age is more than skeletal age. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
This boy with small stature and a normal growth velocity, as well as a chronological age that exceeds the skeletal age is coherent with a constitutional delay in growth.

Constitutional delay is the most common cause of delayed growth in children. The ultimate height attained is normal as well as children do have a normal growth velocity. Patients with constitutional delay have Bone age < Chronological age. It is also important to note that IGF -1 levels remain low for chronological age.

In summary there are 2 types of normal variants of short stature are :

Constitutional delay: – Bone age < Chronological age

Familial short stature: – Bone age = Chronological age (Option A)

Short stature can be defined as growth below the expected genetic potential or below -2 SD for age and sex. If a child's stature is less than -3 SD below the average for their age and gender it is more likely to indicate pathological short stature. A child's height between -2 and -3 SD is more likely due to physiological, i.e. familial or constitutional short stature.

Given below is a graphical representation showing the various patterns of the causes of short stature.

Other options:

Option B: Seckel Syndrome, Silver-Russell Syndrome, Microcephalic Osteodysplastic Primordial Dwarfism types I/III, II, and Meier-Gorlin Syndrome are all classified as primordial dwarfism. Due to the disorganized molecular and genomic alterations that occur during the embryonic stage, this group of genetic disorders is distinguished by postnatal growth abnormalities and intrauterine growth retardation. 

Option D: Patients with hypopituitarism have a growth curve that initially follows the average pattern but then deviates below the mean curve and gradually tapers off. This represents postnatal onset pathologic short stature. 

Related Pearl: Short stature: Familial vs Constitutional

Feature Constitutional Delay Familial Short Stature  
Height Short Short
Final Height Normal Short  
Family history Delayed puberty Short stature  
Bone age Less than chronological age Normal  
Puberty Delayed Normal  
Height velocity Normal Normal

questions.text: A patient presents with a lesion over his face that has a ‘stuck on’ appearance as shown in the image below. This has remained unchanged for some years. The rest of his clinical evaluation is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate next step in management ?
questions.solution:
The above lesion is seborrhoeic keratosis, given the history of it remained unchanged for some years and in sun-exposed areas like the face. If the lesion doesn’t show any malignant features like sudden change in size or change in colour, observation would be the best plan. 

If any malignant features are there, skin biopsy should be done to rule out malignancy and destructive procedures like complete excision, curettage or laser ablation should not be done.

questions.text: NEXUS criteria include all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The ability to rotate the neck actively is not included in NEXUS criteria.

In trauma patients, without the need for radiologic imaging, the decision to discontinue the cervical c-spine collar can be made using the clinical tools namely:

  • National Emergency X-Radiography Utilization Study (NEXUS)
  • Canadian C-spine rule (CCR)

NEXUS criteria: There are five criteria included under NEXUS. If a trauma patient meets all five criteria, then no radiography is required and the cervical c-spine collar may be removed. However, if any one of the criteria is not met then radiography is done to evaluate further.

The NEXUS criteria include:

  1. No posterior midline cervical spinal tenderness
  2. No evidence of intoxication
  3. A normal level of alertness
  4. No focal neurologic deficit
  5. No painful distracting injuries

questions.text: Estimation of glycated hemoglobin at half-yearly intervals in patients diagnosed with diabetes mellitus is part of:
questions.solution:
Estimation of glycated haemoglobin at half-yearly intervals in patients diagnosed with diabetes mellitus is part of secondary prevention.

Prevention and care in diabetes mellitus:

A. Primordial prevention: It involves the prevention of the emergence of risk factors in the countries in which they have not yet appeared.

B. Primary prevention: The scope of primary prevention in diabetes mellitus is currently limited. It involves the elimination of environmental risk factors. The preventive measures include:

  • Maintenance of normal body weight through the adoption of healthy nutritional habits and physical exercise.
  • The nutritional habits include an adequate protein intake, a high intake of dietary fibre and avoidance of sweet foods.
  • Elimination of other less well-defined factors such as protein deficiency and food toxins.

C. Secondary prevention: It involves preventive measures taken up after diabetes is detected. The aims of treatment include maintenance of normal blood sugar and maintenance of ideal body weight. The preventive measures include:

  • Routine checking of blood sugar, of urine for proteins and ketones, of blood pressure, visual acuity and weight.
  • Examination of feet for any defective blood circulation, loss of sensation and the health of the skin.
  • Estimation of glycated (glycosylated) haemoglobin at half-yearly intervals.
  • Self-care, which includes adherence to diet and drug regimens, the examination of his own urine and where possible blood glucose monitoring; self-administration of insulin, abstinence from alcohol, maintenance of optimum weight, attending periodic check-ups, recognition of symptoms associated with glycosuria and hypoglycaemia, etc.

D. Tertiary prevention: It involves limiting the disability occurring in patients with diabetes through its complications, e.g., blindness, kidney failure, coronary thrombosis, gangrene of the lower extremities, etc. The measures include:

  • Establishing specialized diabetic clinics to provide care of the highest order.
  • The clinics should be involved in basic, clinical, and epidemiological research.
  • Establishing local and national registries for diabetics.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is amiloride.

Amiloride belongs to the K+-sparing diuretic group. It is a renal epithelial Na+ channel(ENac) inhibitor in collecting duct cells. Lithium enters through the ENac and inhibits the action of the anti-diuretic hormone. Amiloride blocks the entry of Li+ ion through the ENac and thus mitigates diabetes insipidus induced by lithium.

The most important adverse effect of amiloride is hyperkalemia. Other adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, and headache.

Other options:

Option A: Demeclocycline belongs to the tetracycline group of antibiotics. It interferes with the anti-diuretic hormone action but is used in the treatment of the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone(SIADH). 

Option B: Thiazide diuretics inhibit the Na+-Cl- symport present in the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron. It is used in the treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus by decreasing the ability of the kidney to excrete free water. It increases the reabsorption of water in the proximal tubule and reduces the ability of the distal tubule to dilute the urine. 

Option C: Tolvaptan is a vasopressin antagonist used in the treatment of SIADH, hypervolemic and euvolemic hyponatremia.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with a D shaped pupil?
questions.solution:
Iridodialysis refers to detachment of the iris root from the ciliary body and is associated with a D-shaped pupil. A black biconvex area is seen at the periphery at the site of detachment.

Other options:

Festooned pupil - It is seen in posterior synechiae with the adhesion of the pupillary margin to the lens capsule.(option A)

Iris bombe(option D) refers to the forward bowing of the iris seen in closed-angle glaucoma with irido-lenticular contact and in seclusio pupillae with 360-degree posterior synechiae. Drainage of aqueous is blocked due to the irido-lenticular apposition and pressure of the accumulated aqueous causes the iris to bow forward.

Iridodonesis(option B) refers to a tremulous iris caused by a lack of support. It is seen in pseudophakia after cataract surgery and in lens dislocation.
